IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Name of Applicant (Last, first, middle): Berkowitz, Bruce A. The proposed research is relevant to public health because aging patients remain vulnerable to the devastating dementia associated with Alzheimer’s disease, a disease without any treatment options to prevent or delay its trajectory. Accumulating evidence highlights hyperactive neurons in its very beginning stages as an important driver of Alzheimer’s disease. Here, we propose new imaging biomarkers of hyperactive neurons in the retina, the most accessible part of the nervous system, to enable very early evaluation of treatment efficacy in patients at risk for Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: Glaucoma is a blinding disease associated with elevated eye pressure, progressive death of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and is estimated that, over 76 million people will be affected by 2020. Nitric oxide, a small gaseous molecule known to act as a key player in relaxing the trabecular meshwork (TM) cells in eye and has potential to reduce eye pressure, however, free radicals generated during the disease pathology deplete the nitric oxide bioavailability as well as responsible for both TM cells and RGCs death. Our group is working on discovering such multi-functional hybrid small molecules which will decrease eye pressure and protect TM cells as well as RGCs from free radical induced death with potential to be used for treatment of glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Teleophthalmology using retinal cameras in primary care clinics has been shown to improve diabetic eye screening rates and visual outcomes, but remains greatly underutilized in the U.S. This multi-center randomized controlled trial proposes to test the effectiveness and generalizability of a promising implementation program (I- SITE: Implementation to Sustain Impact in Teleophthalmology) for sustaining increased diabetic eye screening rates using teleophthalmology in rural health systems. This research seeks to identify methods for successful integration of telemedicine technology into rural primary care workflows to prevent blindness from diabetes, the leading cause of blindness among working-age U.S. adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL Lower grade (World Health Organization (WHO) grade II/III) glioma (LGG), a malignant tumor of the brain, is a uniformly fatal disease of young adults for which the optimal clinical management remains unknown. A comprehensive genomic characterization of the evolution from primary LGG to recurrence is required to begin to address the LGG knowledge gap. As optimizing the engagement of LGG patients in this effort is critical to the success of this process, we will use our International Low Grade Glioma Registry as a starting point to development methods to engage and construct a community of 700 LGG patients who have undergone surgical resection at time of diagnosis and at time of recurrence and want to participate in research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Frontotemporal dementia (FTD, also known as frontotemporal lobar dementia or FTLD) is an age-related non-Alzheimer dementia characterized by progressive degeneration of cortical neurons in the frontal and temporal lobes, which share a wide spectrum of clinical, pathological and genetic features with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). A subset of FTD is defined by the pathology of protein inclusions containing Fused in Sarcoma (FUS), namely FUS FTD that is caused by pathogenic FUS mutations. This project is to determine the mechanisms how pathogenic FUS interferes with RNA surveillance and turnover, disrupts protein translation, and induces downstream cellular toxicity in cortical neurons in FTD using in vitro and animal models as well as FTD patient tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The brain consumes a disproportionate amount of energy, and it is not known how the brain balances its energetic needs with those of the rest of the body. Proposed studies investigate a mechanism by which a protein that evolved from a virus directly transmits needs from the brain to fat storage cells. The goal is to transform our understanding of how energy imbalance, such as in obesity, perturbs neurodevelopment and cognitive functions.

PHR: This Lakota Center for Health Research NARCH program project renewal application will: 1) Continue the productive partnership with 3 Lakota Sioux Tribes in western South Dakota; 2) Focus research on a culturally- relevant, trauma-informed mindfulness-based smoking cessation for Northern Plains Tribal women who have experienced intimate partner violence; 3) Implement a community wastewater treatment testing process, including SARS-CoV-2, on the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Reservation; and 4) Build further capacity within our Tribal partners for the support and conduct of future health disparities-related research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to create systemic and sustainable culture change to support inclusive excellence in research by recruiting clusters of faculty focused on health disparities, specifically in the areas of cancer, obesity and diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and neuroscience. We will recruit and select 12 junior faculty who are committed to diversity, and provide supportive institutional environments to facilitate their development of successful independent research programs. Support will include individual career development, infrastructure and assistance, opportunities for networking and collaboration, and changes to policy and environment to reduce isolation, build community, and increase retention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. Washington University supports a large and diverse group of vision scientists who, collectively, make a substantial contribution to the diagnosis and treatment of blinding eye disease. The provision of shared resources and technical support through the Center Core allows investigators to make far more rapid scientific progress than would otherwise be possible. Additionally, the Center Core fosters collaborations between established investigators, draws new researchers to vision research, and supports the career development of junior faculty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to study RNA polymerase III-specific CD8+ T cells in the peripheral blood and target tissues of patients with co-incident cancer and scleroderma. Identifying distinct RNA polymerase III epitopes recognized by CD8+ T cells, which we believe to play a fundamental role in disease initiation and propagation, may inform us of candidate disease-specific diagnostic, monitoring and therapeutic tools. Moreover, this proposal seeks to enhance our understanding of the mechanistic relationship between cancer and autoimmunity in general.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SD BRIN has supported a robust network of faculty researchers throughout South Dakota in developing and maintaining new areas of biomedical research by providing expert resources in core facilities available to all researchers. In addition, SD BRIN has maintained a strong undergraduate research fellows program at predominantly undergraduate institutions (PUI) with growing research cultures to develop future biomedical researchers and to assist faculty mentors with their cutting-edge research efforts. The faculty fellows program has allowed PUI faculty to concentrate on their research efforts and use this support to increase publications and application to external funding agencies.

PHR: Project Narrative. This K99/R00 Pathway to Independence Award will prepare the candidate to become an independent, mixed-methods ELSI researcher pursing a research program on ethical issues related to the actionability of genomic information. The study examines the values and assumptions underlying conceptualizations of the actionability of genomic information for healthy populations. Results of the study will contribute to the ethical and effective implementation of genomic sequencing into care for healthy populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Islet transplantation is a cure for Type 1 diabetes, but transplanted islets are susceptible to immune-mediated destruction. Encapsulation of islets with a protective biomaterial that retains insulin secretion, but also prevents recognition by the immune system is highly desired. We will determine if islet encapsulation with a novel antioxidant and immune system modulator, tannic acid and CTLA-4-Ig, respectively, can mediate immune suppression and prolong islet function after transplantation in a subcutaneous site.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to public health since Ewing sarcoma (EWS) is the second most common bone tumor of children and treatment remains suboptimal, with survival rates for patients who present without metastatic disease plateaued at 70% and less than 30% for patients who present with metastatic disease. Due to the dose intensity of current standard therapies, patients who survive EWS experience an unacceptable incidence and severity of late effects. The proposed research is highly relevant to the NIH mission, as it seeks to discover new approaches to harness the immune system for the treatment of EWS, which will deliver novel therapeutics for testing in this disease and will also provide generalizable knowledge regarding optimal approaches to develop immunotherapies for low mutational burden cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately one million transrectal prostate biopsies are performed annually in the U.S., and the risk of post- biopsy infection is increasing due to greater antibiotic resistance of rectal flora. Preliminary data demonstrates that a transperineal MRI-targeted biopsy approach under local anesthesia compared to the standard practice transrectal MRI-targeted prostate biopsy has a much lower risk of infection, comparable pain/discomfort and may improve detection of prostate cancer. Our pivotal randomized controlled trial will be the first prospective study to evaluate in-office transperineal MRI targeted prostate biopsy, and if our hypotheses proves true transperineal MRI-targeted biopsy will become the new standard of care and significantly reduce post-biopsy infections and increase detection of clinically significant prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This work will establish that reduction in SELENOF levels is an underlying biological factor contributing to racial disparity in breast cancer, and thus supports the development of SELENOF-based therapeutics. Successful completion of pre-clinical studies on two different therapeutic strategies investigated here may result in personalized and more effective therapy options for African American patients affected by low SELENOF. SELENOF polymorphisms and protein levels can be developed into biomarkers to identify African American patients at risk of lethal breast cancer disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: Overall The overall goal of the National Center for Engagement in Diabetes Equity Research: National CEDER is to strengthen the engagement of communities and individuals from diverse backgrounds and sectors in type 2 diabetes (T2D) research across the research spectrum and the United States. National CEDER will achieve this goal by 1) creating a centralized, national network infrastructure, 2) creating a partnership hub model that will inform T2D research priorities and methods, 3) developing a robust studio and consultancy model rooted in bi- directional capacity building and co-leadership, and 4) collaborating to disseminate best practices and lessons learned. National CEDER is an expansive partnership consisting of 18 schools of public health, schools of medicine, and minority-serving institutions; and 10 regional and national community based organizations reaching diverse African American, Latinx, Asian American, Native Hawaiian, Pacific Islander, and American Indian/Alaska Native communities, geographic areas, and communities facing historical marginalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Cognitive behavioral therapy with exposure and response prevention is highly effective for children with OCD, yet not all children will fully remit. Exposure therapy requires leveraging extensive cognitive control, which is shown to be altered in youth with OCD. This project will leverage a child-friendly, computerized, at-home cognitive training program in 8–12-year-olds with OCD to enhance the capacity for cognitive control (target engagement) and augment response to exposure therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies of the visual experience of infants are relevant to public health because impaired vision and visual learning have long term consequences across many domains of a healthy and successful life. Disrupted visual experience in infancy is evident in the continued risk in perceptual, cognitive and school achievements and is implicated in the nexus of disrupted visual learning and motor development of children with more general developmental disorders. Determining the expected and normative early visual input in infancy and its links to infant eye- movements and behaviors is expected to give rise to new diagnostics and behavioral interventions for at-risk infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-range goal of the “Building a Culture of Health and Action” Project is to create a national deep engagement learning model of Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Math (STEAM) education that engages 8th - 12th graders and provides them with the tools, skills and support to document, reflect upon, and communicate issues of concern (through an advisory board and Photovoice); collect soil and dust samples (through co-created citizen/community science); and make sense of data so that their results can inform actions at the local, regional, and even national level (through data visualization and environmental communication). The proposed educational program is focused on social determinants of health and environmental health in rural, medically underserved communities in Arizona that neighbor resource extraction. In the context of learning, environmental health education objectives include understanding: (1) how advisory boards can foster the development of critical thinking and communication skills; (2) how a summer certification program can increase environmental health literacy (EHL); (3) how an equity-centered community design approach to data sharing strategies can build a participant’s EHL; and (4) how to successfully broaden participation in STEAM learning by historically underrepresented individuals living in environmentally compromised spaces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Neuroinflammation has been associated with a variety of neurodegenerative diseases, but the pathology of neuroinflammation in glaucoma is unique due to the highly localized nature of glial reactivity in the optic nerve head as RGC axons exit the eye, correlated with the initial site of injury along RGC axons. While animal models have demonstrated the contributions of neuroinflammation to the pathology of glaucoma, important differences exist between animal models and human patients, including low conservation of RGCs as well as numerous functional differences in glia. Thus, to better recapitulate interactions between RGCs and glia in glaucoma, the current application leverages human pluripotent stem cell-derived retinal ganglion cells, astrocytes, and microglia in a robust and reproducible in vitro microfluidic platform that recreates the spatial interactions of glia upon human RGC axons relevant to the neuroinflammatory phenotypes observed in glaucoma.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Complex patients with chronic health conditions are much more likely to experience medication errors, poor healthcare outcomes, and higher healthcare costs compared to people with shorter-term or fewer health ailments. This study seeks to conceptualize, design, implement, and test a Medication Safety Map for the community pharmacy setting to enhance pharmacists’ and technicians’ abilities to either avoid, or to quickly identify and recover from, medication errors before patient safety is endangered. The Medication Safety Map is an innovative approach that will be used by pharmacists and pharmacy technicians to better navigate the complex tasks in the pharmacy, and to facilitate communication with both patients and clinicians, while safely providing medications to complex patients with chronic health conditions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Engineering Resilient Community Pharmacies (ENRICH)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The high prevalence of multiple chronic conditions (MCCs) and geriatric syndromes among older adults make it difficult to diagnose Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD); biomarkers may enhance diagnosis, but many questions remain regarding accuracy and utility of these biomarkers in primary care for prognosis, patient preference, disclosure, and ethical considerations. The overall goal of the Alzheimer’s Diagnosis in older Adults with Chronic Conditions (ADACC) Network is to establish a national consortium consisting of multi- disciplinary and multi-site investigators that will develop evidence-backed strategies for the use, interpretation, and implementation of biomarkers for the diagnosis of ADRD in older patients with MCCs. The network will include existing diverse observational and real-world cohorts, a Steering Committee, Data Coordinating Center, and working groups; will fund three pilot projects each year; and convene an annual meeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since release of the 2016 CDC Guideline for Prescribing Opioids for Chronic Pain, over 200,000 Veterans Health Administration (VHA) patients have had their long-term opioid therapy (LTOT) discontinued despite unclear long-term health risks and limited knowledge about the barriers to, and clinical effectiveness of the therapies used to supplement LTOT taper, such as non-pharmacological modalities (NPM). This project will leverage VHA electronic health record data to provide needed information to healthcare providers, healthcare administrators, and policy makers on the health consequences of LTOT taper or discontinuation among adults living with chronic pain, barriers to receipt of NPM for veterans who taper or discontinue LTOT, and whether use of NPM affects clinical outcomes on a large scale, which is crucial information for establishing safe and effective strategies for tapering prescription opioids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender and non-binary persons (TGNB) experience intimate partner violence (IPV) at alarming rates and prior work has linked IPV with sexual risk-taking behavior and to increased risk for HIV seroconversion among TGNB, but less is known about the impact of IPV on HIV/STI testing, pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) uptake, and the persistence of PrEP use among subgroups of TGNB. The proposed innovative observational cohort study will examine how various forms of IPV (e.g., physical, sexual, emotional, TGNB-identity specific), in the context of steady or casual intimate relationships contribute to HIV/STI risk and protective behaviors among TGNB persons over a 24-month timeframe. This research will advance our understanding of both the risk and resilience factors relevant to preventing and reducing IPV, reducing HIV risk behaviors, and increasing HIV protective behaviors among diverse TGNB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 400,000 people in the United States are living with hidradenitis suppurative (HS), which is a chronic inflammatory disease marked by painful, recurrent skin abscesses, cysts, draining sinus tracts, and disfiguring scarring that disproportionately affects racial and ethnic minority groups. To address our limited understanding of the underlying factors that lead to the development and severity of hidradenitis suppurativa, this research proposal will examine individual-level, interpersonal-level, and community-level factors that influence hidradenitis suppurativa epidemiology, outcomes, and care experiences in a racially and socioeconomically diverse study population. This will enable the development and evaluation of evidence-based targeted interventions to improve outcomes in populations disproportionately burdened by this devasting disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To understand function of every human gene, the Molecular Phenotypes of Null Alleles in Cells (MorPhiC) program is experimentally deleting each gene in tissue culture cells and then applying cutting-edge molecular tools to determine how the deletion affects the cells' behavior. Because transcription factors regulate the genes that control cell behaviors, our goal is to ensure that the effects of transcription factor deletion on the cells are accurately and consistently quantified so that this information can ultimately be used by the biomedical community to improve healthcare. Thus, we propose to establish a MorPhiC Data Analysis and Validation Center to 1) computationally analyze the quality of multiple types of genomic data collected from these cells and 2) determine whether these data can be used to accurately identify the network of genes regulated by a specific transcription factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Everyday tasks such as reading and driving require a healthy eye movement control system in order to keep images in focus. The neuronal mechanisms that control voluntary eye movements are not well understood yet their disruption, due to disease or dysfunction, can have debilitating effects. The studies in this proposal seek to advance our understanding of these mechanisms with the goal of laying the groundwork for improved treatment when they go awry.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Narrative Beginning in early childhood, children living in low-income circumstances are twice as likely to experience developmental delay in at least one domain including motor, cognitive, communication, and social-emotional; for Black and Latino children, this risk is compounded by structural racism. Further, racial and linguistic disparities exist in both diagnosis of delay and services received. To address these inequities, I will utilize Item Response Theory to design a new developmental assessment computer adaptive test that serves two functions: 1) determination of a child’s development status, and 2) inform primary care-based developmental support interventions and can be delivered in team-based care models.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Advancing Equity in Early Childhood Developmental Screening Through Item Response Theory and User-Centered Design

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Currently, no brief psychotherapy interventions for anxiety exist for VA primary care settings - where many Veterans seek care. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is a first line treatment for anxiety but Primary Care Mental Health Integration (PCMHI) providers need an intervention approach for anxiety disorders that is a brief, problem-focused, and fits into their system of care. The proposed 4-year, multisite trial will use a pragmatic randomized design to examine the effectiveness and implementation potential of a brief CBT intervention for anxiety either in-person or via VA Video Connect-Home (VVC-H), according to patient preference. Brief CBT will be delivered by existing PCMHI providers at three large VAMCs. Primary aims will examine the clinical effectiveness of bCBT vs. enhanced usual care for anxiety and quality of life outcomes at 4-, 8- and 12-month follow-ups. Secondary aims will predict treatment response and use of VVC-H. This project aligns with VA initiatives to use telehealth and implementation science to increase Veterans’ access to high-quality care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The burden of visual disability in the U.S. is substantial, and the challenges confronted by several population subgroups are similar to those with visual disability in Thailand. We will use next-generation mapping and localization technology to support microservices that are embedded in a novel wearable, serving as a smart service system to improve the mobility and health of individuals in these populations. Our transdisciplinary and global team will use a patient-centered approach that leverages input from study participants and visual disability experts for improved function and usability, ultimately benefitting visually impaired persons worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The prognosis for GBM patients remains dismal and there is an urgent unmet need for novel therapies. The first oncolytic virus to be approved by the FDA is an oncolytic HSV whose use is prescribed for melanoma patients. To increase the utility of this novel approach for brain tumor patients we propose to create and optimize a lead HSV derived virus for development for clinical intracranial use without affecting neurologic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microphthalmia, anophthalmia and coloboma (MAC) are severe ocular phenotypes characterized by a reduction in size or absence of the eye or a gap (hole) involving ocular structures. This project will study the genetic mechanisms of MAC using human samples and zebrafish models. The results of this study will increase our understanding of MAC spectrum, generate relevant animal models, and allow for the development of advanced therapies in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep disordered breathing (SDB) is a significant public health concern that impacts 10.5-17.1% of youth. Non- Latinx Black children are 4-6 times more likely than non-Latinx White children to evidence SDB; and Black children also experience increased OSAS severity and subjective sleepiness when diagnosed, and less neurobehavioral improvement following OSAS treatment. The purpose of this project is to identify socio- ecological factors at the individual child, family, healthcare setting, neighborhood, and broader socio-cultural levels contribute to racial disparities in SDB consequences and timely therapeutic options in Black and White children with SDB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is important to public health because it will lead to the critical understanding of how nucleic acids recognize ligands and drugs in terms of the basic thermodynamics underlying intermolecular interactions. Use of advanced force fields will allow computation of binding energetics to within an accuracy of 1 kcal/mol. The methodology and calculations proposed will help enable a new era of drug design where unique chemical structures are accurately designed and evaluated by computational means alone, especially for the targeting of small molecules-RNA interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular stress response is a common pathway for cells to respond to daily stress. It is dysregulated in many human diseases accompanied by disrupted daily rhythms. Understanding its interactions with the body clock is therefore fundamentally important for understanding general principles of biological systems and for treating these diseases using its FDA-approved modulators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite decades of research about the centrality of behavioral and psychosocial factors in supporting health and mental health outcomes of people with diabetes, there are few empirically supported interventions in the field, and a larger, more diverse field of well-trained behavioral scientists is needed to make progress. This K26 proposes to expand Dr. Marisa Hilliard’s capacity to provide in-depth, strengths-based, culturally aware research mentorship to a diverse, multidisciplinary group of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and other early career researchers interested in behavioral research for youth and young adults with type 1 diabetes and their families. To strengthen her skills for working with a highly diverse pool of mentees, Dr. Hilliard will engage in targeted research mentor training experiences and receive individual coaching from two established mentorship experts, focusing on fostering an anti-racist, culturally aware mentorship approach that is tailored to learners’ individual strengths, developmental level, and goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Environmental exposures with carcinogenic potential are a concern to individuals living in Minnesota, including poly- and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), glyphosate (RoundUp), and radon. The impact of these exposures may be especially relevant for populations that have been typically under-represented in existing cohort studies such as individuals living in rural areas, racial/ethnic minorities, and immigrants. We are proposing to launch a new cohort study to investigate these relevant exposures and risk of malignancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Dysfunction of the cerebrovasculature is a common factor in many diseases of the brain, including neurodegenerative diseases, cerebrovascular diseases, as well as in aging. Next-generation models of the cerebrovasculature will enable study of the underlying physical and biochemical processes that regulate these processes in health and disease. The overall goal of this project is to use zonation- and age-specific intrinsic and extrinsic cues to reverse engineer human cerebrovascular models, and to use these models to understand cerebrovascular phenotype during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Approximately one-quarter of all suicides occur among patients who are within 3 months of discharge from a psychiatric hospital. Intensive outpatient programs/partial hospitalization programs (IOP/PHPs) have been instituted to help care for high-risk patients who do not fully require 24-hour supervision, but there is a tremendous amount of regional variation in access; while IOP/PHPs are readily available in some regions of the United States, they are virtually nonexistent in others. Using linkage with the National Death Index, this project will examine the effectiveness of IOP/PHP as a service intervention to reduce the risk of suicide death in the post-hospital discharge period compared to standard outpatient follow-up care among Medicaid recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is an essential imaging technique for management of many common eye conditions, including diabetic retinopathy, age-related macular degeneration, and glaucoma. OCT has a limited eye screening role outside of ophthalmology offices due to personnel and training barriers, however. This project seeks to develop a robotic point-of-care approach for semi-automated OCT imaging that may eventually enable chronic eye disease surveillance in primary care offices and non-specialist clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Non-human primates (NHP) such as baboon, cynomolgus macaque, rhesus macaque, and vervet are susceptible to the same age-related health challenges and diseases as humans. The overall aging trajectory in NHP is also influenced by stressors and lifestyle similar to humans. Research in NHP allows for controlled environments, providing longitudinal data with less “noise” than in human studies. Identification of molecular mechanisms underlying aging in multiple NHP species will significantly increase the likelihood that these mechanisms translate to human aging. The goals of this study are to generate an integrated NHP resource to support aging studies (R21 phase), and to demonstrate the utility of this resource for comparative omic studies in four NHP species (R33 phase).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proteins mediating mitochondrial calcium uptake have been identified but many of their roles in calcium transport and beyond remain an enigma. We will test if the MICU regulators of calcium uptake are important for individual cells’ calcium signal fingerprints, for redox homeostasis and for fusion-fission and cristae dynamics of the mitochondria. These studies will inform on the pathways by which MICUs support mitochondrial structure, dynamics and signaling, and on the pathogenesis initiated by their perturbations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Learning to make good decisions in the present, and accurately recalling events and information from the past, are critical aspects of human cognition that are often impaired in many psychiatric disorders. This project aims to identify the how the choices we make influence what, and how, we remember by combining disparate techniques in computational modeling and direct brain recordings in human subjects. The results of this project will identify specific neurocomputational mechanisms unifying decision-making and memory processes, and the skills gained will prepare me to become an independent investigator in this field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer is the second most common cancer diagnosed in males worldwide, and a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. At this time, there is a significant unmet need for identifying men at initial diagnosis who will develop more aggressive disease possibly leading to symptoms, metastases, or death. This project proposes the combination of clinically established prognostic biomarkers and radiomic signatures extracted from magnetic resonance imaging of the prostate gland, co-registered with diffusion basis spectrum imaging (DBSI), and matrix- assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI) imaging, to optimally select candidates for active surveillance from males being assessed at initial diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Although messenger RNA (mRNA) as a therapeutic holds tremendous promise, bottlenecks to development, application, and manufacturing arise due to current enzyme-based production methods. Solid-phase synthesis of chemically defined mRNAs offers an ideal solution but also presents its own challenges, including compatibility with translation and mRNA synthesis size limits. To address these challenges and unlock a new generation of mRNA therapeutics, this project creates and studies solid- phase synthesized mRNAs with diverse chemical modifications and unnatural linkages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative River blindness is a major neglected tropical disease caused by the filarial nematode Onchocerca volvulus with 21 million people estimated to be affected, 99% of whom live in sub-Saharan Africa. The main intervention strategy relies on annual or bi-annual mass drug administration (MDA) of ivermectin, however, in areas of high endemicity and intense transmission, elimination is unlikely to be achieved within reasonable time frameworks, if at all, using ivermectin MDA on its own. Alternative and complementary therapeutic strategies are urgently needed at this crucial point in the path from control to elimination. The long-term goal of this project is to overcome this barrier by rationally identifying, optimizing, and developing new drug candidates and novel integrated treatment regimens to complement current control interventions, and consequently enhance the probability and feasibility of eliminating this devastating disease which mainly affects the most marginalized populations of rural Africa. 2

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Lyme disease, a bacterial infection which has become the most common vector-borne disease in the United States, poses a diagnostic challenge to clinicians and a threat of chronic illness to patients. The current paradigm for diagnosis of Lyme disease relies on a two-step laboratory- based testing approach. In this Phase II proposal, we will complete the development of a simple and accurate one-step test for Lyme disease that can be carried out in an average, non- specialized laboratory, enabling faster diagnosis and consequently more appropriate treatment for patients, and we will validate its performance in a clinical study to support an FDA submission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed randomized control trial challenges the dogma of symptom-based diagnosis and empiric management of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in high-risk convalescing infants by seeking objective evidence criteria and testing the efficacy of natural maturation, acid- suppressive medication (proton-pump inhibitor) and added rice cereal formula with equipoise. The diagnosis of GERD and the consequences of its therapies, e.g., the added burden of an extra $70k and 30 days of hospitalization per infant, are a highly relevant public health concern. Our study will likely overcome the critical barrier to progress by providing the scientific basis of managing vulnerable infants, thereby enhancing digestive health, overall nutrition, growth, and quality of life in infants, all relevant to the mission of NIH (NIDDK).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Megalin captures proteins from the urinary space to produce an essentially protein-free urine, thereby protecting the kidney tubules from damage caused by proteinuria. Megalin recycles between cell surface and intracellular compartments to carry out this function, but the molecular basis for this recycling is not well understood. I will use structural approaches to study the molecular basis of its recycling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Anhedonia, the inability to seek-out and experience pleasure, is a common symptom in depression that predicts treatment-resistance and is sometimes exacerbated by first-line antidepressants. Anhedonia decreases goal-directed behavior and related neural activity. The research generated in this proposal will investigate which neural circuits play a causal role in goal-directed behavior, how enhancing related neural activity increases goal-directed behavior, and target engagement in a potential treatment paradigm of five-consecutive days of stimulation in depressed patients with anhedonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the >330,000 Americans hospitalized annually for hip fractures, acute pain is primarily managed through parenteral opioids, which are associated with increased delirium, increased length of stay, and recurrent opioid use after initial exposure in the emergency department (ED). Although alternative hip fracture pain management techniques are employed in the ED that are proven to reduce opioid usage and improve outcomes, such as the pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block, broad utilization is limited by lack of access to the training required to achieve competency and challenging workflow requirements. The goal of this project is to develop and validate an ultrasound-based regional anesthesia guidance system that provides workflow intelligence to overcome barriers to ED use of the PENG block, increases utilization of the technique, and ultimately improves patient access to opioid-sparing analgesia for hip fracture pain.

PHR: NARRATIVE: GLNARCH OVERALL  This Great Lakes Native American Research Centers for Health (GLNARCH) is housed at the Great Lakes Inter-Tribal Council. This application aligns established partnerships to promote a synergistic education, training, and research within the Indian Health Service Bemidji Region with increased focus on including Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs). This application proposes an unprecedented endeavor to engage AI/AN populations in an indigenized (culturally responsive) research and training agenda. The Center is composed of an Administrative Core, Capacity Building project (NEHR), a Career Enhancement project (SCEP), and a Pilot Project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: GLNARCH XII Administrative Core  The GLNARCH administrative core is a team who have promoted health science careers and research within the Bemidji Region since 2003. This Great Lakes Native American Research Centers for Health (GLNARCH) application aligns established partnerships to generate a network of resources for AI/AN consortia as well as continue support for our impactful programs. The overall mission of the GLNARCH Administrative Core is to ensure the AI/AN Tribes remain central to NARCH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Pilot Project, Healing from Within.  The proposed pilot study uses a mixed-methods and community engaged approach to identify and understand barriers to help-seeking among Indigenous women with co-occurring mental health and/or substance use disorders after experiences of gender-based violence, and to understand how resiliency and cultural identity may help to motivate help- seeking among Indigenous women survivors of GBV in the local context of Wisconsin. This proposed pilot study is the first of its kind in Wisconsin by being Indigenous led, and through the formation of academic community partnerships between universities, 3 of Wisconsin’s 11 federally recognized tribes, Indigenous-led organizations, and tribal community leaders across the State.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this investigation, we will use nuclear imaging to study the in vivo behavior and health effects of polystyrene micro- and nanoplastics in mammals under environmentally relevant concentrations. Determining the biodistribution, biokinetics, and bioretention of these materials will shed light upon the mechanisms of their toxicity and has the potential to impact decision-making on the remediation of plastic pollutants as well as the exposure of workers and the public to these materials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many types of blindness result from the neurons of the retina no longer being able to communicate with the brain due to injury or disease. In mammals, the adult retina cannot make new retinal ganglion cells (the neurons that connect the retina with the brain) to replace those that are lost. In this project, I aim to learn about normal development of retinal ganglion cells and, further, to make new retinal ganglion cells from retinal cell types that can divide and produce neurons in adults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: This project will investigate brain changes that occur throughout the first year of formal schooling, a year  of foundational learning that has consequences for future academic attainment and other major life  outcomes. Understanding the brain mechanisms that support emerging reading and mathematics  throughout this first year is crucial for developing biomarkers that can identify children at risk of future  difficulties and may identify windows of great plasticity within the first-grade year for optimal intervention.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Neurocognitive impairment (NCI) in HIV common and as people with HIV (PWH) live longer and experience higher rates of comorbidities, rates of NCI are likely to increase. This study will develop exploratory multimodal (e.g., demographic, medical, inflammation) longitudinal phenotypes of NCI risk among aging Malaysians with HIV. To do so, we will also adapt and validate the NeuroScreen neurocognitive testing tablet app for use in Malaysia and generate locally derived norms and NCI cut-off scores for its use there and in phenotype development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis is a leading cause of death in patients with severe burn injury, accounting for nearly 75% of mortality among burn patients. However, it is difficult to detect burn patients at higher risk of sepsis at the time of intensive care unit presentation and recognize sepsis in burn patients. In this proposal, we will use proteomics analysis of immune dysregulation and cardiovascular injury to define sub-phenotypes of patients and linked to the risk of secondary sepsis in burn patients and identify proteomic signatures specific to sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Statement Spinal cord injury results in debilitating motor deficits, neuropathic pain, autonomic dysfunction, bladder, bowel, and sexual dysfunction. The objective of this proposal is to inform the design of multi-modal rehabilitation therapies – i.e., those specifically intended to restore multiple functions simultaneously. If successful, this work could lead to a new, more efficacious therapies for individuals living with spinal cord injury.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Deterioration of kidney function, or acute kidney injury (AKI) is an important contributing factor to the morbidity and mortality of hospitalized veterans. We previously showed that Tamm-Horsfall Protein (THP), a glycoprotein made by the kidney, protects the kidneys in the setting of injury. This projects will validate the use of recombinant THP as a therapeutioc tool to treat AKI. Therefore, this project has improtant direct relevance to veterans health, as it will aid towards the development of recominant THP as a therapeutic drug to be used to treat kidney injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emerging field of comparative oncology may provide a novel solution to rare human cancer studies, as genomic resources, reference genomes and non-human model cancer sequencing data are proliferating rapidly. We propose to, for the first time, develop and apply new machine learning methods to jointly analyze and integrate information from hundreds of mammalian genomes to identify pan-mammalian mechanisms of cancer resistance and susceptibility, and apply those insights in human cancers. To disseminate this date to the wider community and catalyze further research we will develop a tumor compendium, portal, and toolkit that will allow other researchers to leverage pan-mammalian comparative genomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study addresses the worldwide escalating burden of Parkinson’s disease (PD) by characterizing the molecular, cellular, and network-wide mechanisms of deep brain stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus (STN DBS) in PD. This will not only expand our fundamental understanding of the intricate connections between α- synuclein aggregation, neuroinflammation, and senescence in PD but will also offer a transformative avenue to enhance health and mitigate progression of this debilitating disorder. Using rigorous translational investigations, this study will apply innovative DBS interventions to potentially reduce disability and lengthen lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical trial of omalizumab for allergen sensitized and exposed individuals with COPD (COPD OMA) is a multi- center phase II randomized, masked, placebo-controlled clinical trial that tests the efficacy of omalizumab in improving risk for exacerbations, disease status, and lung function among individuals with COPD having sensitization with exposure to common indoor allergens. If efficacious, this study will be impactful in demonstrating allergic sensitization and exposure as a treatable trait among individuals with COPD with high risk for adverse outcomes for whom novel treatment strategies are greatly needed. Additionally, this study will provide insight into relevant biologic endotypes associated with increased responsiveness to treatment using molecular signatures of airway inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to uncover novel points of intervention for future drug development. Regulatory mechanisms for RGS protein function represent a largely untapped area of investigation for the purpose of uncovering more druggable targeting strategies than the RGS proteins themselves. Thus, this research is relevant to the mission of the NIGMS because it provides basic research that increases our understanding of biological processes and lays the foundation for advances in disease treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: End stage disease of the kidneys, heart, lungs, or liver shorten the lives of veterans and solid organ transplantation of these organs is life saving. Transplantation requires life-long medications that reduce the function of the recipients’ immune systems. These medications are needed to keep the recipient from rejecting and losing the transplant, but also cause several complications including what are termed opportunistic infections. Cytomegalovirus or CMV is a virus that 60-70% of the population is infected with at a young age and is never cleared, but rather is kept in check throughout life by an active immune system. In settings of reduced immune system such as after transplant, CMV can recur resulting in illness including loss of the transplant or even death. Even when suppressed, CMV has profound effects on the immune system. This proposal seeks to better understand both the immune response to CMV and alterations to the immune system caused by CMV in veteran transplant recipients with the eventual goal of improving the lives of these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Since 1993, the University of Washington’s annual Principles of STI/HIV Research and Public Health Practice Course has provided participants with a state-of-the-art intensive, interdisciplinary, two-week introduction to the fundamentals of behavioral, clinical, epidemiologic, statistical, implementation, and basic science research and practice in HIV and sexually transmitted infections (STI). Participants are often new and early-stage investigators from global locations. The course is designed to increase success in identifying important knowledge gaps, asking impactful research questions, procuring research funding, and establishing cross-disciplinary research collaborations in the field of STI and HIV/AIDS.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: LGBT Veterans have faced a long history of stigma, discrimination, and exclusionary policies that were intended to exclude them from military service. Despite recent shifts in policy and increased staff trainings, existing evidence suggests that this group is at high risk for health disparities, particularly with respect to mental health and health risk behaviors. While informative, the research to date has been limited in several respects: cross-sectional designs, collapsing LGBT subgroups, severe lack of data on some subgroups, problems with identifying a comparison group, and lack of data on risk and protective factors and care experiences. This prospective cohort study will fill these gaps, recruiting and conducting surveys online with 1,600 Veterans to identify health disparities, test a conceptual model of prospective risk and protective factors, and assess VA utilization, barriers to care, and treatment preferences. Data from this study will inform future intervention efforts to achieve health equity for LGBT Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Veterans with diabetes are more likely than diabetic civilians to develop chronic disabling peripheral neuropathic pain (CDNP). Research on frontline treatments for CDNP (enhanced glycemic control, exercise, pharmacological agents), shows inconsistent outcomes and dissatisfaction among Veterans. Veterans and clinicians have shown significant interest in cannabis derivatives (THC, CBD) for neuropathic pain control, but there are no well-controlled trials guiding expectations for benefit and adverse outcomes associated with cannabis for CDNP. Because Veterans are likely to present with pain and pain-related polymorbidity significant differing from that of civilians, a well-structured clinical trial of cannabinoids for Veterans with CDNP is vital. The present study will offer the first evidence describing the potential benefits and adverse effects of cannabinoids for CDNP in Veterans using a four-arm, double-blind, multisite randomized trial comparing THC, CBD, THC+CBD and placebo on neuropathic pain outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Bladder cancer is a tumor associated with aging. We have hypothesized this is due to increased inflammation that drives cancer formation and progression in aged patients or aged animals and that this may be related to age associated alterations in the gut microbiota. We hope to reduce this inflammation through direct interventions against neutrophils or through microbial transplantation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Inflammatory bowel disease has one of the highest hospitalization rates among veterans (>100,000 hospitalizations from 1975-2006). Current therapies primarily involve systemic immune suppression. This carries certain risks, including an increased risk of infection and malignancy. The risks are more significant with increasing age, duration of use and in patients who require a combination of drugs for disease control. Additionally, many patients do not respond to available therapies and the costs of many options are significant. The veteran population includes a substantial proportion of older patients susceptible to these risks, as well as young patients who may have to be on these medications long term. To address these problems, novel and safer therapeutic strategies are needed. This project is designed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of targeted activation of two important homeostatic pathways using novel approaches that can be harnessed to characterize and translate the potential of other mucosal homeostatic pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PATH is an innovative intervention that builds on years of strong theoretical, experimental, and clinical work to target key interconnected maladaptive (unproductive processing, avoidance, and impaired reward sensitivity) and adaptive processes (updating/reappraisal, approach, and positive affect) related to persistent, stressful life event-related psychopathology (e.g., depression, posttraumatic stress disorder). This brief 6 session intervention focuses on processing of negative destabilizing life events, positive life events, and future events. It has the potential to enhance treatment engagement and outcome, build resilience, prevent relapse, and ultimately to reduce the substantial and costly burden of stressor-related psychopathology.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Heart disease remains the leading cause of death in Veterans. Inflammation in the arteries of the heart may increase the risk of cardiac death. Patients with heart disease undergoing major surgery are at increased risk of complications after surgery, including heart attack, stroke, and death. The proposed research seeks to better understand the role of inflammation in the damage to the heart and blood vessels after major surgery. This research also seeks to identify the potential beneficial role of a safe medication, colchicine, which has direct effects on inflammatory cells and has been used in the treatment of inflammatory diseases for more than 2000 years, on reducing the rate of complications after surgery. With its quick onset of action and excellent safety profile, colchicine may have the potential to reduce risk of heart injury, stroke, or death after major surgery.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Prostate cancer is a disease with a remarkably high impact on Veteran health. Not only is it the most common cancer diagnosed in Veterans, with nearly 15,000 new cases diagnosed each year, but Veteran men get diagnosed with prostate cancer at nearly twice the rate of the general population. Unfortunately, even with treatment, many of these Veterans will eventually die from their prostate cancer. New, effective prostate cancer treatments are therefore desperately needed. While this research begins in the lab, current laboratory research models do a notoriously poor job of identifying therapies that will be effective in patients. We have therefore developed a new cell culture platform, called Stacks, that enables improved modeling of patient tumors in the lab using their own cells. Our primary objective in the proposal will be to determine whether the Stacks platform can better mirror the biology inside patient tumors and more accurately predict the effectiveness of prostate cancer therapies in Veteran men with metastatic prostate cancer than currently available platforms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Breast cancer is the most common cancer and the second most common cause of death in women. Lack of mechanistic understanding on how a breast cancer in situ develops into malignant invasive breast cancer contributes to growing problem of both overtreatment and undertreatment. To address this, we propose to develop three-dimensional organoid model using cell lines and primary patient-derived cells. Based on existing studies and our own preliminary studies, we hypothesize that organoid size-induced hypoxia and secretome factors work cooperatively to initiate and maintain the migratory phenotype. We will use integrated bioengineering, computational and imaging approaches to test this hypothesis and discover novel druggable targets to stop emergence of migratory phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Arthropod borne flaviviruses, such as Dengue, produce non-coding RNAs that function to benefit these viruses during infection. Specifically, these non-coding RNAs (termed sfRNAs) have been shown to be involved in pathogenicity, interferon repression, RNAi repression, along with many other functions, indicating that they are important to understand in order to better arm ourselves with potential new therapies. This study will focus on unveiling the specific coordination observed in relevant tandem xrRNA structures located within the flavivirus 3′ UTR, as well as how these sfRNAs attenuate the mosquito RNAi immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Domesticated animals have provided invaluable insights into biological and biomedical traits important to hu- man health, but most are not easily amenable to experimentation. Here, we propose to develop and use Sia- mese Fighting Fish, Betta splendens, as a powerful new vertebrate model system by developing genetic tools and by studying the molecular bases of anatomical diversity and the genetic and neuronal bases of their ex- treme aggressive behavior.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients suffer from heart attacks at rates well above the general population. Heart disease results in part from abnormal function of endothelial cells that prevent artery clogging cholesterol plaques from forming. Half of SLE patients also develop kidney disease that can lead to kidney failure. We propose a paradigm shift to focus on endothelial cell dysfunction as a mediator of inflammation in the kidney as well as in heart disease. Based on the results of the prior funding period, we will test the effectiveness of a medicine that restores endothelial function (sepiapterin) to treat lupus-like kidney disease and improve endothelial function in mice with lupus kidney disease. We will study its ability to prevent kidney disease, induce remission of kidney disease along with standard treatment, and maintain remission after withdrawal of the standard medication. We will study alternative ways that endothelial dysfunction occurs and how sepiapterin works to improve outcomes to inform future human studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), the most devastating and least treatable form of stroke, is induced by a ruptured blood vessel within the brain. Unfortunately, no FDA-approved therapies currently exist to recover the extensive loss of brain function after ICH, contributing to the poor quality of life in ICH survivors. Our proposed state-of-the-art studies will determine whether remote ischemic conditioning (RIC), a simple, safe, and non- invasive therapy that involves the repetitive inflation-deflation of a blood pressure cuff on the arm, restores brain function in a pre-clinical model of ICH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative RNA viruses are significant, ever-evolving pathogens that cause morbidity and mortality worldwide, and therapeutic interventions are scant. Here, we propose to investigate how these viruses rely on small metabolites called polyamines for replication. We will also characterize how polyamines interconnect with other metabolic pathways, highlighting opportunities for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Retrotransposons are ancient DNA elements that self-replicate within our genome and now make up 45% of our genetic material. Expression of retrotransposons presents acute dangers to cell viability and occurs during the progression of multiple human diseases such as cancer, and chronic inflammation. This proposal aims to decipher the epigenetic defense mechanisms that silencing retrotransposon expression and to understand how dysregulation of these mechanisms occurs in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Consumption or rejection of food are outcomes of a hierarchical multisensory decision-making process. Food-related decisions must frequently resolve conflicts, such as whether to consume a fruit that is visually appealing but smells rotten. Such decisions require neural substrates for evaluating characteristics of food—appearance, smell, taste, touch—and comparing/contrasting such characteristics to decide whether to approach, assess, and/or consume. Food-related decisions and their neural mechanisms are hugely important in human life, and dysfunction leads to disorders such as obesity, diabetes, and heart disease. We study food-related decision making in Drosophila melanogaster flies and Caenorhabditis elegans nematode worms, which have simpler behavioral repertoires, are highly experimentally tractable, and have proven utility at generating biological insights of relevance to mammalian model systems and human beings.

PROJECT_TITLE: Biological Mechanisms of Food-Related Decision Making

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Necroptosis is a type of genetically encoded necrotic cell death that is associated with many human diseases, including cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, liver injury, pancreatitis, neurodegenerative disorders, and a diverse range of viral, bacterial, and fungal infections, including SARS-CoV-2. Here, we aim to decode the molecular mechanisms of necroptosis regulation at its execution stage. Our work will pave the way for future anti-microbial therapies, as well as treatments for diseases that involve necroptosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with severe speech and motor impairment often have difficulty with accessing communication technology, which is increasingly based on interaction with computers. This project aims to develop new methods of interacting with computers via decoding newly discovered brain signals to provide restoration of movement and communication. Successful completion of this project could allow this marginalized segment of the US population to once again have the means to manage their health care, form meaningful relationships, have a means for recreation and entertainment, and interact socially with their health care providers and loved ones.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veteran surgical patients commonly suffer critical illness, and a high percentage of these patients in the intensive care units incur stress-related injuries to their very vulnerable intestinal lining. These injuries can result in malnutrition, overwhelming bacterial infection, and death. Despite the medical advances of the past few decades, therapies for these stress injuries are, for the most part, conservative, as there is no current pharmacologic therapy available. This proposal explores the use of a new molecule that could potentially prevent injury and loss of the intestinal epithelial cells, and lead to improved outcomes of critically ill Veteran patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will establish the feasibility, acceptability and credibility of a novel, live video mind-body program, “Toolkit for Optimal Recovery after Concussions; TOR-C”, aimed at preventing persistent symptoms following uncomplicated mild traumatic brain injury (aka mTBI) among college-age individuals with anxiety. This age group experiences among the highest prevalence of concussions, and up to 40% of these individuals have comorbid anxiety. A brief, tailored mind body program delivered to this high risk population during the window of opportunity of the acute phase has the potential to decrease conversion to costly and challenging-to-treat chronic symptoms of mTBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Little is known about the molecular, structural, and physiology features of human nociceptors, the neurons responsible for detecting and transmitting pain signals to the brain. The proposed Harvard PRECISION Pain Center will provide fundamentally new insight into the molecules expressed in human nociceptors, how these molecular features correlate with nociceptor activity, and how they interact with the cells and molecules that are present in painful human neuromas that drive phantom limb pain. We envision that the intersection of these data types will have valuable implications for prioritizing new pain therapeutic targets and interpreting how human genetic variation contributes to chronic pain.

ORG_NAME: MASSIVE ANALYSIS AND QUALITY CONTROL SOC
PHR: The MAQC Society seeks to enhance reproducibility, and quality control across high throughput biomedical research. Through the annual society conference, the MAQC Society promotes education, best practices, collaboration, and idea exchange across sectors, training levels, and communities. Educating scientists around the world about ways to enhance the rigorousness of their research will enable more successful translation of research to positively impact patient lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States and the number of cancer deaths is growing. The increasingly burdensome, unbeneficial care received by cancer patients at the end-of-life has been identified by the National Academy of Medicine as a major public health problem. This application proposes to test powerful psychosocial approaches to reduce the suffering and improve the delivery of cancer care both for the patients with end- stage disease as well as for the family members who love, care for, inherit cancer risk from, and, ultimately, survive them.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will advance public health by developing new CAHPS survey items targeted at underserved groups of the U.S. population, evaluate alternative methods of data collection designed to improve response rates, enhance the collection and analysis of patient narrative reports about health care, and assess the impact of CAHPS surveys and reports on quality improvement efforts and patient experiences with care. We will use a health equity focus to better represent and enhance the experiences of care for traditionally underserved patients: racial/ethnic minorities, those with Spanish-language preference, and those with functional limitations. The products include new targeted items, updates to the standard CAHPS health plan and clinician and groups surveys, information about optimal data collection methods, methods to minimize bias in analyzing patient narrative data, and quality improvement demonstrations that improve patient care and promote equity.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (CAHPS) VI

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The CAHPS VI team will develop, test, and maintain CAHPS surveys; survey methods and protocols; and analysis programs. In addition, the team will conduct and evaluate quality improvement projects. The study results, surveys, reporting materials, and quality improvement methods will be communicated and promoted to improve patients’ care experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria are increasingly being appreciated as regulators of immune signaling, including during age- dependent immune dysfunction. MOTS-c is a peptide encoded within the mitochondrial genome that can regulate nuclear gene expression during age-related metabolic stress to increase lipid metabolism and prevent high-fat diet induced obesity. Here, we will test the effect of MOTS-c on preventing and reversing age-related macrophage maladaptation to lipid stress, which will demonstrate that immunity is encoded in both the nuclear and mitochondrial genomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The number of distinct cell types has been increasing throughout the diversification of animals. Despite recent advances in our ability to characterize the molecular identity of individual cells, understanding the processes that result in the origin of truly novel cell types persists as one of the key challenges in developmental biology. The goal of this research project is to probe the capacity of cells to acquire new functions by manipulating the genes that control cell identity and to use this knowledge to produce a cell type that has never arisen naturally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative In biomedical research, the need for a diverse pool of researchers in statistics and data science has never been greater, but the requisite academic pipeline for training such a workforce remains inadequate. SeattleStatSummer (SeattleStatSummer for Biomedical Data Science Research Training) is a summer mentored research program for undergraduate students who identify as underrepresented minorities, and will include an engaging and supportive mentored research experience along with career development, community building, and social/emotional support activities to encourage students to (1) gain skills and confidence in statistics and data science and (2) feel a sense of belonging and rightful place in the statistics and research communities. The goal of SeattleStatSummer will be to promote a diverse workforce to ensure that future biomedical researchers will represent our broader community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Ocular inflammation plays a significant role in vision loss associated with retinal disorders, yet immune cells that facilitate this response are poorly understood due to limitations in imaging these microscopic cells. Using a collection of innovations in high-resolution imaging, this project will image these cells for the first time using a label-free approach combined with fluorescent cell populations to reveal the types and behaviors of immune cells in the living eye as it responds to inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Given the rising burden of obesity, diabetes, and heart disease in the community, new approaches are needed to maintain blood vessel health from the impact of cardiometabolic traits. The proposed research investigates the impact of cardiometabolic diseases on health of the blood vessel lining cells, endothelial cells, by measuring stress markers and gene expression pathways. Our results will clarify how cardiometabolic diseases result in different patterns of endothelial cell gene expression and may identify novel molecular underpinnings of cardiovascular risk that will have important preventive and therapeutic implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia in the elderly. Two major pathological hallmarks are amyloid β plaques accumulation outside of cells and phosphorylated tau tangles within the neurons. Understanding the crosstalk between these two pathologies allows for better capture of the timing of disease development and is crucial for the development of therapeutic targets for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Even though data science and STEM careers offer financial stability, youth who identify as Black, Latinx, women, low-income, or first-generation college students face systemic barriers to pursuing these careers. The proposed project will address this workforce issue by attracting and supporting a diverse group of top science students from Boston, Cambridge, and Everett, Massachusetts high schools with large Black and/or Hispanic enrollment who will be engaged, supported, and encouraged to grow their interest in data science and STEM through a two-year, multi-industry partnership that provides high-level experiential learning opportunities in data science. Combining paid data science internship opportunities and mentorship with college access and persistence, career readiness, and social-emotional learning programming will enable youth to access the financial stability associated with a booming STEM industry without leaving the city where they grew up, while also supporting local industry with a more diverse and well-prepared applicant pool.

PHR: Project narrative: Methylated RNA Immunoprecipitation Sequencing (MeRIP-seq) is a new technology to quantify RNA epigenetics modification. This proposal aims to develop a series of novel statistical methods for MeRIP-seq data preprocessing and analyses, including data normalization, RNA methylation site detection and comparison, and signal deconvolution for data from complex tissues. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The basal amygdala (BA) is important for valence-specific behaviors such as the recall of aversive memories. Understanding learning and memory associated with the BA is especially important considering how dysregulation of tightly regulated emotional behaviors and associations can contribute to anxiety, depression, and PTSD. This proposal aims to dissect the role of novel projection-defined subregions within the BA in the retrieval of fear and extinction memories, which will provide valuable insights into BA spatial and functional organization.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drugs may help the sensory part of chronic pain and the anxiety and depression that follow, but they do not address its core emotional, cognitive and behavioral roots, which require a biobehavioral approach, typically foreign to most primary care practitioners (PCPs). Our prior work showed that PCPs skillfully appropriate and implement this approach with 4PCP, a training program for PCP's to manage chronic pain effectively, resulting in greater work satisfaction and improved patient outcomes. Here we propose to train 27 practices in 4 cities using an intensive, codified and dissemination-ready version of the training and measure whether over the ensuing 2 years: (1) patients have less pain and (2) PCP's are happier with their work, and (3) fewer opioids are prescribed.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Impact of a Novel Community-Based Biobehavioral Chronic Pain Team Training Program (4PCP) on Practitioner and Patient Outcomes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Memory deficits resulting from temporal lobe epilepsy are often left untreated due to the lack of knowledge regarding underlying mechanisms. This proposal aims to provide novel insights into mechanisms of dentate pattern separation by identifying the contribution of semilunar granule cell (SGC) to inhibition and information processing in normal and epileptic dentate circuits. Understanding fundamental mechanisms of dentate information processing and how they are altered in epilepsy will enable development of therapies to treat memory deficits in epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Human brain tumors are genomic heterogeneous within the tumor population and very large datasets of clinical and molecular data on large numbers of patients have been created. Over the past 25 years, my laboratory has worked on modeling brain tumors in mice and correlating those findings with data from human brain tumor patients and have developed unique big data visualization tools that allow the interactive interpretation of these data. We are now using our mouse modeling technology to understand the biology of rare tumors driven by gene fusions and the role of RNA splicing variants of TrkB in development and oncogenesis.
