IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to understand the evolutionary tradeoff between bacterial fitness and phage intracellular competitiveness against other phages when multiple phages infect the same cell. Many clinically relevant bacterial pathogens, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, carry phages in their chromosome which influences the phenotype and fitness of the bacteria. Understanding this tradeoff will not only be relevant for phage therapy but exploitation of this tradeoff to lower bacterial fitness can potentially make bacterial infections easier to treat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While AD pathogenesis is still poorly understood, genetic studies have clearly indicated a causal role for microglia, the innate immune cells of the CNS. This project will investigate the effects of competitive inhibition of CD33, a genetically-associated risk factor for Late- Onset Alzheimer’s disease, by sialic acid binding peptides on downstream microglial function in an in vitro model of human AD. This proposal will provide insights to not only the mechanism of action of these peptides, but to also help to clarify the role of CD33 in microglial activation and immune signaling pathways in the progression of Alzheimer’s disease and further development of CD33 targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many human diseases are driven by errors during cell division. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of this project is to examine neural circuit mechanisms involving the retrosplenial cortex that facilitate spatial cognition and episodic memory. The proposed experiments will directly examine circuit flexibility, functional projection patterns, and input-output transformations between retrosplenial cortex, sensorimotor cortex, and the hippocampal formation. These studies will characterize and test dynamics amongst these regions in support of navigation and mnemonic processing while revealing network interactions that may be impaired in pathological states such as Alzheimer’s disease.

PHR: Young, black men who have sex with men in the US are disparately impacted by HIV, and there is an urgent need for interventions that support these men in HIV treatment, especially those who drink heavily. The proposed project will develop an intervention that leverages social network support and electronic mobile technology to reduce alcohol use and improve HIV treatment outcomes that will then be evaluated against a randomized control condition in a pilot trial among 60 young, black men who have sex with men in an HIV clinic in New York City. The project aims to reduce disparities in HIV treatment outcomes and, in turn, incidence of new HIV infections, a high research priority of the NIH Office of AIDS Research, and an important step towards achieving End the HIV Epidemic milestones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with HIV (PWH) disproportionately experience neurocognitive impairment and psychiatric and medical comorbidities, placing them at greater risk for functional decline in older age. Addressing this public health concern in a rapidly aging population, the proposed study aims to develop a risk index for functional decline in middle-aged and older PWH using adverse and protective factors. Identifying both adverse and protective factors for functional decline in two large, longitudinal datasets of PWH is novel and will contribute to scientific communities and clinical practice by informing prevention and intervention research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is a severely debilitating neurodegenerative disease, marked in early stages by synaptic deficits thought to be caused by the amyloid-β peptide. Down syndrome, a developmental disorder caused by trisomy of chromosome 21, is also marked by synaptic deficits as well as an overabundance of the amyloid precursor protein (APP). This proposal will explore the role of APP in mediation of amyloid-β impairment of CaMKII, an extremely abundant neuronal protein known to play a vital role in mediating synaptic plasticity, and the results of these experiments will provide critical insight into the role APP plays in mediating synaptic impairments in both Alzheimer’s disease and Down syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Multiciliated cells (multiple cilia per cell, MCCs) line the mucociliary epithelium of our airway and are critical to propel mucus out of our body. Defects in morphogenesis of MCCs can lead to an array of respiratory diseases, yet the underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms remain elusive. We have demonstrated that mechanotransduction plays a critical role in MCC morphogenesis and our proposed research will uncover new mechanochemical pathways essential in regulating the differentiation and development of MCCs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: The burden of COVID-19 on survivors and health care systems is greater than we imagined. Most Veterans recover from the illness, but a considerable number have lingering symptoms that affect mental health and sleep. Cognitive problems are commonly reported in post-acute COVID-19, with a substantial impact on social and occupational function. Yet self-reported “brain fog” appears to be an under- investigated outcome. A distinct gap in the literature to date is objective cognitive testing in Veterans who had a positive test for COVID-19. The current project will use a web-based platform to directly assess cognitive function over time and its relationship to mental health in COVID survivors. Determining which factors are most associated with the negative consequences of compromised cognitive function post- COVID is a critical question not yet addressed by current studies. The results will have important implications for Veterans and the VA, especially since new variants of the virus will appear in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Molecular Epidemiology of Cancer Training Program emphasizes a multidisciplinary approach by providing instruction and mentoring to pre- and postdoctoral trainees in both epidemiological methodology and molecular genetic aspects of cancer. Eleven predoctoral trainees have graduated with Ph.D. degrees and eight postdoctoral trainees have finished their training and hold academic or research positions at leading universities and research institutions. In this continuation application, we will continue to focus our training program on molecular epidemiology of cancer with new directions on human microbiota, epigenome, post genome-wide gene-environment interactions, and integration of behavior and molecular epidemiology.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses inappropriate antibiotic use in children which occurs commonly and contributes to the development of antimicrobial resistance as well as individual adverse events and unintended consequences. Development of a rich understanding of antibiotic prescribing variability, a novel metric to track this prescribing variability, and a usability informed, mobile antibiotic electronic clinical decision support tool to impact this variability that is effective, efficient, and easily integrated into clinical settings offers the opportunity to substantially reduce inappropriate antibiotic use, ultimately leading to reductions in adverse events and unintended consequences in children. The proposed research is relevant to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality’s (AHRQ)’s mission for its focus on utilizing data and technology to improve healthcare quality and safety for children and adolescents, an AHRQ priority population.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Standardizing Antibiotic Prescribing for Children Hospitalized with Infections using Novel Metrics and Electronic Clinical Decision Support Tools

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cross-priming of CD8+ T cells by conventional Type 1 dendritic cells (cDC1) is necessary for effective antitumor therapy, yet there is no established method for measuring T cell cross- or direct-priming in vivo. This project seeks to define a signature of cross-primed T cells using RNA-seq of tumor-specific T cells isolated from H2Kd-/- tumor-bearing mice that can only cross-prime T cells, or allogeneic mice that can only directly prime T cells via direct tumoral antigen presentation. This will produce cross- and direct-primed T cell signatures that can be used to guide design of immunotherapies by targeting novel checkpoints or costimulatory receptors, to monitor responses to immunotherapy, and to predict responses to checkpoint blockade and similar therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NIH SEPA Project Narrative The University of New Hampshire, in collaboration with faculty participants from the New Hampshire IDeA Network of Biomedical Research Excellence (NH-INBRE), as well as school district and industry partners, propose an NIH Science Education Partnership Award to establish and advance NH CREATES the Future: the NH Collaborative for Regenerative Medicine Education and Training for Engineers and Scientists of the Future (hereafter, NH CREATES). This combination of stakeholder relationships and their activities, including teacher professional development and youth STEM projects, will establish an innovative ecosystem in New Hampshire that facilitates entry and retention of students in a biomedical education pipeline spanning middle school to higher education. This pipeline provides entry into the workforce critical to NH’s regenerative medicine, biofabrication and biotechnology needs, so that, in turn, this burgeoning industry can fulfill its potential to not only cure significant disease, but in time, evolve into that disruptive innovation that will transform medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: Project Narrative Colleges and universities across South Carolina have come together in the SC INBRE network to advance biomedical research by addressing the need for increased understanding of, and treatment options for, many human diseases while training the next generation of biomedical scientists. SC INBRE creates research training opportunities for undergraduate students at institutions across South Carolina and provides underrepresented minority and underprivileged students biomedical research experience aimed at promoting increased diversity in the biomedical workforce. With the changing demographics in our state and country, engaging a diverse undergraduate student population in biomedical research will ensure a well-educated workforce of physicians, scientists, health-care providers and other professionals prepared to address the current and future health care problems in America.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Loss of language function (aphasia) due to a stroke has an enormous impact on quality of life and mental health. While some individuals with post-stroke aphasia recover a great deal of their language function, many do not, and the factors leading to these differences in outcomes is not fully understood. In this study we will use network theory and dynamic functional connectivity analyses to better understand how (1) reorganization of connections in the brain and (2) differences in moment-to-moment fluctuations of brain connections lead to differences in language recovery outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Tumors are often kept in check by the immune system, however, because tumors are made of our own tissue, this sometimes results in autoimmune reactions against our healthy tissue called paraneoplastic syndromes that are quite common and can affect the brain, with devastating consequences. This project examines the role of KIR and HLA in these complications, in the hope they can be stopped or prevented. This project is also important for cancer patients treated by immunotherapy, as these poorly understood complications often emerge as a result of these treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: In patients receiving deep brain stimulation for treatment of epilepsy the majority see significant improvement, but few actually achieve seizure freedom. These stimulators have many possible settings, but there is no systematic method of setting them and it is unlikely that they are providing the maximum possible benefit. This research will develop a process for selecting settings for deep brain stimulation treatment of epilepsy based on neural signals to improve efficacy of this therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE H3.3-G34R mutation occurs in 15% of pediatric high-grade gliomas (pHGGs), and due to a lack of proper in vivo models that fully recapitulate the genetic and histopathological features of pHGGs, no advanced therapy for this deadly disease has been developed in the last 3 decades. We have generated a genetically engineered mouse model with a conditional knock-in allele of the H3.3-G34R point mutation on the backdrop of ATRX- and Trp53- loss, which develop pHGGs exhibiting human H3.3-G34R mutant glioma features. In this study, we propose to elucidate the mechanisms by which H3.3-G34R mutation and ATRX deletion modulate cell fate switch in gliomagenesis, which would provide insights into developing novel therapeutic strategies for pHGGs and other cancers that frequently harbor H3.3 and ATRX mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Correlative measures of clinical tumor behavior for targeted, immune and cell based therapies in lung cancer are required for optimal treatment plans. A liquid biopsy of the lung using bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) can augment tumor and blood immunogenomic profiling but pre-analytic variables will alter results. We propose experiments herein to standardize collection and processing of BAL for the immunogenomic profiling of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Many diseases are caused by inadequate protein synthesis at the right time and in the right place including major neurological disorders, cancers, cardiovascular disease, and autoimmune diseases. Understanding how this processes works is essential to understanding human disease and developing therapeutics. Therefore, this project aims to develop a molecular picture of the function and mechanisms by which a central regulatory hub, the elongation factor 2 kinase pathway, regulates protein synthesis.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award A Study Section[MRAA]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stress-related neuropeptides are thought to participate in the transition to alcohol dependence, in part through an upregulation in their receptor gene expression. This process may be different for the stress-related neuropeptide, pituitary adenylate cyclase-activating polypeptide (PACAP), which is highly expressed in the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus, is dense in projections to the nucleus accumbens, and is known to act through several different PACAP receptor variants. This proposal aims to investigate the role of PACAP and its receptor variants in the transition to alcohol dependence, with the ultimate goal of informing the development of pharmacotherapies for the treatment of alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Phase separation has recently emerged as a fundamental mechanism for spatial and functional organization that does not require internal membrane-enclosed compartments in eukaryotic cells, but phase separation in bacterial cells remains poorly understood. This project will fully characterize the phase separation of the bacterial chromosome by connecting its mechanical behavior to its molecular properties and by defining the effect of phase separation on the structure, mobility, and accessibility of bacterial chromosomes. Our work will identify the mechanism of chromosomal phase separation and its role in the ability of bacteria to survive stressful environments, providing new targets for rationally designed antibiotics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper gene expression is crucial for cellular differentiation, development, and disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal Alcohol Exposure (PAE) is a common cause of fetal growth restriction, which is a known risk factor for brain disability. The proposed studies meet a significant need for mechanism-centered diagnostics and interventions for this important pregnancy complication due to PAE and other etiologies. The goals of these studies are consistent with the goals outlined in the 2017-2021 strategic plan of the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA), to diagnose and to treat the consequences of alcohol use and misuse, including Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unstructured (free-text) clinical notes in electronic health record (EHR) systems contain valuable phenotypic, genomic, and other data needed to support cancer research ranging from identification of rare cancer cohorts to data abstraction. These notes remain underutilized, in part, because of the complexity of accessing and extracting details from the unstructured data. EMERSE (The Electronic Medical Record Search Engine), an easy-to-use, mature, information retrieval software system that is being used or implemented at research institutions across the nation, simplifies this process. The aims of this proposal are to develop novel, valuable, user-prioritized features to extend the power and reach of EMERSE, including incorporating Natural Language Processing (NLP) capabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Optical imaging allows for biological processes to be visualized in real time, providing key information on mechanisms of disease; however, its utility has been limited due to the low penetration of light through tissue. This proposal uses a special type of light (shortwave infrared) that passes through skin and tissue to allow for optical imaging in mammals. Through the development of new contrast agents, we will illuminate biology in relevant models of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastasis is the leading cause of death in patients with advanced breast cancer and increases in frequency with obesity; however, the underlying mechanisms that cause breast cancer metastasis remain unclear. By iteratively coupling computer simulations, experiments, and advanced omics approaches, the proposed studies will improve understanding of how obesity-dependent changes in breast adipose tissue mechanical properties regulate breast cancer invasion and metastasis and link these changes to targetable cellular mechanisms. The generated new insights have the potential to decrease breast cancer burden associated with the obesity epidemic in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) for Stress, Trauma, and Resilience (STAR) will serve as the only research center in Rhode Island focused on stress, trauma, and resilience. The STAR COBRE will catalyze the development of promising, early career faculty to emerge as leading, independently- funded investigators conducting transformative research in stress, trauma, and resilience. Capacity and infrastructure created by the STAR COBRE will establish The Miriam Hospital as a vibrant regional and national hub for faculty development, transformative research focused on: isolating and disentangling biological and behavioral mechanisms of risk and resilience following exposure to stress, trauma and adversity during sensitive periods of development, with ecologically-valid in vivo measurements leading to novel and actionable intervention targets to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The importance of proper regulation of cell growth and energy homeostasis to human health is underscored by the association of many disease states with altered energy states, including diabetes, cancer, and neurological diseases. Therefore, it is the goal of this work to resolve the controversial role of mTORC1 inhibition caused by AMPK activation in regulating the gene expression, autophagy, and lipid synthesis involved in cellular metabolic reprogramming. Understanding the basic principles of how mTORC1 inhibition supports AMPK’s ability to reprogram metabolism and restore energy homeostasis provides conceptual advances for understanding these key mediators of cellular metabolism and offers mechanistic insight into how dysregulation of these pathways can lead to metabolic dysfunction and disease to allow us to identify new therapeutic strategies for treatment of metabolically-linked human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Diffuse-Large-B-cell-lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma and remains incurable in ~30% of patients. Coding-genome sequencing efforts identified several genes/pathways altered in this disease, including new potential therapeutic targets; however, the non-coding genome of DLBCL remains largely unexplored. This proposal builds on our recent discovery of a highly pervasive, pathogenetically relevant mutational mechanism targeting super-enhancers in DLBCL that is likely to significantly influence the current understanding of the somatic genetic landscape of this disease, by identifying novel mechanisms of dysregulation for known oncogenes, as well as new dysregulated genes and pathways, with implications for precision classification and therapeutic targeting of DLBCL.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spina bifida (SB), a breech in the spine through which nerve roots protrude, causes a spectrum of disabilities associated with permanent and irreversible neurological damage, and arises from a complex interaction of multiple changes or variants in the genes that converge to predispose to the condition. We will use advanced DNA sequencing, computation methods and biological validation of effects on gene function to analyze specific gene and gene combination mutations with the greatest influence on the disorder, and illuminate how these genes interact to cause SB. This will be essential research toward seeking new ways to prevent SB from occurring and to improve the lives of those affected by this birth defect.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Development and validation of a workflow to conduct virtual bioequivalence studies using PBBM-PBPK models. – Specific Aims The proposed project will utilize state-of-the-art physiologically based biopharmaceutics model (PBBM) and physiologically based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) modeling to develop and validate a workflow to conduct virtual bioequivalence studies. This project will support the FDA in its assessment of generic drug products. The first objective of this proposal will be to validate the ability of two PBBM-PBPK modeling platforms, GastroPlus© and PK-SIM©, to predict inter- and intrasubject variability. Then, the second objective of this proposal will be to develop and validate a workflow for designing and performing a reliable virtual bioequivalence study using PBBM-PBPK models, validated for their intended purpose, to detect formulation differences between the reference standard product and a prospective generic drug product that may impact the bioequivalence outcome.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development and validation of a workflow to conduct virtual bioequivalence studies using PBBM-PBPK models

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural variants (SVs) have been difficult to detect with conventional DNA sequencing methods, however, they are associated with complex phenotypes. The proposed research will develop a new generation of computational tools that take advantage of cutting-edge DNA and RNA sequencing technologies to characterize and phase SVs from a large population of samples. This effort is expected to have a major impact in the understanding of complex diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is strong evidence to support a syndemic of depression, anxiety disorder, alcohol use disorder, hypertension, and HIV. In the proposed study, we will use a syndemic approach to adapt Medly Uganda- a mobile health platform developed and tested by our team- to address this syndemic using evidence-based strategies. We will use a human-centered design approach to develop Syndemic-Adapted Medly Uganda (SAMU), will conduct a clinical trial to assess its effectiveness at improving key mental health care cascade outcomes among patients living with HIV and hypertension in Uganda, and use mixed methods to evaluate engagement with SAMU.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Anal cancer is particularly high among certain groups; health disparity further contributes to this high risk among minorities. The proposed research will examine performance of emerging screening methods for aHSIL (precancerous condition of anal cancer) among minorities with a high risk of anal cancer, as well as characterize DNA methylation, immunologic response, and social determinants associated with aHSIL, most likely to progress to cancer. Findings will provide much-needed evidence for anal cancer screening strategies to reduce health disparities, improve screening outcomes, and decrease the incidence of anal cancer among high-risk minorities.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it proposes a novel digital health solution to address the major challenges of crowding, delays in care, and disparities in emergency care in the United States. The proposed solution will use advanced predictive analytics and patient electronic health record data to prioritize patient needs and acuity more optimally at the time of patient arrival to the emergency department. The proposed research is relevant to AHRQ’s mission of producing evidence to make healthcare safer, higher quality, and more equitable.

PROJECT_TITLE: Improving safety and quality of emergency care using machine learning-based clinical decision support at triage

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite ample evidence supporting physician diversification as a mechanism for reducing health disparities, diversity remains elusive at all levels in surgery. The inability to recruit and/or retain a diverse surgeon workforce is a direct result of lack of inclusion in the surgical training environment. The proposed research seeks to understand and leverage organizational culture to improve inclusion in surgical residency programs; with input from experts and key stakeholders, we will develop and contextually adapt interventions that target organizational policies and practices (rather than individual beliefs or skills) to enhance inclusion.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Inclusion in Surgical Residency to Advance Workforce Diversity and Health Equity

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE Retained Foreign Objects (RFOs) are one of the most well recognized and persistent patient safety problems, with an estimated 3000-50,000 RFOs per year, and an 80% morbidity rate. The Retained Foreign Object Reduction and Mitigation (ReFORM) patient safety learning laboratory will explore the causes of and solutions to RFOs using a systems engineering approach, which will initiate the most fundamental reappraisal of the causes of and solutions to RFOs for more than 20 years.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Retained Foreign  Object Reduction and Mitigation (ReFORM)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional precision oncology has the potential to revolutionize treatment options for cancer patients by providing much needed new approaches to identify the correct therapy for individual patients. Most patients with melanoma, a deadly skin cancer, are treated with one of two very different therapeutic options – either of which cure many patients, but neither of which work on all patients, making melanoma an ideal model system in which to develop and demonstrate functional approaches. We propose to engineer a prototype technology that analyzes small biopsies of living tumors to predict which melanoma patients will respond to which therapy, to help address the burden of melanoma and to provide a novel, functional approach that can be extended to other cancers in the future.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Substantial racial and socioeconomic disparities persist in Sudden and Unexpected Infant Deaths (SUID); SUIDs are preventable with greater adherence to safe infant sleep guidelines. Our team's safe sleep video education program, called TodaysBabyTM, delivered through text messages in the first 2 months after birth to 1600 mothers across the US, was effective at eliminating racial and economic disparities in maternal adherence to safe sleep education (1R01HD072815). We therefore propose a cluster randomized trial to test implementation and effectiveness of "high touch" and "low touch" strategies to sign up mothers into the TodaysBabyTM program at 20 US hospitals in counties with high rates of SUID; this study will inform wide-scale dissemination of TodaysBabyTM, and subsequent adherence to safe sleep practices and reduction of SUID in communities with historically high SUID rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The microbiome is related to a vast range of disorders and conditions, yet our limited understanding of how microbes interact with each other, with host genomics, and with disease outcomes poses a serious barrier to translation. Within the context of three of the largest and richest microbiome profiling studies, this proposal seeks to develop statistical and computational approaches to enhance the mapping of these critical relations. The knowledge gained from our methods offers the potential to improve etiology and also drive the development of new therapies, particularly as the microbiome is modifiable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabis is the most commonly used psychoactive substance among those with Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD), yet there is a lack of data examining the direct impact of cannabis use on alcohol-related treatment outcomes. This project will use ecological momentary assessment and transdermal alcohol biosensors to study the momentary impact of cannabis use on alcohol craving and consumption in the natural environment among those early in AUD treatment. Results from this research will have direct impact on cannabis messaging, clinical decision-making, and intervention development for those with AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute and chronic bacterial infections often entail microbial biofilm growth, rendering pathogens difficult or impossible to remove with out surgical resection. My lab studies how cell-cell and cell-surface interaction lead to higher order biofilm architecture, composition, and community dynamics. Here we propose to study how predatory viruses and bacteria propagate among prey bacteria inside biofilms, which can inform how novel alternative antimicrobial strategies could be used against biofilms where traditional antibiotics fail.

ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO START-UP FACTORY II, LLC
PHR: Project Narrative Translating bench science to the patient and the public faces many challenges, particularly in IDeA states. The objective of this proposal is to develop an educational product to promote and develop biomedical entrepreneurship in the Western IDeA states, addressing the specific needs of both IDeA state academic institutions in developing and strengthening technology transfer programs that stimulate technological innovation, as well as the needs of IDeA state university investigators and innovators (from students to faculty) in translating scientific discoveries and technologies from research laboratories into commercial products that improve human health and promote economic growth in IDeA states. The product of this initiative will constitute a comprehensive, sustainable educational, mentoring and consulting product to accelerate biomedical entrepreneurship and create the next generation of entrepreneurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with chronic kidney disease (CKD) pose unique challenges to the health care system, which must address not only the primary kidney disorder, but the many extrarenal manifestations which include social function and emotional wellbeing, risk for cardiovascular disease and metabolic bone disease and a high mortality rate in young adulthood. The CKiD study is a landmark cohort study of children with CKD, having rallied more than 50 pediatric nephrology centers across the US and Canada to recruit and study 1100 children with mild to moderate CKD. From 2023 to 2028, the Clinical Coordinating Centers will continue to coordinate study visits with the following long term goals: enhance the current cohort to collect additional data as the new and existing cohorts become young adults; define how risk factors for GFR decline, and early cardiovascular abnormalities detected during childhood ultimately impact long-term health outcomes after transition to adulthood; examine the impact of risks developed during childhood CKD on outcomes in adulthood by linking CKiD data with external sources; and assess the social functioning and emotional well-being of children with CKD to understand their impact on subsequent clinical care and life course.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder, a physical and psychological reliance on opioids, kills more than 60,000 Americans each year and has cost the United States healthcare system more than $30 billion. Continuous treatment with pharmacotherapy for the duration of physical and psychological reliance is crucial to optimal outcomes of opioid use disorder but faces barriers with co-occurring substance use disorders. Findings from this study will support the development of health information technology that can help overcome these barriers by routinely incorporating patient needs in clinical decision making.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Patient-centered decision making to improve opioid use disorder treatment

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Thermedical is developing the Durablate® Catheter which will deliver Saline Enhanced RF (SERF) ablation to treat Ventricular Tachycardia (VT), a condition that in the United States kills more than half of the 450,000 people who die from Sudden Cardiac Death each year. Currently, VT is treated with Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators (ICDs), expensive devices that halt VT by delivering shocks to the patient. These shocks can be painful, and recent studies indicate that they also contribute to a shortened life expectancy. A recent first in human clinical trial showed that the Durablate can eliminate or substantially reduce the number of shocks that refractory patients are receiving from their ICDs. Thermedical’s ablation technology will improve the quality of life for patients who have VT and possibly extending their life. Long-term the Durablate Catheter may be used for primary prevention of VT which will greatly reduce the cost of VT treatment and improve the lives of patients suffering from VT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to establish the Washington University Omics Production Center (WU-omics PC) as part of the Multi-Omics for Health and Disease Consortium. The WU-omics PC will profile human genes, proteins, and metabolites by using six different omics profiling technologies. The integration of these omics datasets and others will improve our understanding of human health and potentially lead to new strategies for the early detection, prevention, and treatment of disease in ancestrally diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative While non-proliferating disseminated cancer cells in distant tissues have been observed in many types of cancer, mechanisms of how metastases originate from these dormant cancer cells are unclear. In this proposal we plan to (1) interrogate how dormant cancer cells initiate proliferation and how immune cells regulate these dissemi- nated cancer cells in development to metastases upon stimuli, such as glucocorticoids treatment, and (2) deter- mine immune-stromal cell interactions, and how they orchestrate to regulate cancer dormancy as we age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma is the most common chronic disease of childhood, however disease burden is disproportionately higher in communities of color and of low socioeconomic status. Socio-environmental exposures, including psychosocial stressors and air pollution, are concentrated in these historically marginalized communities and contribute to asthma pathobiology through poorly understood mechanisms. Our goal is to improve our understanding of heterogeneous asthma pathobiology associated with socio-environmental exposures, relevant to marginalized populations, allowing us to better discriminate individuals at high risk for poor outcomes and identify place-based targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The prevalence of behavioral health (BH) disorders has climbed steadily among children in the U.S. over the past decade, disproportionately affecting children in lower income and minoritized populations. Access to appropriate diagnostic and treatment services for vulnerable populations is particularly challenging, but Medicaid accountable care organizations (ACOs) have the potential to address gaps in BH care for children in these populations. This study takes advantage of a natural ACO experiment taking place in Massachusetts to addresses gaps in knowledge about the effects of the accountable care ‘experiment’ on pediatric BH quality of care, utilization, outcomes, and disparities.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black patients receive care at lower quality hospitals and are at increased risk of patient safety events compared to White patients. Our goal is to understand the currently unknown patterns of hospital patient safety culture and its association with financial resources, other hospital characteristics, and patient safety events for hospitals that predominantly serve Black patients and compare those to hospitals that do not predominantly care for Black patients. Our work will identify any disparities in patient safety culture and explore differences in barriers to health equity, with specific attention to identifying pragmatic strategies and best patient safety practices that aim to improve patient care and reduce health inequities in hospitals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Culture of Patient Safety in Black Serving and Non-Black Serving Hospitals
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE BRCA2 is an essential player in the DNA damage response pathway preventing genome instability and cancer through proper homologous directed repair (HDR) and protection of DNA replication forks. I recently identified a novel group of BRCA2 misssense mutations which affect nuclear localization and increase sensitivity to PARP inhibitors (PARPi) and platinum drugs, but the mechanism by which this occurs is still not fully understood. The goal of my K22 proposal is to dissect the mechanisms of BRCA2 mislocalization, the altered functions of cytosolic BRCA2, and detect BRCA2 expression in human tissues as a cancer diagnostic tool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States and 90% of deaths occur at metastatic stages. Metastasis requires the cancer cell to accomplish many distinct tasks as it moves through the body to form new tumors in distant organs. Our proposal seeks to identify systematically how a cancer cell's molecular toolkit changes during metastasis with the goal of identifying new therapeutic targets to prevent metastasis and for treating patients with metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many low-income and minoritized children with chronic conditions live in poverty and therefore have both care coordination needs and unmet social needs, such as food insecurity and housing instability, which can lead to decreased access to care and poor health outcomes. To promote health equity and increase access to health care for low-income and minoritized children with chronic conditions, there is an urgent need for effective family-centered interventions addressing both care coordination needs and unmet social needs. The goal of this application is to develop and test the first-ever pediatric adaptation of the evidence-based Individualized Management for Patient-Centered Targets (IMPaCT) community health worker intervention, tailored to the unique needs of hospitalized children with complex chronic conditions and their caregivers.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Family-Centered Community Health Worker Support for Children with Chronic Conditions and Unmet Social Needs

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative To facilitate validation of in-silico models of deposition of orally inhaled drug products, we will develop and implement protocols to conduct a deposition study using either PET or SPECT nuclear imaging. By leveraging advances in scanner technology and quantitative CT techniques, we will develop methods to produce more accurate estimates of branch-level deposition from these images than was previously possible. This data will be formatted and shared with FDA to disseminate for use by other groups to validate their in-silico models.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A prospective study to support validation of lung deposition models with nuclear medicine imaging methods

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public health relevance This project proposes to study the function of ubiquitin modifications in hematopoiesis. Specifically, it proposes to extend our knowledge on ubiquitination mediated by DCAF7, a protein dysregulated in blood disorders. This proposal will provide enhanced understanding of regulators of hematopoietic stem and progenitor function.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: This study will advance scientific knowledge in equity-focused implementation and create solutions to improve the uptake of evidence-based intervention in underserved communities through a community-engagement process. The proposed study will inform the development of equity-focused implementation strategies and examine the effectiveness of a full-scale sleep intervention that will help Black women mitigate the effects of psychological stress on their stress- related disease risk. Given the detrimental effects of psychological stress on sleep and the associated sleep health disparities among Black women, this study will contribute to significant efforts to improve public health.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing mindfulness practice to advance sleep health equity among Black women

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children in families with healthcare communication in a language other than English (LOE) are at increased risk of worse asthma care and outcomes compared to those without a language barrier. The proposed research addresses the gap in knowledge about effective interventions to address asthma disparities for children in LOE families through a hybrid type 2 effectiveness-implementation trial of the Navigating Toward Equitable Asthma Management Program (Nav-TEAM) intervention which is an adaptation of evidence-based asthma navigation specifically for children in families who communicate in LOE. Our mixed methods implementation evaluation using PRISM (Practical, Robust Implementation and Sustainability Model), the contextual expansion of the RE-AIM framework with an equity lens and assessment of cost, sustainability and contextual domains will promote sustainability and scale-out of Nav-TEAM.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Navigating Together for Equitable Asthma Management (Nav-TEAM) for Children in Families who Communicate in Languages other than English

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research will identify important interrelations among problematic social media use patterns and binge-eating disorder, using novel measures and prospective data of a large, diverse, national cohort during an important developmental period spanning early to late adolescence. The findings from this research will: (1) provide precision guidance for social media use for adolescents, parents, and clinicians to prevent binge-eating disorder; (2) inform adolescent social media use guidelines for professional societies; and (3) be disseminated through infographics, press releases, and social media based on input from youth.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders (SUDs), which can involve illicit drugs, prescription drugs, or alcohol, are common and result in substantial morbidity and mortality worldwide and in the US, and Ohio is among the states with the highest rates of SUDs. Despite the burden of illness and recommendations to screen and provide evidence-based interventions for SUDs, relatively few people who visit primary care providers are asked about substances or ever discuss it with a health professional. The STop UNhealthy (STUN) Substance Use Now Trial (STUN II) is a multisite trial aiming to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of the following strategies for improving the implementation of screening and interventions for SUDs in primary care: practice facilitation (PF), PF plus a learning collaborative (LC), PF plus performance incentives (PI), and PF+LC+PI.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The STop UNhealthy Substance Use Now Trial (STUN II)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to environmental toxicants during early life development may negatively impact sleep health during adolescence. This project will examine whether mixtures of phthalates, per-/polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), and metals during gestation, infancy, childhood, and adolescent development are related to poorer sleep and higher allostatic load, cumulative ‘wear and tear’ from physiological disruptions. Understanding whether environmental toxicants that are commonly found in consumer products and residential environments impact sleep characteristics may lay the foundation for novel interventions to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. Irinotecan is an effective chemotherapeutic agent that is widely used for the treatment of cancers that are not sensitive to other drugs. Its clinical use is severely limited by the severe diarrhea that results in poor quality of life, hospitalization and even death. The purpose of this research is to develop and test a classical Chinese Medicine formula called Xiao-Chai-Hu-Tang (with hundreds of years of recorded human use) to reduce severe diarrhea so patients will have less side effects and perhaps even better therapeutic efficacy. Both animal studies and human clinical trials are proposed to determine the mechanism(s) by which XCHT act an effective agent to alleviate irinotecan-related severe diarrhea.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Physicians prescribe and patients use antibiotics too often, but most research has focused on antibiotic prescribing that happens at visits and is focused on physician behavior. We propose a project to better understand high-inappropriate-antibiotic-utilizing patients and develop, refine, and test an intervention to address high-inappropriate-antibiotic-utilization. By addressing inappropriate antibiotic use, our goals are to improve patient care, diagnostic accuracy, and decrease inappropriate antibiotic prescribing, which would increase patient safety and limit the spread of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Patient-Centered Stewardship to Improve Antibiotic Use in Ambulatory Care
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: DEVELOPMENT AND VALIDATION OF A MULTI-FUNCTIONAL, MULTI-PURPOSE QUANTITATIVE TOOL FOR DERMAL PHYSIOLOGICALLY-BASED PHARMACOKINETIC (PBPK) MODELING Project Narrative This project will identify a set of enhanced critical quality attributes to (a) describe topical products in their starting “as in the tube” condition, the residual film that forms after application to the skin and the kinetics of metamorphosis, (b) integrate metamorphosis events with effects of excipients and solvents on skin permeation, and (c) establish the manner in which these enhanced CQAs must be input into a PBPK model. The outcome will be an enhanced, validated and mechanistic dermal PBPK model that can predict the performance of topical products and support bio(in)equivalence decisions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Validation of a Multi-functional, Multi-purpose Quantitative Tool for Dermal Physiologically-Based Pharmacokinetic Modeling

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Ambulatory diagnostic error is a vexing problem because events unfold across time with shifting team members, and accurate and timely diagnosis relies on keeping patients and health care professionals (HCPs) on the same page, both in and between clinic visits. Yet little is known about how patients and HCPs develop and sustain a shared mental model of the diagnostic process. We will identify the specific teaming behaviors that help patients and HCPs to coproduce safety at known diagnostic process risk points, and then develop and disseminate tools to support patients, care partners, interpreters and clinicians as active contributors to the diagnostic process.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Safety II Together: Coupling teaming science with patient engagement and health information transparency to coproduce diagnostic excellence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired recovery from skeletal muscle disuse in aging results in heightened risk of disability and falls contributing to decreased healthspan. During the F99/K00 phases, I will study the mechanisms of novel therapeutic compounds and cellular interactions to promote muscle recovery in aged mice. This proposal will be guided by a panel of muscle aging experts and training experiences across various disciplines and institutions to promote my training in muscle aging research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brains from Alzheimer’s patients often display loss of 5-HT neurons, but the causal relationship of this 5-HT dysregulation and Alzheimer’s symptoms is unclear. In the proposed research, we will determine whether the dysregulated 5-HT→hippocampus circuit contributes to the cognitive and neuropsychiatric symptoms in AD and further test whether a 5-HT receptor (5-HT2CR) is a suitable target for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) causes chronic neuroinflammation with progressive neurodegeneration leading to long-term neurocognitive dysfunctions including dementia and emerging evidence suggests that bi-directional brain-systemic interactions contribute to these neuropathological changes. Notably, TBI causes gastrointestinal (GI) tract pathology and GI diseases are associated with neurological dysfunctions. We propose that, TBI and colitis synergize to promote the development of chronic neurodegenerative processes, causing delayed central inflammation, hippocampal neuronal loss and neurobehavioral dysfunctions, the proposed studies will probe the novel concept that therapeutic strategies that target GI tract mechanisms may limit brain disease processes including neurodegeneration and thus attenuate chronic cognitive decline after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Native Ion Mobility-Mass Spectrometry (IM-MS) can reveal a wealth of information about the structure of biomolecules and their complexes, especially when combined with activation methods used to disrupt physiological structures and expose their more detailed architecture. Short-term goals of the proposed research include developing theory and experimental methods to boost the power of these methods by relating activation energies and entropies to structural information. The long-term goal of the proposed research is to provide academic, pharmaceutical, and clinical researchers with robust experimental and computational tools needed to quantitatively analyze structure and behavior of biomolecules relevant to human health while harnessing the specificity, sensitivity, speed, and tolerance to heterogeneity of native IM-MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The use of α-emitting radionuclides is rapidly growing as a promising approach to treat several types of cancer and metastases. In these radiation-based treatments, maximizing efficacy while minimizing non-desired toxicities is only achievable through an accurate knowledge and prediction of the α radiation interaction with the organism. This project will contribute decisively to a rigorous and complete determination of the radiation dosimetry and biological effects of α-particles in the context of radiopharmaceutical treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative White matter deep brain stimulation is a rapidly developing therapy for individuals with treatment resistant neurological and psychiatric disorders. Despite this, little is known about the specific anatomical and functional mechanisms that are engaged when stimulation is applied in this way. Here we will address these issues using a combination of resting-state fMRI, diffusion tractography, multi-site neurophysiology, and postmortem anatomical analysis in macaques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PI Name: Mardelle Atkins Commons ID: MRATKINS Project: Assessing if tumor induced muscle cachexia is initiated by defects in Myosin Heavy Chain production and localization in a Drosophila tumor model Narrative Cancer induced wasting, or cachexia, negatively impacts patient treatment, quality of life and survival. However, we do not understand how or when this complex process begins, and can only diagnose it at later stages. Using a basic research model this research will characterize the earliest changes in muscles leading to cachexia and investigate how they result in eventual muscle loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Multi-Omics for Maternal Health after PE (MOM-Health) Disease Study Site aims to use multi-omic analyses of biosamples matched with comprehensive clinical and demographic information and measures of environmental exposures before and after delivery to uncover mechanisms leading from preeclampsia and other hypertensive diseases of pregnancy to cardiovascular disease following delivery in a diverse population. Knowledge resulting from this project can be used to develop strategies to predict patients at risk for later cardiovascular disease and to develop preventative therapies, improving postpartum maternal health in those most at risk for long-term morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative People insured by Medicaid with co-occurring serious mental illness (SMI) experience significant disparities following non-psychiatric hospitalizations. Our previously developed post discharge support pathway has successfully reduced post hospitalization disparities, though its benefits for patients diagnosed with SMI are unknow. This study seeks to adapt, implement, and evaluate the THRIVE post discharge support clinical pathway to determine if the invention benefits people insured with Medicaid with and without SMI equally and to evaluate the organizational features that support its successful implementation.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: An equity-focused intervention to improve care transitions for Medicaid insured individuals with co-occurring serious mental health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs) used with MRI provide critical insights for disease diagnosis and staging, with over 12 million of administrations annually in the US. This proposal aims to address safety concerns surrounding the use of GBCAs and the long-term retention of gadolinium in tissues. Our goal is to develop a quantitative, non-invasive and sensitive PET/MRI technique to help understand the fate of GBCAs in vivo and to monitor biochemical processes using responsive contrast agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Lack of progress in curing metastatic breast cancer is due to a number of fundamental treatment barriers. These include insufficient knowledge of therapeutic vulnerabilities, lack of reliable predictive biomarkers, inability to target common tumor suppressor gene loss, inability to target oncogenes that are not protein kinases or ligand- dependent transcription factors, resistance due to clonal evolution and tumor heterogeneity, and failure to mount an immune response against the tumor. Here we articulate cross-cutting objectives and aligned approaches that increase the efficiency of core utilization and promote inter-project collaboration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer is the largest contributor to death from breast cancer, which now  exceeds a half million annually worldwide. The major cause of death is resistance to treatment. Therefore,  this project aims to study a powerful resistance driver, neurofibromin (encoded by the NF1, neurofibromatosis  type 1, gene), to define its role in resistance and to seek a vulnerability that can be targeted to greatly improve  treatment efficacy and enhance patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal aims to develop new strategies to combat a common and aggressive subtype of human breast  cancer (triple-negative breast cancer, or TNBC). We recently discovered a new mechanism that contributes to  the coordinate hyperactivation of RTKs in TNBC and invokes a new therapeutic entry point through which to  target these cancers. We propose to translate these preclinical findings into a new therapeutic approach by  evaluating the efficacy of the well-tolerated RTK inhibitor sitravatinib as monotherapy in metastatic TNBC  patients, assessing sitravatinib in combination with standard of care taxane chemotherapy, and capitalizing on  the pro-immune effects of sitravatinib in combination with immune checkpoint therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE After the introduction of successful HER2 directed therapeutics, most fatal cases of breast cancer are associated with chemotherapy-insensitive triple-negative or luminal B breast cancer. Our research will  establish endoplasmic reticulum stress sensor IRE1-targeted therapy as a novel therapeutic approach to  enhance chemotherapy sensitivity and reverse the immunosuppressive microenvironment in the presence of  chemotherapy that sensitizes MYC-driven breast cancers to immune checkpoint intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The central goal of our translational research is to get the most up to date laboratory research and the most current clinical experience to talk productively to each other, for the most rapid and efficient progress toward controlling and eliminating breast cancer. Thus we have designed this career enhancement program to expose young researchers to the full range of the breast cancer research experience in a vigorously translational environment, whatever their initial training was, as they move towards research independence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Collective cell migration is a process by which cells move in concert with each other that occurs across all stages of human development, as well as in tissue repair and various pathologies. The proposed work seeks to understand the mechanisms that drive collective cell movement. New tools will be developed to activate, monitor, and analyze a critical molecule involved in collective migration, thereby enabling the identification of pathways and cellular behaviors that can be manipulated to control this process in pathological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Emerging adulthood (EA) is a developmental phase characterized by increased risk-taking behaviors including heavy episodic drinking (HED). Romantic relationship conflict may be a particularly salient social influence in EA drinking behavior and a promising target for prevention and intervention, but these associations have not yet been explored. The proposed award will support the candidate’s transition to independence in patient-oriented alcohol research and address this critical gap in the literature by examining the associations between controlled alcohol administration, conflict communication behaviors, and the psychophysiological responses that may underpin this bidirectional relationship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Replication of the DNA within our genome requires a highly orchestrated series of molecular events to propagate genetic information during cell proliferation with high fidelity, and thus to suppress the onset of diseases such as cancer. This project will combine a unique genetic strategy in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster with sophisticated imaging and molecular biology approaches to determine how the synthesis of histones proteins and their packaging of DNA into chromatin regulates the process and fidelity of DNA replication. Because of the high evolutionary conservation of regulators of chromatin and DNA replication, discoveries resulting from our mechanistic studies in flies will be directly applicable to humans.

PHR: Project Narrative The ODSP will develop a flexible, scalable open data science platform for the DSI-Africa consortium to find and access data, select tools and workflows and run analyses on a choice of computing environments, all through easy to use workspaces. Administration and support of the core resources and consortium activities will be coordinated by the CC. Together, the ODSP and CC will provide an infrastructure for researchers to use data science technologies to deliver cutting edge biomedical research for health, while promoting cohesion, collaborative cross-consortium activities and engagement with external stakeholders to facilitate innovation and translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research harnesses data science applications to establish the spatial variability in the impact of ambient PM2.5 exposure on children’s health in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) and further identify the explanatory and moderating factors. The proposed research is relevant as it focuses on leveraging data science tools to address a very pressing public health problem in Africa in line with the overarching goals of the DSI-Africa program. The proposed research will enhance public health data science capacity on the continent and with the findings triggering investment in air pollution control as well as policy action for addressing area and household poverty to help improve child health and survival in SSA.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the widespread adoption of clinical exome sequencing has helped identify the genetic basis of many previously unsolved Mendelian disorders, approximately 50% of individuals remain unsolved after a complete clinical workup. Long-read sequencing has the potential to identify and resolve many complex or difficult-to- identify variants such as insertions, deletions, repeat expansions, and variants within duplicated genes, but it has yet to be systematically evaluated in a clinical cohort. Here I propose a set of experiments which seek to evaluate the incremental diagnostic rate of long-read sequencing in cohorts that have had extensive but nondiagnostic clinical genetic testing and to compare long-read sequencing as a single test to a standard outpatient clinical workup.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The known dental caries pathogen Streptococcus mutans is able to survive an acidic environment and cause disease by increasing the proportion of unsaturated fatty acids in its cell membrane. The proposed research will determine the extent of this acid stress response among oral bacteria, and the mechanism by which unsaturated fatty acids protect against environmental acid stress. Results generated from this study will improve understanding of the pathogenesis of dental caries, the world’s most common chronic infectious disease, and will likely open the door to investigation of novel anti-caries therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Zambian AGYW remain at high risk for HIV as incidence rates rose from 2010 – 2020 while decreasing in all other groups. AGYW, 15-19 year-olds are 4 times more likely to acquire HIV than their male peers, but HIV testing rates are low (45.4%), and 71.2% do not know their HIV status. PreP uptake and sustained adherence is poor. This theoretically-grounded, hypothesis-driven hybrid-trial will address critical gaps in the HIV prevention continuum for Zambian AGYW, with a long-term goal to sustain effective programs that reduce HIV/STI infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: The University of Illinois at Chicago Center for Clinical and Translational Science (UIC CCTS) proposes to continue to be a robust and highly contributory hub in the national CTSA program that both advances and applies clinical translational research in a timely manner and expands and diversifies the clinical translational workforce. The overarching goal - and driving focus - of UIC CCTS is to improve population health, particularly among minorities and underserved populations across the lifespan. Today's health problems are complex, and addressing them requires the integrated collaborative efforts of scientists and practitioners along the translational spectrum, along with processes to overcome translational barriers. We propose a suite of programs and processes that will help accelerate the translation of scientific discoveries into practice and to overcome the challenges of addressing the complex health problems of today.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Proteins perform critical cell functions, but they also fuel growth and proliferation, which, can lead to cancer if not carefully controlled. The goal of this research is to understand how the functions of the molecule named LARP1 change in response to its environment and how these changes influence the cell’s fundamental ability to make proteins. Our work will reveal the mechanisms of LARP1 that can be targeted for the future design of chemotherapeutics to treat these diseases.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children from low-income Latino backgrounds are at elevated risk for poor school readiness, which perpetuates existing health inequities. Primary care is an ideal setting to promote optimal school readiness given its frequent contact with at-risk children. The current proposal will yield important information on the effects of an innovative family wellness program in primary care and in turn will provide insight on how primary care can promote whole person 360-degree care for at-risk children and their families.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Ready and Healthy for Kindergarten: A Primary Care Innovation to Promote a 360-degree View of Child Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The results of this research will provide quantitative characterization of anatomical form and its relationship with function in patients that undergo ankle fusion surgery to treat ankle osteoarthritis. These data should help surgeons to better address deformities at the time of ankle fusion surgery, which could in turn improve clinical outcomes and reduce the likelihood that patients will develop secondary subtalar arthritis later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain is a highly prevalent and undertreated symptom in patients with cirrhosis, a population which may also be particularly vulnerable to adverse outcomes related to pain medications. Currently, there is limited understanding of how pain is managed or the actual, real-world harms associated with use of pain medications in this population. This proposal aims to quantify the harms of specific types of pain medications in cirrhosis patients, using these data to develop evidence-based guidance to help clinicians feel more comfortable managing pain, improving quality of life and outcomes for patients with cirrhosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The inheritance of a particular gene expression profile is key to conveying proper cellular identity to progeny cells upon cell division. The proposed studies will directly expose key mechanistic aspects and biologically relevant factors inherent to this epigenetic regulation, as well as the sequence of events that accompany leukemogenesis as a consequence of naturally occurring mutations that target this inheritance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Based on the hypothesis that the peripheral inflammation to neuroinflammation pathway largely drives the relationship between periodontal disease and Alzheimer’s disease, our long-term goal is to investigate the full spectrum of oral organisms that drive this association, and with an understanding of related social determinants that affect oral health, evaluate their potential as a target in the development of oral health interventions for the mitigation of Alzheimer’s disease onset and progression. The main objective of this study is to characterize the taxonomy and function of oral bacteria, viruses and fungi among cognitively normal individuals at risk for Alzheimer’s disease, and over a two-year period, investigate relationships among periodontal disease associated microbiome features, inflammation, social determinants of oral health, and Alzheimer’s disease central cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of patients with Tourette Syndrome and other chronic tic disorders do not experience adequate benefit from the first-line tic treatment, Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT). This study will measure brain, behavioral, and psychosocial functioning in patients receiving CBIT to identify predictors of response (for whom does CBIT work?), the therapeutic processes that activate change (what are the potent aspects of CBIT delivery?), and correlates of response (what changes occur in patients whose tics improve?). Results will help guide treatment decision-making for patients and providers and reveal novel targets for treatment development research in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While permanent supportive housing is typically situated in high-risk environments, it is also surrounded by public spaces that can be resourceful and supportive for formerly incarcerated people with serious mental illnesses. The risk environment framework provides a structure for understanding the geography of permanent supportive housing during reentry, including the individual, interpersonal, and environmental factors interacting with these spaces to reduce risk and promote reentry wellbeing. This project involves career development and training activities that will enhance the applicant’s expertise in spatial methods supportive housing and the risk environment framework, community-based intervention development, and community-based participatory research methods to help support the use and interaction of public and private spaces in supporting reentry from prison for people with serious mental illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial minorities in the United States have a disproportionately higher burden of heart failure and often receive worse quality of care, however, studies of American Indian/Alaska Native patients are limited. This study aims to characterize the disease burden, quality of care, and outcomes of American Indians/Alaska Natives with heart failure receiving care through the Indian Health Service, as well as develop strategies to ensure quality heart failure care for this population. The findings of this study will allow better understanding of the current state of cardiovascular health of the American Indian/Alaska Native population and ways in which it can improved, and will also inform a future pragmatic clinical trial seeking to improve cardiovascular outcomes for this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current rehabilitation programs for people with ultra-low vision (ULV) (VA<20/1600) mainly involve sensory substitution training with audio and haptic devices with no recommendations for maximizing the use of their residual vision. It is not known whether and how residual vision plays a role in functional vision performance when integrated with other senses in people with ULV. The proposed research will address this critical gap in knowledge and develop a multisensory rehabilitation program using, among others, assessment and training in virtual reality to improve functional vision and independence in people with ULV, in keeping with NIH’s mission to improve quality of life through innovative use of technology and devices in rehabilitation research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use disorder (SUD) is a major public health challenge in the United States that has been further exacerbated in recent years by the Covid-19 pandemic and social isolation, leading to a higher demand for treatment with limited provider capacity to meet the need. In this Phase II SBIR project, we will evaluate the effectiveness and implementation of Suzy, an innovative mobile- and web-based chatbot designed to provide engaging, scalable, on-demand follow-up support for primary care patients on the path to SUD recovery. Suzy will be developed with features that are evidence-based and will follow a community-based continuing care model with an interface designed with and for individuals who struggle with SUDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal cord stimulation (SCS) is a validated treatment for pain, including with painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy (PDPN), the most common form of small fiber neuropathy that impacts more than half of patients with diabetes. The mechanisms by which SCS improves pain are not known, but may include the promotion of small fiber nerve plasticity and regeneration, which we will test in this study in PDPN patients across 3 groups: conventional medical management, SCS, and SCS with a delayed start of stimulation. We will compare traditional measures of neuropathy (small and large fiber), including a new measurement of small fiber nerve electrical activity with the Detecting Early Neuropathy (DEN) device, with improvements in pain scores across an 18mo longitudinal study with the hypothesis that pain improvement correlates with better tissue innervation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to establish a diabetes and kidney disease study site (DSS) comprised of 300 racially and ethnically diverse participants, including 200 with diabetes (half with kidney disease) and 100 healthy controls. Our DSS will be part of a collaborative initiative with an overall mission to advance the application of integrative multi-omics technologies to study health and disease in ancestrally diverse populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Washington University Postbaccalaureate Program (WUP) is a one-year, multi-pronged program designed to increase the number of underrepresented individuals matriculating and graduating from research-intensive biomedical doctoral programs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal activation of the complement pathway, which regulates innate immunity and inflammation, is associated with blinding diseases such as inherited and age-related macular degenerations. This research will investigate how a novel pathway of intracellular complement activation endangers the health of the retinal pigment epithelium, a key site of insult in macular degenerations. We will study the impact of intracellular complement on the function and integrity of the retinal pigment epithelium, and identify potential points of therapeutic intervention that can be targeted to preserve vision.
