IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to public health since it would: 1. Add scale to the study of genetic variants related to CKD, more particularly by having power to identify  rare variants associated with this condition which has not been addressed by prior studies. By conducting  gene-burden analysis in a diverse sample comprising 850,000 participants with whole-genome or whole-  exome sequencing information, we will improve our ability to identify people carrying increased genetic  risk related to CKD, opening opportunities for primary and secondary prevention. 2. This will be the largest study addressing the penetrance of CKD-related variants in an unbiased way.  Absolute and unbiased association estimates between CKD-related variants and CKD and other renal  phenotypes will be computed and stratified by age, sex, and comorbidities. These findings will be useful  the interpretation of genetic variants in scenarios where the clinical trait is absent or just partially present.  In conjunction with the finding of rare variants, the results of this proposal are expected to support  investigations in translational research, more specifically in terms of mechanisms of disease,  development of biomarkers, and identification of possible targets for intervention and new therapies. 3. By fostering the career development of a researcher representative of a minority group, the diversity  supplement would empower the candidate to become a strong representative of her minority group within  her Institution and the nephrology community, fostering new similar initiatives, inspiring students and  colleagues from similar backgrounds, and creating opportunities for mentoring within the diversity scope.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical translational science could better address health equity if researchers and communities had access to community level data to identify inequities, recognize the people and communities impacted, detect potential underlying causes of and solutions to address disparities, and longitudinally track changes over time. Building on its expertise calculating census tract level community measures, engaging communities to understand needs and priorities, and unique bright spot and community asset mapping approach, the Wright Regional CCTS will develop the Virginia Accountable Health Equity and Action Dashboard (Va-AHEAD) to identify bright and cold spot communities that do better or worse than predicted for 15 equity topics and the modifiable socioecological factors that contribute to outcomes. Once created, we will engage local translational science researchers, learners, care team members, and policymakers to use Va-AHEAD and its community designed products to inform their work, and we will track the use and impact of content on health equity, including the dissemination of the approaches and assets used by bright spot communities for success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurological injuries and diseases negatively affect quality of life for millions of people in the US, such as the various visual and oculomotor pathologies (e.g. optic ataxia and oculomotor apraxia) caused by damage to the posterior parietal cortex (PPC). Despite extensive research, much remains unknown about how PPC encodes motor decisions, in part due to technical limitations of existing neural recording technologies. This project aims to increases our understanding of the neuronal circuits involved in these visual-motor pathologies by using a novel neuroimaging technique (functional ultrasound neuroimaging) and conventional electrophysiology to investigate how and where motor and decision variables are represented from the single neuron level to detailed maps of neural populations across the entire PPC.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES H QUILLEN VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: People with tinnitus, or ringing in the ears, frequently report that it impacts their ability to concentrate and can make them feel depressed or anxious. Recently, about 1.5 million adults in the US said that their tinnitus was a “big or very big problem.” Veterans report higher rates of tinnitus than the public, so we expect there to be proportionately more Veterans bothered by their tinnitus. There are no practical ways to measure tinnitus because we cannot pinpoint its location, making it hard to treat. We think that when tinnitus becomes difficult to ignore, people must work harder to listen. We also think that when tinnitus makes people feel depressed or anxious, their bodies respond negatively to certain sounds and pictures. If we are correct, we plan to use these tools to improve how we identify and treat Veterans with bothersome tinnitus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial discrimination is one of the most common stressors reported by Black individuals and is related to a host of negative outcomes including increased substance use among Black youth. The current project will use a mixed method longitudinal design to examine individual, interpersonal, and contextual factors influencing emotional health and substance use outcomes over time among Black youth who experienced racial discrimination. Findings will help identify novel leverage points for strengths-based interventions that jointly address experiences of discrimination and substance use to improve emotional health among Black youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE The Boston University Core Center for Clinical Research will provide broad clinical research expertise with state- of-the-art methods and resources to a large multidisciplinary research community whose research focuses on rheumatic and musculoskeletal diseases including osteoarthritis, crystal-related arthritis, spondyloarthritis, musculoskeletal pain, among others. Our group, which includes persons with backgrounds in rheumatology, physical therapy, epidemiology, biostatistics, behavioral science, engineering, computer science, and pain meets weekly to critically review research projects and serves a broad research community with which it actively engages. The CCCR has been successful in publishing influential papers on the diseases of focus and in training many of the clinical research faculty in the US and internationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Aside from COVID-19, TB is the leading cause of death globally from a single infectious disease. At present, the only approved tuberculosis (TB) vaccine—BCG, which was introduced in 1921—has variable efficacy in adolescents and adults. As vaccination remains the most cost-effective method of controlling the disease, an improved vaccine for TB infection and disease prevention would have very large public health impact. This project will support the development of a novel TB vaccine in the form of a novel recombinant BCG strain that compared to traditional BCG has greater protective efficacy that lasts into adulthood, and an improved safety profile.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative: Modern electron-microscopy imaging and analysis methods permit the comprehensive reconstruction of all neu- rons and synapses in large volumes of brain tissue or the entire brains of individual organisms. This data is now being paired with functional and behavioral measurements, but how to integrate these new data modalities is not clear. Litwin-Kumar’s group is developing analysis methods to translate the rich anatomical information identified in electron microscopy data into insights about how neural circuits give rise to behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The UAB Building and InnovatinG: Digital heAlth Technology and Analytics (BIGDATA) Core Center for Clinical Research (CCCR) encompasses three distinct and synergistic cores (Administrative, Methodologic and Health Informatics [MHI], and the Dissemination, Implementation and Community Engagement [DICE] Resource Core) aligned around the theme of big data and real-world evidence that spans the continuum of research. BIGDATA harnesses informatics, digital health tools, and advanced analytics in pursuit of its theme and sub- theme of health equity and community engagement. The goal of the BIGDATA CCCR is to bring the innovative research and technology tools necessary to transform healthcare in the 21st century and to improve outcomes for patients with rheumatologic and musculoskeletal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The underlying mechanisms and neurological function of reactive astrocyte proliferation after traumatic brain injury are unclear. Our preliminary data suggests that transiently increased expression of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha (PDGFR) is required for the reactive astrocyte proliferation post-trauma and the inhibition of this process worsens synapse loss. We will therefore study the PDGFR signaling pathway that underlies the reactive astrocyte proliferation following TBI and explore proliferative reactive astrocytes’ neuroprotective function on counteracting synapse loss and enhance synaptogenesis in order to find novel therapeutic targets for TBI treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pain and loss of function that results from rheumatic and musculoskeletal diseases (RMDs), combined with their high prevalence, contributes to substantial disability in the population. Among RMDs, osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common form of arthritis and a leading cause of pain and disability among older adults worldwide. Our Center, focused on optimizing clinical studies in OA and other RMDs through advanced methodologic approaches including phenotyping and precision medicine and broad subject area expertise, will have a sustained impact on the field by enhancing and enriching high quality, innovative studies to improve the understanding of disease mechanisms and targeted interventions for prevention and treatment of OA and other RMDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed studies will demonstrate a role for neutrophil derived EVs expressing proteolytic activity, that is resistant to endogenous protective mechanisms, in mediating toxicity after halogen gas exposure. Demonstrating this pathway may lead to the future development of a common therapeutic countermeasure targeting proteases specifically associated with EVs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use disorders during pregnancy and the postpartum period pose a significant threat to public health and have long-term, transgenerational effects on maternal and child health. Interventions, grounded in evidence-based clinical and translational sciences, which can be feasibly integrated into patient care practices should be developed to counter this growing health issue. This research proposes to evaluate the current role of doulas in the maternal and child health care continuum from the perspectives of patients, doulas, and healthcare providers, with the long-term goal of determining how to most effectively integrate doulas into interdisciplinary care teams to 1) reduce barriers to treatment, 2) improve perinatal outcomes, and 3) provide equitable patient-centered care for pregnant and postpartum populations with substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cephalosporin antibiotics are commonly used but can result in allergic reactions and anaphylaxis. There is no clear diagnostic approach for cephalosporin-allergic patients, and guidance for the use of other antibiotics in allergic patients is based on side chain chemical similarity and limited skin testing evidence. This project includes a clinical trial and mechanistic studies to optimize the approach to cephalosporin allergy and advance future diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Subjects in diabetic macular edema (DME) clinical trials in the United States are disproportionately White and male, compared with the population undergoing treatment for DME and limited evidence suggests that minoritized men with greater central macular thickness (CMT) are at risk for vision loss if left untreated. The Health Equity and Access to Leverage Technology for Improved DR Outcomes (HEAL-DR) study seeks to understand the association of optical coherence tomography and CMT, laboratory, and clinical measures for racial and ethnic minority patients for reducing visual impairment using an innovative strategy that incorporates data from the Sight OUtcomes Research CollaborativE (SOURCE). This research will have high impact by providing the health sector and other stakeholders research that will enhance visual risk assessment to better identify minority people at greatest risk for vision loss from undetected and/or worsening disease on a population level to enhance clinical guidelines for high-risk minority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Half of adolescents who suffer from pediatric systemic lupus erythematosus do not take medications regularly as prescribed and face high risk of poor health outcomes. Though critically important to health outcomes, non- adherence is often difficult to identify in research and clinical care settings using existing measures. This proposal will use pharmacokinetic model simulations to define a blood concentration predictive of non- adherence, and then develop and pilot test a novel, patient-facing intervention designed to reduce non- adherence in pediatric systemic lupus erythematosus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Proper brain function requires neural activity in the cerebral cortex with a broad repertoire of intrinsic timescales, from a few milliseconds to many seconds. Determining the fundamental origins of cortical intrinsic timescales and mechanisms that tune the repertoire of timescales is important for advancing understanding of the brain in health and in brain disorders. The research proposed here meets this challenge by developing new theoretical approaches and user-friendly data analytic tools that holistically account for multiple timescales and applies these tools to gain insight on how the brain changes as we awake from sleep and become alert.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The goal of the clinical trial proposed in this project is to test whether treating a donor kidney with a drug called Berinert®, that blocks an inflammation pathway, will improve outcomes of patients given a kidney transplant from a donor who died. We will also use blood samples and small pieces of kidney tissue obtained by a biopsy to analyze how the treatment affects the donor kidney after transplantation. If the study is successful, we believe the findings will change the way physicians treat kidney transplant recipients in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients attempting to initiate buprenorphine treatment now routinely experience precipitated withdrawal despite waiting for withdrawal symptoms to first emerge, leading many clinicians and patients to recommend a novel strategy called “micro-dosing” or “low-dose” buprenorphine induction. Even though the emerging evidence of low-dose inductions is promising, conventional approaches require splitting the buprenorphine medication, are costly, or utilize formulations prohibited in the United States. We therefore propose to conduct a study to evaluate the safety and feasibility of orally administered buprenorphine as a low-dose induction strategy, which if successful will be the basis for a safe, accessible, and an evidence-based approach to buprenorphine initiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Patients suffering from congestive heart failure due to severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction may require a ventricular assistive device (VAD)—a mechanical pump alternative to cardiac transplantation—to increase cardiac output, which, once implanted, VAD patients are dependent on for their wellbeing, and many become completely dependent on the device’s output for their very survival. The performance of the VAD pump is in part dependent on the physical and functional aspects of the pump itself, but equally important is the moment to moment interaction between the pump and the patient’s native cardiovascular system, and while current generation pumps have internal monitors of pump performance, their capabilities are rudimentary and typically require advanced cardiovascular diagnostics (transthoracic or transesophageal echocardiography) for correlation with patient signs and symptomatology. The goal of this research is to prove advanced acoustic interrogation of the VAD device can provide information related to the physical mechanisms causing the condition that is not currently available to clinicians at the bedside regarding VAD loading conditions and pump performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Toxic organophosphorus (OP) compounds, ranging from insecticides to chemical warfare agents, pose a persistent threat to human populations in a variety of contexts. We seek to develop a highly effective clinical treatment for OP exposure, based on a modified human butyrylcholinesterase (BChE) enzyme with catalytic degradation activity against nerve agents. Key to this approach is the targeted installation of a hydrolytic zinc site within the BChE active site gorge, which will functionally mimic the active sites of bacterial enzymes with strong OP degradation (hydrolase) activity while retaining the bioavailability of a human enzyme.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Vascular access is the most common medical procedure in the world, with over a billion insertions performed annually. Ultrasound-guided vascular access is increasingly utilized but still has success rate stagnant at 81% primarily due to low contrast resolution, and the unsuccessful cases can develop significant patient discomfort, decreased efficiency, increased costs, and occasionally life and limb threatening complications. To address the enormous problem, we propose a vendor-independent ‘5T (tool tip tracking + tissue typing)-IV’ guidance platform to augment the clinical US imaging guidance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Although the absolute risk of violence among persons with serious mental illnesses (SMI) is small, young people experiencing early psychosis are a subgroup at highest violence risk with estimates that up to one-third of individuals engage in violence. Despite the public health impact of violence in this population, no evidence-based behavioral interventions to reduce violence have been tested. This study will conduct mixed-methods formative research within OnTrackNY, the largest early intervention services (EIS) program in the United States, to adapt and assess the feasibility of a behavioral intervention to reduce violence for young adults with early psychosis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed work addresses a relevant public health concern through advancing health care patient safety by developing novel, artificial intelligence based health information technology (IT) tools to guide critical care pharmacists in preventing medication errors and reducing adverse drug events (ADEs). Critical care pharmacists improve medication safety and patient-centered outcomes in the critically ill but are an underused resource. Therefore, this project is relevant to the AHRQ mission because it will contribute to implementation of health IT tools that can improve health care quality and outcomes through the prediction of ADEs that can be prevented by critical care pharmacists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteria encode a broad range of immune systems that protect individual cells and cell populations from infection by bacteriophages, but whether and how these systems coordinate their activities to fight infections is not known. We will characterize how two transcriptional regulators control bacterial immune system expression in response to DNA damage, and determine whether these regulators enable multiple immune systems to synergistically fight a bacteriophage infection. As antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections rise and bacteriophage therapy becomes more mainstream, this work will aid the rational design of effective bacteriophage therapies that circumvent and/or suppress bacterial immune responses.

PHR: Project Narrative  The perception of gut distension is an interoceptive feeling associated with a number of clinical conditions. However, we still don’t understand how the brain discriminates between distension and nutrient sensing. We will map the circuitry linking the spinal cord to the brain to decipher how gut mechanical signals are perceived.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Down syndrome (DS) pre-disposes individuals for early-age onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and sleep disturbances are common sequelae in both pathologies. This relationship suggests that chronic sleep disturbance in DS could be one factor that contributes to or hastens the onset of AD. The purpose of this grant is to determine the extent that trisomy21 candidate mediators, Amyloid Precursor Protein (APP) and Regulator of calcineurin1 (RCAN1), contribute to sleep disturbances in DS, thus establishing a mechanistic link between DS and early-age onset AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Over 3 million Americans have glaucoma, of whom 120,000 are blind. Visual field tests are essential for monitoring the treatment of glaucoma to prevent vision loss. We made a new test with a modernized task, called Vivid Vision Perimetry (VVP) that patients can easily use on their own at home to collect massive amounts of data about their vision. In the proposed project, we will quantify the ability of VVP to detect loss of vision in patients with glaucoma, so patients can know within months rather than years whether they can stop worrying, or need to take additional action to save their vision.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High utilizers of the emergency department have a very heavy burden of chronic illness, significant unmet social and behavioral health needs, and account for a large proportion of health care spending. Improving care and decreasing costs of this patient population is an urgent demand for health systems. This project will provide evidence about the effectiveness of patient navigation for emergency department high utilizers, and will result in an evidence-based, optimized model of patient navigation to disseminate and test in future research.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Effectiveness of Patient Navigation to Address Social and Behavioral Health Needs for Emergency Department High Utilizers.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current approaches to the measurement of shared decision making (SDM), a process in which patients and clinicians work together to understand the patient’s problematic situation and collaboratively develop a plan of care, are inadequate in determining if SDM occurs when a patient and clinician make a decision together. Therefore, the objectives of this proposal are to develop a theoretically based, expert-informed, user-tested, observer-based measure of if SDM occurs (“SDMo”), and to estimate its reliability and validity. The outcome of this work, led by a team of experts in SDM, measure development and validation, and user-centered design, will enable a more accurate assessment of how often SDM is used in the care of patients with multiple chronic health conditions and, in the longer term, improve the quality and consistency of research on SDM in this priority population.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: SDMo – a measure of the occurrence of SDM in the care of patients with chronic conditions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Monoclonal antibody therapies are an important class of therapies that have been used to treat a wide range of diseases including cancer, autoimmune conditions, and even viral infections like COVID-19. We propose to develop easily accessible tools so that scientists can more quickly discover the best antibodies, and understand their function at the earliest stages of discovery. Enabling more access to cutting-edge tools ultimately will yield cost savings to health systems and better outcomes for more patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New, molecular imaging tests offering improved detection of prostate cancer are changing the management of the disease in ways that are not understood but have the potential for both positive and negative effects on patients and their disease. In this proposal we aim to understand the effectiveness of molecular imaging tests with the goal of helping patients and prostate cancer stakeholders make more informed clinical decisions that account for the cascade of effects that can be set into motion. To accomplish this, we will generate new evidence relating to the effects of PET imaging in the real-world setting, ultimately integrating this data in a decision model that will generate a clearer picture about the tradeoffs of imaging, including practical scenarios that are most or least likely to benefit patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Johnson, Kevin DP1 Details Project Name: Helping Doctors Doctor: Using AI to Automate Documentation and “De-Autonomate” Health Care Project Narrative Clinical encounter documentation has become an increasingly burdensome, typically manual process that has been implicated as a major source of physician cognitive burden and job dissatisfaction. At the same time, computer science methods such as natural language processing and deep learning have yet to be explored as alternative approaches to summarizing medical data collected in real time. As a pediatrician and biomedical informatician with considerable expertise in real-world systems design, I propose to use those skills to design and test methods to automate documentation from clinical encounter audio, video, and EHR data and to demonstrate its feasibility as a novel documentation approach that improves the quality of what is communicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The NIH has created the Helping to End Addiction Long-term (HEAL) initiative to speed scientific solutions to the national opioid public health crisis. Trials will be conducted through the NIH HEAL Pain Management Effectiveness Research Network (HEAL Pain ERN), which will use the infrastructure of the NCATS Trial Innovation Network to provide scientific guidance and coordination of the HEAL Pain ERN Trials. The four innovation centers (3 TICs, 1 RIC) will provide integrated functions for the clinical coordinating resource center, data coordinating resource center, statistics and safety resource center, and recruitment resource center. The Johns Hopkins-Tufts TIC will serve as the statistics and safety resource center.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The scientific goal of this project is to examine the efficacy of a mobile insomnia app, enhanced with brief alcohol intervention content, for non-treatment involved post-9/11 veterans with insomnia disorder and alcohol use disorder (AUD). IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Submassive pulmonary embolism (PE) is a common dangerous disease that often causes cardiopulmonary disability, reduced functional capacity, and decreased quality of life; catheter-directed therapy (CDT), by acutely reducing clot burden and improving right ventricular function, has the potential to prevent these long- term complications. This study will determine if CDT, rather than anticoagulant therapy alone, should be used to treat patients with submassive PE. The Data Coordinating Center, led by experts with deep experience in adaptive and pragmatic clinical trial design and implementation, will oversee all aspects of study design, implementation, and analysis, and will provide state-of-the-art data collection and quality control infrastructure, reporting to the independent Data and Safety Monitoring Board, and provision of data and resources to the public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative The US is dealing with an opioid crisis; up to 11 million people are misusing their prescription opioids, leading to high rates of overdose and death. While adverse childhood experiences are a risk factor for opioid misuse and opioid use disorder, the neurocognitive pathways underlying this link are not known. This project will test the hypothesis that hippocampal-associated context-dependent learning and memory is a crucial link between adverse childhood experiences and opioid use disorder, with findings informing efforts to create individually tailored prevention and treatment to reduce opioid misuse and overdose.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proprioception is a critical sensory modality for feedback control of motor actions. How mechanosensory signals at primary proprioceptors and motor commands interact is incompletely understood. This project uses the unique advantages of jaw proprioceptors to elucidate how proprioceptive signals are modulated by motor commands and build a quantitative model of jaw proprioception during active movements.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is an aggressive malignancy epitomized by rapid relapse and pervasive, insurmountable treatment-resistance with a major unmet need to study mechanisms underlying this resistance. To address this, Dr. Allison Stewart (Research Specialist), a Research Scientist with Dr. Lauren Byers (Unit Director) at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, has established a SCLC repository for patient circulating tumor cell (CTC)-derived xenograft (CDX) models and has supervised the collection and analysis of patient liquid and tumor biopsies for innovative genomic, transcriptomic and proteomic analyses to study adaptations driving treatment resistance in SCLC. These efforts have demonstrated with single-cell resolution that treatment resistance involves a dynamic process of shifting gene expression profiles to generate an increasingly heterogeneous tumor with multiple, concurrent mechanisms of resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE  Radiation therapy applied to one tumor has the ability to induce anti-tumor T cell responses that, in combination with immune checkpoint blockade therapy, cause systemic tumor regression. The goal of this proposal is to understand the mechanisms that enable the immune response elicited at the irradiated tumor site to be effective against non-irradiated metastases. This information will fill knowledge gaps about the role of radiotherapy in enhancing responses to immunotherapy, and possibly identify candidate biomarkers and actionable targets to improve cancer patients selection and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed Biomedical Technology Development and Dissemination Center aims to consolidate and distribute imaging-based technology for the study of cellular signals. The Center will combine computer vision, light-sheet microscopy, and advanced imaging probes to visualize, control, and model molecular activities at the level of microns and seconds. The technology will be tested and refined in diverse biological systems and disseminated to the greater scientific community in partnerships with microscopy core facilities and established distribution platforms (Addgene, GitHub, ImageJ/Fiji, Applied Scientific Instrumentation).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA is a major area of biomedical research and the basis of several novel core therapeutics being explored by diverse types of biotechnology companies. RNA is difficult to work with since it is highly susceptible to degradation, requires considerable time and effort for synthesis in the laboratory, difficult to purify, and difficult to chemically label. This proposal will result in the generation of two high-impact market-ready kits, one of which will allow researchers to create (1) large quantities of (2) highly stable and (3) highly purified RNA; and the other will allow researchers to readily impart diverse types of chemical tags to these RNAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Monitoring air quality is fundamental for understanding the biological and environmental vulnerabilities of a population in order to mitigate the effects of climate change and to ensure human health. Quantifying the impacts of ambient air pollution on pregnant women and neonates is a complex task, especially in countries across sub-Saharan Africa, where access to pollution exposure data is limited. In this proposed research project, we will utilize advanced data science solutions such as machine learning approaches to characterize pollution exposure and to understand its associations with adverse outcomes in maternal, newborn and child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: The mission of the NIH-funded Atlanta Center for Microsystems Engineered POC Technologies (ACME POCT) is to assist and enable inventors from across the country who have developed microsystems-based POC technologies in defining their specific clinical needs, conducting clinical validation, and refining their technology, with the objective of accelerating the path to translation and clinical adoption. The ACME POCT uniquely leverages Atlanta’s nationally top-ranked clinical programs at Emory University’s hospitals and Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta, one of the nation’s largest pediatric hospital systems, as well the internationally acclaimed microsystems engineering expertise at Georgia Tech, which includes the Institute for Electronics and Nanotechnology, and other one-of-a-kind medical device prototyping, innovation, and testbed facilities. With the enhanced experience and expertise the ACME POCT gained serving as the Test Validation Core for the Rapid Acceleration of Diagnostics during the COVID-19 pandemic, the center is now especially well positioned to apply our lessons learned from RADx towards assisting any and all microsystems POC diagnostics for any and all clinical applications with a hands-on, pro-active approach.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The complexity of brain dynamics makes it difficult to understand how the brain controls the body in health and disease. This research project uses new methods for controlling neural circuits to investigate how variable activity patterns generate different motor behaviors. This will provide new insights into the neural basis of behavior and tools for manipulating brain dynamics with potential therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Negative consequences of substance use are often underestimated because they occur later in time. However, little is known about how the brain processes the threat of delayed punishment during decision-making. This project will investigate the role of two understudied neuronal circuits in regulating sensitivity to both delayed and immediate punishment, which may enable novel neurobiological treatments to improve decision-making in substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to support African American mothers who have survived intimate partner violence (IPV) in order to buffer the mental health impact of trauma on their children. This project will leverage the sponsor’s R01 adapting the evidence-based Mediational Intervention for Sensitizing Caregivers (MISC) specifically for African American mothers to evaluate its suitability for adoption using mixed methodology and the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR). Barriers and facilitators to scale-up will be identified related to the intervention, outer setting, and inner setting for the project to make comprehensive recommendations for future adoption of MISC at scale and disseminate this evidence-based treatment to a priority population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Data-Driven Sleep Biomarkers of Brain Health, Heart Health, and Mortality RELEVANCE: Sleep state signals encode critical biological information about brain and cardiovascular health. However, present approaches to polysomnography data (“sleep studies”) discard most of this information. This project will establish a comprehensive new dataset and new tools leveraging recent advances in data science to develop robust sleep-based biomarkers of brain and cardiovascular health and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The palatable taste of sugar promotes excess calorie intake and has fueled epidemics of deadly diseases, like obesity and diabetes, in the United States. The proposed experiments aim to deepen our understanding about how sugars are sensed in the oral cavity and processed in brain reward circuits to reinforce consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Advanced rectal tumors are treated with combined chemotherapy and radiation therapy (chemoradiation) prior to surgery, but there is wide variation in the magnitude of tumor response. Optimizing non-surgical chemoradiation-based treatments could spare some patients the need to undergo a morbid surgery, but will require a detailed understanding of how chemoradiation causes evolution of tumor subpopulations as well as the development of unique approaches to therapeutically target these evolving subpopulations. This project will use cutting-edge techniques to dissect tumor responses to chemoradiation as well as an innovative approach to identify new treatment strategies for locally advanced rectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This research will provide a theoretically-motivated account of the cortical mechanisms behind sensorimotor con- trol in the typical speech of patients with Epilepsy undergoing extra-operative clinical monitoring. The project will also account for the subcortical contribution to sensorimotor control in individuals with dysarthria and Parkinson's disease who have undergone neurosurgical intervention. Results will inform the development of novel treatment approaches that tap into sensorimotor control mechanisms to improve speech outcomes in Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative  T-stellate cells have sharp frequency tuning and selective responses to fluctuations in sound amplitude and are implicated in the first processing of auditory signals relating to speech. T-stellate cells in the anteroventral cochlear nucleus provide one of the largest sources of input to the inferior colliculus (IC), however, how T-stellate input to the IC contributes to speech processing remains largely unknown. The proposed research will determine how T-stellate cells influence IC signal processing at a cellular and circuit level and will provide a crucial advance towards understanding how the ascending auditory pathway processes signals pertaining to vocalization and speech cues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The hippocampus plays a key role not only in encoding new episodic memories, but in separating neural representations for highly similar—and potentially interfering—memories. The proposed research will leverage Natural Language Processing algorithms and advanced computational and neuroimaging methods to test whether separation of hippocampal representations predicts distortions in how events are actually remembered (i.e., the content of episodic memories). The project will lead to fundamental new insight into how the hippocampus resolves interference between similar memories and will establish exciting new approaches for investigating these mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Identifying the mechanisms of organizational implementation strategies that positively impacted implementation outcomes and child outcomes is crucial for creating targeted implementation interventions to improve the health outcomes of autistic children. Leveraging data from the TEAMS (Translating Evidence- based Interventions for Autism: A Multi-Level Implementation Strategy) Hybrid Type III trials, the proposed project will 1) identify individual climate embedding mechanisms associated with implementation (provider) and clinical (child) outcomes, 2) utilize quantitative methods to examine whether the individual climate embedding mechanisms identified in Aim 1 mediate the effects of an organization-level implementation strategy on implementation and clinical outcomes, and 3) Use qualitative and mixed methods to complement and expand quantitative findings on additional climate embedding mechanisms and explain how individual mechanisms facilitated implementation of autism EBPs. The present study represents an important step in further understanding mechanisms of organizational implementation strategies for autism EBPs in publicly funded settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Enhancer RNAs (eRNAs) are a new class of noncoding RNAs that play important roles in chromatin interactions and regulation of gene expression, but their significance during stroke is not known. In this project, we investigate the role of a recently identified stroke-induced eRNA in the adult cerebral cortex in order to understand its involvement in post-stroke brain damage. This work may help identify novel therapeutic targets against ischemic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Adaptive functioning in all animals, including humans, requires a careful balance between recognition and pursuit of potential rewards (food, shelter, and social interaction, among others) and detection and avoidance of potential threats (theft, natural disasters, and interpersonal rejection, for instance). Many psychiatric diseases involve impairments in one or both of these processes, symptoms which significantly impair functioning and cause considerable distress. The present work will investigate the neural basis of alterations in reward and threat processing following chronic stress in mice, with the goal of understanding and ameliorating the changes in brain circuitry that lead to impairments in reward and threat processing.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this Glioblastoma Therapeutics Network U19 application is to develop superior treatments for patients with glioblastoma, the most common and aggressive primary brain tumor in adults. Effective treatments for glioblastoma remain elusive, and patients are rarely cured with standard therapies. The proposed research projects will all evaluate novel therapeutic agents in phase 1 clinical trials, and, if successful, have the potential to transform the treatment of patients with glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The motor behaviors we engage in constitute a fundamental element of human experience, and yet, it is poorly understood how these behaviors interact with our ability to remember novel, non-motor information. My proposal will bridge the fields of motor learning and episodic memory by revealing how the well-learned motor routines we follow as part of everyday life (e.g., commuting to work) facilitate memory for temporally-coincident novel experiences, while also shedding light on the neural mechanisms that underlie these interactions. In the long term, this work will strengthen theories of how distinct memory systems interact in behavior and the brain, which may advance knowledge of how episodic memory deficits arise in populations with motor impairments (e.g., Parkinson’s), and how they can be mitigated in those where motor function is spared (e.g., Alzheimer’s).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 30% of patients with dementia have aggregates of alpha-synuclein called Lewy bodies in the brain, and when these are present, patients should not receive antipsychotic drugs to treat common symptoms because these drugs can cause rapid worsening of the disease and early death. Current methods to determine which patients have these aggregates are difficult, expensive, and rarely used in patients without clear evidence of specific diseases, resulting in more than two-thirds of these patients going undiagnosed. This project is designed to develop and validate a new blood-based test to determine whether patients with dementia have these aggregates, with the goal of informing patient care to prevent inappropriate prescription of antipsychotic drugs.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a rapidly progressive fatal disease for which there are few therapeutic options. Understanding how to predict clinical responses to available therapeutics would be a significant clinical advance in treating this disease by permitting tailored, targeted and effective first line therapies. Our continued studies seek to develop and validate a decision support tool for predicting survival in Adult and Pediatric PAH, which will allow the scientific community and patients a means to choose appropriate specific therapies based on individual risks and patient choices in order to improve survival and quality of life for our patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stress response mechanisms play a dual role in organism health- they are required for tissue homeostasis and also for minimizing damage during toxic conditions. Intimate molecular knowledge of these mechanisms will thus inform clinical approaches to prolong tissue function under pathobiological conditions. Consistent with the mission of the NIGMS, the research described herein aims to gain such mechanistic understanding and will have broadly relevance to many pathologies from neurodegeneration to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current proposal is highly relevant to public health and to the NIA’s mission of advancing knowledge on the causes of aging processes and age-associated diseases to extend healthy lifespan. This funding opportunity is critical as it will allow me to change my research field to one, spatial transcriptomics applied to brain aging, that I currently do not have preliminary data for. I will use my expertise in neural function and in non-coding RNAs to identify key factors involved in accelerated brain aging that can be targeted to delay or reverse brain aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative: Early detection of cancer and pre-cancerous lesions improves outcomes and reduces the cost and pain associated with treatment. Better tools are needed to improve early detection of cancer at the point-of-care, especially in medically underserved communities. The Center for Innovation and Translation of Point-of-Care Technologies for Equitable Cancer Care (CITEC) will accelerate the development and adoption of new technologies that can be used to improve the early detection of cancer in low-resource settings in the US and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This research seeks to develop and test an integrated, multi-level, and interdisciplinary program in two schools of Dentistry that will promote a research “culture” among dental students, residents, clinical faculty, and throughout their oral health educational programs. Partnering between a research-intensive college of Dentistry (i.e., University of Florida) and a newer dental school (i.e., East Carolina University that has a growing research focus, there will be training in clinical research skills, team-based science, mentoring, and interdisciplinary collaboration, in the context of two clinical research studies with dental patients, one on diabetes detection and the other acute/chronic pain. This approach has the potential for dissemination to other schools of Dentistry and various health science training programs, with a positive impact on public health through a more research-informed and evidence-based workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will deliver replicated findings of functional and structural connectivity abnormalities in schizotypy and schizophrenia based on large-scale, global, collaborative meta-analyses. It will identify shared brain connectivity abnormalities, associated with overlapping symptoms, and unique brain connectivity abnormalities, associated with non-overlapping functioning profiles between schizotypy and schizophrenia which lie at the extremes of the schizophrenia spectrum continuum. Finally, the study will generate label-noise-reduced, machine-learning based models that generate schizotypy protective and schizophrenia liability scores that may serve as biomarkers for functioning, and that may be predictive of functional outcome in schizophrenia and possibly individuals at clinical high risk for psychosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the earliest pathologic changes in Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is critical to developing neuroprotective therapies for this devastating dementia. Defects in the energy systems of brain cells are thought to be critically involved, but this has been difficult to study in people. This study utilizes a combination of brain imaging techniques and other measures, in people who are at risk for or have developed DLB, in order to determine how and when the energy system fails and to help guide development of targeted protective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to advance the knowledge and skills of next-generation dental clinicians to conduct practice-based research (PBR), acquire critical thinking skills, and facilitate interprofessional communication and care to address dental patients’ conditions such as Sjögren’s Disease (SD) that require multidisciplinary expertise for timely diagnosis and management. The PBR study will develop a salivary hypofunction index in combination with salivary biomarkers to detect patients susceptible to SD, thus improving shared decision- making and management of patients at risk for SD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work examines the role of PIDD1 in brain development and is motivated by genetic findings in patients with lissencephaly, a devastating disorder characterized by simplified or absent convolutions in the anterior part of the brain. The work aims to understand the function of PIDD1 in mammalian brain development and to apply a novel approach to the analysis of existing whole exome sequencing datasets from additional patients with smooth brain, to discover other genes and gene networks that are involved in this condition. Successful completion of the work will provide insights into the biology and function of PIDD1, expand our understanding of the development of the normal brain and the genetic causes of smooth brain, and inform future studies aimed at the identification of possible interventions for this disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the evidence for reduced morbidity and mortality for people with HIV (PWH) who receive tuberculosis preventive therapy (TPT), and guidelines recommending TPT for PWH and other persons at high risk for TB including contacts, there remains a substantial gap between people recommended to receive and people who actually receive and complete a course of TPT. With the recent availability and evidence for newer, shorter TPT regimens (e.g. 3HP, 12 weekly doses of isoniazid and rifapentine), and successful transformation of HIV care delivery models (in part forced by the COVID-19 pandemic), it is increasingly urgent to adapt and investigate new patient-friendly, differentiated service delivery models for TPT in order to inform programmatic guidance that results in greater uptake, adherence, and completion of TPT. We will conduct a randomized controlled trial of community-based vs. clinic-based TPT delivery among people participating in a community-based TB screening program in South Africa, examine barriers and facilitators of TPT completion with qualitative research, and explore the feasibility of task-shifted TPT delivery engaging pharmacy staff in South African public sector clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will examine the impact of Maryland’s Global Budget Revenue (GBR) program on spending, utilization, and quality of care for individuals with cancer in Maryland and similar patients in control states. As policy makers consider expanding the GBR program, this proposal has important public health implications because it evaluates a population that disproportionately drives Medicare spending, and it seeks to determine if this program leads to inequities in care for historically marginalized populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The recent public successes of deep learning have reinvigorated computational thinking around healthcare and biology. This work develops rigorous methods and tools ensuring the efficient application of machine learning principles to computational biology. This will save resources and make these tools more reliable when they are ultimately deployed for diagnostic, research, or clinical purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Results from the 2020 national survey on alcohol use and health show that about 17 million Americans met the diagnostic criteria for moderate to severe alcohol use disorder (AUD), and relapse to alcohol seeking has become a public health concern. Psychopathology of the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) has been implicated in enhanced propensity for relapse. In this proposal, using a well-established rodent model of moderate to severe AUD and enhanced propensity for relapse, we will begin to identify the role of endothelial cell specific junction protein cadherin-5 in the mPFC in relapse to ethanol seeking, and offer a mechanistic approach by evaluating the associated endothelial transcriptome, inflammatory and neuronal alterations in the mPFC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE UCSF’s Clinical and Translational Research Innovation in Dental Schools (ClinTrain-RIDeS) will provide a robust clinical research development program at the individual trainee level (predoctoral and postdoctoral) with the overall goal of preparing the future pipeline of dentist-scientists (NIDCR Strategic Priorities 4.1 and 4.2 Diverse Research Pipeline), at the school level to create a supportive environment enabling and encouraging practice-based clinical research activities that lead to new discoveries and innovations in advancing oral health and the quality of dental care, and at the community-level to expand the reach of UCSF’s vast research resources to a new dental school (California Northstate University College of Dental Medicine) and several community-based clinics (NIDCR Strategic Priority 5.4.2). The practice-based artificial intelligence (AI)-generated caries diagnosis and treatment planning study will partner with a dental AI industry leader (NIDCR Strategic Priority 5.3 cross-sector initiatives with industry partners) to improve patient care (NIDCR Strategic Priority 2.2.3) and establish a Learning Health System (NIDCR Strategic Priority 3.3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The Harvard School of Dental Medicine Collaborative Clinical Practice-based REsearch Program for DENTal Schools (H-CREDENT) will engage dental students and residents with research and clinical-based faculty in an integrated, experiential, multidisciplinary dental school practice-based clinical research program. Outcomes of the clinical investigation of disabling pain following dental procedures will allow risk stratification via artificial intelligence/machine learning using patient demographics, clinician management, patient psychosocial determinants, and salivary-based genomic measures. H-CREDENT will advance NIDCR’s national public health research mission in the training of next-generation oral healthcare workforce in the conduct of dental practice- based clinical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Relevance Fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) is completely preventable, yet remains among the top 3 known causes of intellectual disability with an estimated prevalence of 2.4-4.8% in the US that accrues costs to society greater than $3 billion annually. Most children with FASD experience greater early life adversity compared to non-exposed children, yet little is known about how the perinatal, infant and early childhood environment interacts with the effects of prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) on brain and cognitive development. Capitalizing on the large prospective cohort study of children in South Africa where rates of maternal alcohol consumption are high, and in which mothers reported on alcohol consumption during and throughout pregnancy, will allow us to address significant gaps in knowledge about the impact of PAE across the full range of maternal drinking patterns on later brain and cognitive development, as well as interactive effects with early life environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE Alcohol misuse is the largest source of morbidity and mortality in emerging adults (age 18-29) in the United States and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has significantly increased alcohol- related morbidity and mortality. There is a need to understand how emerging adults successfully reduce their alcohol use, factors that contribute to elevated alcohol risk, and opportunities for connecting high-risk emerging adults with evidence-based alcohol-related interventions. The proposed study will accomplish those goals by conducting detailed interviews with a group of racially and economically diverse emerging adult drinkers who have been enrolled in our longitudinal study of alcohol risk since prior to the pandemic, in order to understand pandemic impacts on drinking trajectories and factors promoting drinking reductions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative One goal of this research is to conduct a non-inferiority trial of telerehabilitation versus in-office care to provide follow-up training to individuals with low vision to enhance their quality of life by using magnification devices and/or visual assistive mobile apps for important daily activities, such as reading and/or other valued tasks. This is a high priority given the increasing prevalence of low vision, paucity of low vision rehabilitation providers, and barriers related to access to care, such as transportation and geography, which can be essentially eliminated with telerehabilitation. Another goal of this project is to determine whether significant changes in environmental data collected by Bluetooth low energy beacon sensors can be used as a solution to monitor and indicate when low vision patients’ have abandoned the use of their magnification devices, which has the potential to substantially enhance patient management by providing timely low vision rehabilitation services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver disease is a consequence of alcohol use disorder in which decreasing alcohol use is critical for survival, yet few patients receive alcohol use disorder treatment. This proposal will investigate the integration of treatments for alcohol use disorder, including medications and brief counseling, into liver clinics using a combined approach including: determining the impact of medications for alcohol use disorder in patients with liver disease, assessing patient perspectives regarding receipt of integrated care for alcohol use disorder and alcohol-associated liver disease, and assessing the feasibility and acceptability of a method to help liver specialists provide alcohol use disorder care. The results of this work will inform interventions to improve outcomes in patients with alcohol use disorder and alcohol-associated liver disease through new integrated care models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will provide foundational training that allows students and faculty to competently perform clinical practice-based research well into the future. Furthermore, it will provide applied training in conducting research through the launch of a large, multisite clinical study to assess the relationship between oral inflammation (OI) and functional gastrointestinal disorders (FGIDs), both of which affect up to 40% of populations worldwide. An unresolved connection is documented for OI and FGIDs and this clinical study will explore whether OI observed by dentists can be used to identify a patient’s likelihood of having or developing a FGID, providing information that patients can use to seek appropriate care or intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatments for age-related memory decline rely on understanding the basic mechanisms of hippocampal memory formation and storage over time. The proposed experiments will investigate these mechanisms using a novel method combining two-photon imaging and activity-dependent genetic strategies to identify and track populations of neurons storing episodic memories in the hippocampus. The conclusions from these experiments will advance current models of associative memory formation, ultimately contributing to a circuit-level understanding of memory in order to provide targets for intervention in treatments for memory deficits in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Guaranteed Basic Income (GBI) could address deep systemic social and structural inequities that lead to health disparities in Black youth, with potential to improve the financial, mental and physical well-being of Black emerging adults during their critical period of transition to independence. This study includes implementation and evaluation of an innovative, multilevel intervention to address grave inequities in health by providing GBI and access to financial coaching, peer-support, and real-time monitoring of needs and referral to services. The project will provide critical data needed to understand the potential of GBI for Black youth and how to maximize its impact on health with targeted programming at a time when multiple municipalities are considering GBI legislation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep deprivation results in impairment in long-term potentiation (LTP) in the hippocampus. This proposal aims to uncover a specific molecular mechanism involving cAMP phosphodiesterase isoform PDE4A5 and its involvement in regulating AMPA receptors in b2AR-stimulated cAMP signaling concerning memory impairment in sleep deprivation. Unveiling this molecular mechanism could lead to novel pharmaceutical targeting and advancing current perspectives on neurological disorders involving memory impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As we continue to fight to understand the opioid epidemic and a chronic pain crisis, a major avenue of research has remained glaringly under-investigated: the role of endogenous opioid peptides. This study will lay the long-overdue groundwork into investigating the role that the endogenous opioids play in mediating pain and the role they play in the sex differences that exist in pain and opioid analgesia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this work is to increase our understanding of the genetic predispositions underlying FASD and to uncover novel pathogenic mechanisms in order to aid in prevention and intervention efforts. We will use genomic, transcriptomic, and chemical interactions in zebrafish and mice to discover novel candidate genes that modify susceptibility to early gestational ethanol exposure. Subsequent experiments will use gene editing in zebrafish and mice to further confirm candidate genes that may interact with ethanol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Project Narrative) Chronic pain is a major health condition in people living with Human Immunodeficiency Virus-1 (PLWH) in the combined antiretroviral therapy (ART) era, but the current pharmacologic therapies are not effective in managing chronic neuropathic pain, and side effects are common. The development of new and effective therapeutic tools has been hampered in part by the lack of a suitable animal model that can mimic the HIV-related chronic neuropathic pain condition. The characterization that EcoHIV-infected mice develop a neuropathic pain-like condition with behavioral and pathological changes that mimic neuropathic pain in PLWH will advance the fields of HIV and pain by laying the groundwork for urgently needed therapeutic and mechanistic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a problematic, aggressive, and unpredictable subtype of invasive breast cancer associated with a high systemic recurrence rate with lethal metastasis. Currently, there are very few effective drugs approved by the FDA for the treatment of patients with advanced TNBC. In this project, we will investigate the activity of an experimental compound named LG007 and determine its potential as a new drug candidate for the treatment of TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: As the most common group of inherited retinal degenerations, retinitis pigmentosa (RP) affects about 1.5 million people worldwide. This proposal aims to establish a human retinal organoid model system that recapitulates BBS7, a particularly severe form of RP, to allow for the investigation into mechanistic causes and therapeutic rescue of this disease. These studies will provide an excellent mentored training experience in translational research and will generate a pipeline for therapeutic gene editing to treat individuals with severe inherited retinal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Hepatocellular carcinoma is one of few cancers with a rising incidence a rise that disproportionally affects ethnic minorities and rural residents, however, known risk factors including viral hepatitis, fatty liver disease and cirrhosis cannot fully explain these disparities. Environmental contaminants such as cadmium are common pollutants, ranked in the top ten chemicals of concern, and can cause cancer in animals. We will create a cohort of 16,000 participants to determine whether exposure to multiple common environmental contaminants increases liver cancer risk, whether risk differentially impacts rural and ethnic minorities, and whether epigenetic mechanisms mediate these associations.

PHR: NARRATIVE Humans are exposed to large numbers of physical and chemical substances. However, it is unclear what exposures may increase the risk of cancers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Many motor neuron diseases (MNDs) such as spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) and some forms of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) result from minor genetic mutations that cause damage and cell-death in a largely similar set of tissues, thus a method to genomically correct MND mutations in affected tissues could therapeutically treat MNDs of many genetic origins. Clarity on the determinants of base editing outcomes is much needed to efficiently and precisely correct disease-relevant single nucleotide mutations that are intractable to conventional base editing tools, including many MND targets such as the pathogenic SMA allele and the ALS SOD1A4V mutation. By thorough characterization of base editor variants, and establishing an effective method to deliver genome editing tools to MND relevant tissues in vivo, we will create a general pipeline to design and validate optimized base editing strategies to correct causal MND mutations for the development of a therapeutic treatment for SMA and other genetic MNDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Senescence is a terminal cellular state that contributes to many human diseases. Identification and mapping of senescent cells in tissues will help understand the mechanisms of diseases, with the potential to discover novel disease therapies. We propose to employ a newly invented single-cell proteomic approach to investigate the proteomes of senescent cells in the lungs to reveal novel markers of senescent cells. The identified novel markers will facilitate our understanding of lung biology and disease, and further promote the identification and characterization of senescent cells in other human tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Training and skills development in clinical dental research are imperative to continued improvements in the quality of oral health care in the US, yet dental schools, residency programs, and clinical faculty are generally lacking in this area. Our proposal aims to improve the current state of such training through development of a 2- year MS in Clinical Dental Research, a Clinical Research Resource Network and Resource Center, a Mentorship Pathway, a regional clinical research symposium, and a multi-site developmental clinical study seeking to improve treatment for dental implant patients. Our multidisciplinary, practice-based research incubator is relevant to the NIDCR’s mission in that it will create the next generation of dental clinician-scientists who will create, improve, and deliver evidence-based care for our patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE APOE4 is the greatest known genetic risk factor for sporadic Alzheimer's and there exists a high unmet medical need for therapeutics that could prevent disease associated with this variant. We have developed an innovative split luciferase assay that can detect the binding of compounds to ApoE4 in cells. We propose to leverage this breakthrough to both discover new and optimize known ApoE4 correctors into drugs that can generate in vivo proof of concept that they can functionally correct ApoE4 pathobiology in murine models and ultimately be developed into a therapeutic for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lasting impacts: dynamic, fully natural bioprinted 3d human neurovascular biomimetic to study traumatic  brain injury pathophysiology Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a significant concern for military personnel and global public health, as patients who experience TBI often develop memory and behavioral impairments and are at heightened risk for developing neurodegenerative diseases later in life. The lack of adequate in vitro models that capture the complexity of neurovascular coupling is a key challenge to understanding mechanism and possible therapeutic approaches to improve the effects of TBI on cerebral vasculature. This research focuses on developing a biofidelic neurovascular unit to test the hypothesis that biomechanics of TBI (i.e., shear from trauma of the primary injury and variations in cerebral “blood flow”—a secondary injury of TBI) spatially and temporally influence vascular and neural pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Adolescence is a developmental period of significant risk for anxiety, depressive symptoms, and suicidality, and we propose to target key peer-based risk and protective factors using Cooperative Learning (CL). CL is a small-group instructional approach that can enhance peer relations and reduce peer-related risks, as well as promote academic engagement and achievement and reduce racial disparities. CL will be delivered with the aid of technology that automates the design and delivery of CL lessons, promoting rapid implementation, scalability, high fidelity, accessibility, and sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to develop and evaluate an “in-line and just in time” filtration platform composed of ß-cyclodextrin-based adsorbents, beads and micro/ultra-filtration membranes, that will preserve tissue integrity, and mitigate dermal pathologies associated with subcutaneous insulin administration (SIA)-devices by removing tissue cytotoxic and pro-inflammatory insulin phenolic preservatives and insulin derived fibrils present in commercial insulin formulations. This filtration platform can be easily integrated into current drug delivery devices without the need for the preparation of new insulin formulations, which will save time, money, and effort to advance the development of more effective and specific SIA-devices that will optimize future diabetes therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative After semen deposition, sperm form a reservoir in the oviduct, which supplies sperm to the site of fertilization. Research in this proposal will study sperm binding to the oviduct wall, how binding to the wall increases sperm lifespan, and determine if this fundamental research may be translated to improve the health of offspring produced by a modified in vitro fertilization technique. This fundamental knowledge may lead to simpler, more effective, and less expensive methods to improve the fertility and health of offspring from humans and many species.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will fill a gap by completing the adaptation of iTRAC, a web-based emotion regulation sexual health intervention, and testing its efficacy in promoting safer sexual cognitions and delaying sexual initiation among early adolescents. This application addresses the Office of Disease Prevention and Health Promotion's Healthy People 2030 indicator FP-08, to increase the proportion of adolescents who get formal sex education before age 18 years (currently less than 53%). It also uses a novel approach, emotion regulation skills training, to address indicator FP-04, to increase the proportion of adolescents who have never had sexual intercourse, and indicator FP-06, to increase the proportion of adolescents who used condoms at last sexual intercourse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: CENTER FOR INNOVATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RESEARCH
PHR: Youth who are assigned female at birth (AFAB) and identify as transgender (e.g., as non-binary or as trans boys), not as girls, are at risk for negative sexual health outcomes yet are effectively excluded from sexual health programs because gender-diverse youth do not experience the cisgender, heteronormative teen sexual education messaging available to them as salient or applicable. This lack of programming is likely contributing to obstacles to sexual health: Data suggest that AFAB trans-identified youth may be less likely to use condoms when having sex with people who have penises and are at least as likely as cisgender girls to be pregnant. #TranscendentHealth aims to address this health inequity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prediction models to assess periodontal disease (PD) risk have been developed. However, their clinical use is rare because of their suboptimal performance and absence of oral microbiome data, social determinants and behavioral factors, and accurate medical history. This application seeks to use real-time medical data from a health share exchange to develop a continuity of care report for oral health care, to build a risk prediction models for PD using machine learning approaches including subgingival and salivary microbiome data and to identify potential high resolution biomarkers of PD progression for better disease control and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Periodontitis is a common human mucosal chronic inflammatory disease characterized by destruction of tooth supporting structures, where severe and debilitating periodontitis affects 8-10% of the U.S. population. While it is well appreciated that host-susceptibility is a controlling factor of periodontitis development, a key knowledge gap is the identification of molecular determinants of host susceptibility that mediate severe periodontal disease. The goal of this research proposal is to understand how local fibrin-neutrophil engagement, a novel molecular determinant of periodontitis, mediates periodontitis pathogenesis in the context of both normal and compromised fibrinolysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Successful treatment of tuberculosis infections requires the prompt and accurate diagnosis of resistance to the full panel of antibiotics in clinical use. Here we propose a novel approach to diagnose antibiotic resistance to bedaquiline, pretomanid, linezolid, pyrazinamide, and moxifloxacin using RNA hybridization detecting a transcriptomic signature of antibiotic response. This approach circumvents the delays and biohazard of bacterial growth-based tests and the difficulties in interpretation of DNA based methods.
