IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Point of Care Technologies for Nutrition, Infection and Cancer for Global Health (PORTENT)  1.0 Overall Narrative Focusing on the largest clinical needs where access to better diagnostics can have the largest worldwide impact, we propose the formation of PORTENT – “Point-of-Care Technologies for Nutrition, Infection and Cancer for Global Health” centered at Cornell University in partnership with Columbia and McGill Universities. At full capacity we will advance between 6 and 7 parallel PoC technology teams through: human validation at one of our network of clinical sites spread across four continents, user and developer training and rotations, and commercialization. The PORTENT Center is differentiable from others as it (1) focuses on primary health care globally; (2) addresses the needs of the most vulnerable in the US and internationally; and (3) enable a broad range of diagnostic technologies to be validated on a global scale while simultaneously developing expertise and building capacity internationally to have the most impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Recently discharged psychiatric inpatients who misuse alcohol are at high risk for suicide. The proposed project involves the development of a novel intervention that would enhance care for these individuals by pairing inpatient-based emotion regulation skills training with a mobile health application that extends this treatment into the post-discharge period. Through acquisition and eventual utilization of emotion regulation skills to replace maladaptive, stress-induced emotion-driven behaviors (e.g., heavy drinking, suicide attempts), this approach could reduce post-discharge risk for a suicide crisis and costly rehospitalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Improving care for persons with chronic musculoskeletal pain is a priority in the Military Health System. The Military Health System is supporting a shift towards more holistic approaches to pain management. In this project we will evaluate two different interventions that provide holistic pain care; Empowered Relief and Move to Health. We will compare these two interventions and examine the effectiveness of a stepped care approach that sequences the two interventions based on a patient’s response. The results of this project will provide critical information and strategies to provide holistic pain management in the Military Health System.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Babies with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), a genetic disorder resulting in absence of T lymphocytes, die of infection by 2 years of age unless treatment with blood or bone marrow transplant is performed. This study will test whether transplantation with a low dose chemotherapy regimen will normalize the immune system of patients with common genetic subtypes of SCID identified at birth safely and effectively, avoiding the toxicity of high dose regimens currently in use. Results of this study can set a new standard for treatment of infants with SCID identified at birth, such that in the future, all babies with this otherwise fatal disease may live normal lives.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The intersecting problems of high-impact chronic pain and the opioid overdose crisis continue to be major public health concerns that disproportionately impact veterans, and to address chronic pain and ineffective and potentially unsafe opioid use, interdisciplinary teams are recommended. While a biopsychosocial approach using non-pharmacological pain management strategies is becoming more common, an extension of this approach is the Whole Health Model of care, which promotes a whole-person approach emphasizing multiple determinants of health including the environment, emotional health, and social health, with a broader goal of overall well-being. In this proposal, we will evaluate the benefit of adding components of the Whole Health model, including Whole Health coaching to interdisciplinary pain care teams in a multisite pragmatic effectiveness-implementation hybrid type 2 trial, evaluating these approaches on the primary composite outcome of pain-related interference and opioid safety.

PHR: NARRATIVE As part of our proposal for a “Consortium for Translational Precision Health”, this K12 program seeks to train early-career faculty members in translational science, to help bring the benefits of scientific discoveries into clinical practice and the health of communities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL – PROJECT NARRATIVE Black, Latinx, and low-income Chinese populations in Chicago experience egregious cancer health inequities primarily as a result of inequities that arise because Social Determinants of Health (SDOH). The Advancing Cancer Control Equity Research Through Transformative Solutions in Patient Navigation (ACCERT PN) Center will develop community-engaged interventions, measures and methods for process and outcomes assessment, and researcher and community partner capacity and engagement centered around the theme of innovative multilevel Patient Navigation approaches and implementation science to address SDOH – including structural racism and discrimination, language accessibility, and health literacy – with the goal of mitigating cancer health inequities in Chicago’s Black, Latinx, and low-income Chinese communities. The ACCERT PN Center’s research program will be supported by an Administrative Core and a Research Methods, Measures, and Data Management Core. 3

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Maternal mental illness can adversely modify the developmental trajectory of the child and is a significant contributor to maternal mortality in the U.S. A significant portion of women can experience traumatic childbirth, and some will develop posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), although this condition remains underdiagnosed and undertreated. This study will define the course and predictors of maternal childbirth-related PTSD and its effects on the child and lay the foundation for preventive and holistic care for both mother and child.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NanoAffix Science, LLC Commercialization Readiness Pilot (CRP) Program project aims to continue the development of a handheld lead tester for accurate and low-cost onsite detection of total lead in drinking water by non-technical experts, based on the success of the Phase II project. The project will further NanoAffix’s mission to increase the accessibility of quantitative water quality monitoring with strategic development and refinement of the product. NanoAffix will continue product development to improve performance and ease of use, scale up manufacturing beyond pilot scale production, obtain product and method certifications from relevant organizations, and engage in market research and planning to better understand our target markets.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness globally. Prevalence is greater among Veterans than in the general population and is increasing dramatically. Women Veterans and blast injury survivors are particularly susceptible. Current treatments work well early, but often fail over time. Given the aging Veteran population, there is thus an urgent need to develop new treatment strategies for late-stage disease. We recently developed a drug, HIOC, to protect against loss of retina ganglion cells due to blast injury. These are the same cells whose death in glaucoma causes blindness. We propose to test whether HIOC protects retina cells and vision in mouse models of glaucoma. As we have done successfully with other drugs we brought to clinical trial, this project is designed to test critical in vivo responses and mechanisms of action that will provide preclinical data in support of our proposing ophthalmic clinical trials of HIOC, a potentially inexpensive and accessible treatment for Veterans suffering from a chronic disease that results in blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project, we will measure the clinical utility of an objective and quantitative eye-tracking assay collected on a standalone, mobile investigational device to accurately screen 9-month-old infants for autism spectrum disorder and other actionable developmental delays. We will recruit a large cohort of infants from primary care pediatric practices and follow them longitudinally for clinical ascertainment at outcome. Our goal is to develop a community-viable methodology for early ASD screening, thus affording at-risk and affected children with the opportunity to access, and benefit from, early intervention services during periods of maximal neuroplasticity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is prevalent among military Veterans and is more than just a psychological condition; PTSD has profound negative impacts on health, function, and quality of life. Older Veterans are the largest patient population served by the Veterans Health Administration (VHA), and many have lived with PTSD for 30+ years. Veterans with PTSD engage in low levels of physical activity and spend much of their time in sedentary activities, adding to their risk of physical disability. The benefits of exercise on mental health and physical well-being in older adults are well-substantiated, but the effects of exercise training on late-life PTSD symptoms is a new area of study. This study is designed to examine the effects of 6 months of supervised exercise training on PTSD symptoms and PTSD-related conditions (e.g., functional impairment, sleep) in older Veterans with chronic PTSD. This study speaks directly to VHA’s mission and emphasis on non- pharmacologic approaches to improve mental health and well-being of older Veterans with chronic PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cells adjust their protein degrading capacity to adapt to different forms of stress by upregulating, removing, or relocating proteasomes. As both the ability to degrade proteins and several of the regulatory factors have been implicated in human diseases, it is critical to obtain a molecular understanding of these processes. The proposed work will utilize the model organism S. cerevisiae, human cells, and in vitro assays to understand the molecular mechanisms that drive these conserved processes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal immunity and microbial experience shape fetal immune development. Mechanistic understanding of how normal microbial experiences are communicated to the developing fetus is limited by the common practice of raising animal models in artificially hygienic specific pathogen free conditions. This proposal uses an innovative microbial normalization model whereby female mice are exposed to diverse microbial communities through cohousing with pet store mice prior to conception and throughout gestation to gain critical insight into the effects of maternal microbial exposure on fetal immune development and the mechanisms by which microbial encounters are communicated between maternal and fetal immune systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Anorexia Nervosa (AN) is a serious and sometimes deadly psychiatric illness characterized by distortions in valuation for food that drive rigid and stereotyped food choices and lead to dangerously low body weight. We propose to examine the cognitive and neural mechanisms that underlie subjective food value construction that drive maladaptive food choices in AN using state-of-the-art cognitive neuroscience methods and computational modeling to determine how this process arises and how it can be biased to normalize decisions about what to eat. The proposed studies will develop a new pathway for understanding and treating the salient behavior of restrictive eating that contributes to the significant disease burden of Anorexia Nervosa.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Spinal cord injury (SCI) affects approximately 40,000 Veterans and leads to healthcare costs of $525,000 for the first year after SCI and $80,000 each year thereafter. This provides a strong justification to find treatments which help reduce the financial burden facing Veterans with SCI while also increasing their well-being. Skeletal muscle function and health are severely reduced after SCI and this is associated with negative health factors such as insulin resistance, inflammation and obesity. Protecting mitochondrial health after paralysis may be a way to preserve muscle health after SCI. There are no FDA-approved treatments to preserve mitochondrial health. Investigating whether the appearance of connexin hemichannels in muscle after SCI is linked to mitochondrial health may provide an avenue for future drug design. Testing current drugs for improving mitochondrial health, such as SS-31, can provide essential information regarding how best to improve the health of Veterans with SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Methane is a potent greenhouse gas that contributes significantly to global climate change, and strategies to curb atmospheric methane emissions are vital to mitigate its harmful impacts on human health. Archaea are the primary source and sink for methane in the environment, and cytochrome c proteins play an important role in methane metabolism across diverse archaeal species. Thus, investigating the molecular function of cytochrome c in the methane-metabolizing archaea will provide molecular insights into the mechanisms of methane production and consumption, which can then be used in the development of technologies to curb methane emissions.

PHR: Project Narrative Restoring binocular vision and responsiveness to complex, naturalistic stimuli in subjects afflicted with amblyopia is a recognized challenge. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Xu Lab will persist in its efforts to uncover novel mechanisms for intracellular transport and organelle biology through the continued development and application of next-generation super-resolution microscopy methods. Major topics include intraorganellar diffusion and pH dynamics, anomalous diffusion in the living cell, the structure and physical properties of the ER exit site, the integration of FIB-SEM and super-resolution microscopy for ultrathin organelles, and new methods to quantify protein charge states at the super-resolution level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The pediatric population poses unique challenges for developing diagnostic imaging techniques. I aim to develop and optimize an MRI method that is suitable for all ages, from infants to adults, that will enable physicians to effectively and reliably assess cardiac flow over a patient's lifetime. The technique will be used for evaluating and monitoring patients with congenital heart disease to better understand and manage their disease progression.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Large-scale protein conformational changes play a crucial role in the function of proteins; however, these processes are not well-understood at the molecular level. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The silent development and progression of neurologic morbidity, or neuromorbidity, among hospitalized, critically ill patients represents a newly recognized and emerging epidemic. Despite this, no standard clinical tool exists to identify patients at risk for neuromorbidity or for real-time neurologic monitoring, in stark contrast to the heart, kidney, liver, and many other organs. To fill this gap and transform the way clinicians detect and monitor for evolving brain injury, we propose to validate and deploy a bio-digital process for 24/7 point-of-care neurologic monitoring for early detection of neuromorbidity in critically ill patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sustained retention in HIV care is a critical determinant of viral suppression for the 26 million people living with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa, but many frequently transition in and out of care over time, potentially contributing to viremia, drug resistance, transmission, and overall morbidity and mortality. The proposed research seeks to 1) assess patient and healthcare worker needs and preferences for strategies to strengthen reengagement in HIV care and 2) use human centered design to develop and pilot a multicomponent strategy to optimize care delivery and support long-term engagement among patients returning to HIV care after loss to follow-up. This research agenda will lead to a full-scale cluster randomized trial to assess this reengagement strategy to improve long- term patient outcomes and prevent ongoing lost to follow-up in this high-risk patient population, a critical global public health priority.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glial cells play a crucial role in the pathological changes in both vascular dementia and Alzheimer’s disease. Dysfunction and/imbalance of microglial immunometabolism and phagocytosis contributes to cognitive decline. This study investigates role of Na/H exchanger in regulation of microglial phagocytosis and immunometabolism and its impact on post-stroke brain repair and cognitive function recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lymphatic malformations are congenital anomalies that can cause significant or life-threatening morbidity due to infiltration and compression of critical structures. Targeting Angiopoietin-2, a vital lymphatic growth factor, may have the potential to reverse the abnormal phenotype of lymphatic malformation endothelial cells and would have a substantial impact on the field given current therapeutic limitations. The goal of this project is to identify novel mechanisms underlying lymphatic malformation endothelial cell dysfunction which may provide suitable targets for the development of deliverable, molecular therapeutics for the treatment of lymphatic malformations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Stroke affects upwards of 800,000 Americans every year and has an enormous impact on the well-being of the American veteran population with 6,000 new stroke admissions every year. Many of these stroke survivors are living with walking disabilities. Gait problems result in inability to function independently, high risk of falls and poor quality of life. Unfortunately, current gait rehabilitation treatments are limited and many stroke survivors do not achieve full recovery. Therefore, it is critical to develop new approaches to enhance gait rehabilitation methods. We propose to evaluate a brain stimulation treatment called transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) that can be added to physical therapy. tDCS has been applied for arm rehabilitation after stroke with positive results, but gait-related investigations are lacking. We will test whether simultaneous tDCS and gait training produces greater improvement in walking abilities than gait training alone. Adjunct tDCS therapy may improve outcomes, and reduce cost of both rehabilitation and post-stroke care. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The biological functions of proteins and nucleic acids is a result of both their three-dimensional structure and their conformational dynamics. In this work, computer simulations are utilized to explore and quantify these dynamic properties, as well as how they are linked to the function and regulation of biomolecular complexes. Specific projects will provide a basis for how dynamics affect DNA condensation and gene expression in chromatin fibers, the molecular mechanisms of heme extraction by Gram-positive bacteria, how synthetic peptide-mimics interact with the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, and how experimental small angle X-ray scattering experiments can be interpreted to better understand the structure/function/dynamics relationship in diverse biomolecular complexes.

PROJECT_TITLE: Probing the Structure/Function/Dynamics Relationship in Biomolecular Complexes with Multiscale Computational Techniques

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed multi-site cluster randomized controlled trial will use a hybrid-type 2 implementation- effectiveness design to evaluate the effectiveness and implementation outcomes of two low-cost pragmatic interventions of different intensities to increase prescribing of recommended short antibiotic durations (5 days) for acute otitis media for children 2 years of age and older. Mixed-methods will be used to compare a High- intensity intervention comprised of provider education, electronic health record (EHR) changes, and individualized provider audit and feedback with peer comparison to a Low-intensity intervention comprised of provider education and EHR changes.

PROJECT_TITLE: RELAX: Reducing Length of Antibiotics For Children With Ear Infections

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Constructing a Community of Teen Health Science Leaders (THSL) will build teens’ knowledge and understanding of cutting-edge NIH-funded research that underlies the health recommendations on topics that are highly relevant to adolescents. The program will provide high school students with the evidence-based rationale for making health positive decisions and promoting better health in both the short and long term. THSL will recruit and work intensively with teens from backgrounds underrepresented in the biomedical sciences, developing these students as teen health science leaders in their community with the goal of increasing these students’ belonging in science, ultimately increasing their interest in and persistence to careers in the health sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteonecrosis of the femoral head is a prevalent skeletal complication of sickle cell disease that causes severe chronic pain and significant disability. Low bone density, another prevalent skeletal manifestation of sickle cell disease, co-occurs with osteonecrosis and may further exacerbate chronic sickle cell pain. Repurposing alendronate, an inexpensive oral drug that inhibits bone resorption and is FDA-approved for treatment of osteoporosis (or severe low bone density), as a non-opioid treatment of femoral head osteonecrosis may alleviate pain, increase mobility and improve the health-related quality of life of adults living with sickle cell disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to public health. Gene regulation is largely defined by the interactions between different epigenetic marks under the genetic context within the cells. To understand the gene regulation in heterogeneous tissues, we propose to develop several computational methods and experimental assays in single-cell multi-omics. My long-term goal is to understand gene regulation from genetic variations to phenotypic variations, which will eventually pave the road for the discovery of drug targets and early intervention strategy for the different complex diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Each year, ~200,000 newborns worldwide, 80-85% of whom require surgical intervention, are afflicted with congenital conditions that cause impaired growth of the skull or mandible, leading to abnormalities that affect breathing, hearing, speech, visual function, neurologic development, and mastication. Distraction osteogenesis (DO) is a widely recognized treatment modality for craniofacial abnormalities that harnesses the body’s natural ability to regenerate bone in order to correct skeletal deficiencies and defects. While surgeons have shown the utility of DO for restoring functional discrepancies in patients born with craniofacial differences, the technique has not been widely adopted due to numerous limitations of current DO systems stemming from their semi- buried design and burdensome reliance on caregivers to follow precise treatment protocols. The Ostiio distraction system addresses many of these issues as the first fully subcutaneous, contactless DO system for the CMF skeleton, thereby markedly reducing potential for infection, scarring, and manipulation noncompliance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: This Center of Research Translation is focused on understanding the autoimmune disease, systemic sclerosis (SSc) and to better understand the cellular and molecular processes driving this disease when it affects the skin and lungs. Lung complications of SSc are particularly lethal, but recent technological advances are providing new opportunities for understanding the pathologic processes directly from human diseased skin and lung tissues by examining the molecular alterations associated with disease cell-by-cell. Metabolic changes in cells have also recently become better understood to lead to disease and will be investigated in circulating cells known as platelets, as well as through a novel imaging approach. Thus, this Center proposes to better understand the pathogenic pathways driving SSc skin and lung disease through translational studies, identifying informative biomarkers and developing novel targeted therapeutics. The focus of each of the projects on different SSc clinical manifestations, mediators of disease, and drug inhibitors will provide a rich, highly collaborative environment for fundamental discovery within bridging project topics and core resources.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall As the US population becomes increasingly older and more diverse, the number of Americans with dementia is expected to rise substantially, particularly among those with concomitant vascular disease. The Clinical significance of INciDEntal white matter lEsions on MRI in a Diverse population with cognitive complaints (INDEED) proposes to comprehensively examine the impact of individual and combined MRI measures of white matter injury on cognitive performance among a diverse, non-demented, stroke free population with cognitive complaints over an extended period of observation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Artificial neural networks have contributed significantly to many areas of medical data science, but they have not been fully explored for 3D protein structure design tasks. This project builds on our existing efforts to develop generative neural network models and engages the challenging issues that face conventional design methods. For their significance in biotechnology and therapeutics today, antibodies provide a rich and diverse venue for developing and applying our cutting-edge protein design technology, and our goals are to achieve fully-automated, epitope-specific antibody design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Skin fibrosis in systemic sclerosis (SSc) leads to significant morbidity resulting from disfiguring, painful and itchy skin, and joint contractures. We propose to understand at a molecular level the roles different inflammatory and profibrotic cells pay in the skin of SSc patients at a single cell level. We anticipate that our findings will reveal novel insights into the pathways driving the scarring process, and motivate targeted drug development .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure is typically preceded by cardiomyocyte hypertrophy. Hypertrophy is regulated by a complex intracellular signaling network which is not targeted by current therapeutics. Computational modeling allows for the discovery and predicted efficacy of drugs that target cardiomyocyte hypertrophy to prevent heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bioelectrochemistry is currently an underused experimental tool that enables to study bioelectrochemical process that cannot be applied by other methods for studying the system's thermodynamic and kinetics. The proposed projects aim to bring new electrochemical techniques to the forefront of studying biological redox reaction. Ultimately, the research proposed is expected to (i) promote a deeper understanding of how single enzymes operate individually, and (iii) develop a new generation of biosensors, potentially stimulating the development of targeted approaches to rapid diagnosis of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sepsis is a global public health threat. Numerous clinical trials have failed to come out with new therapies. Sepsis is a prominent cause of organ dysfunction and failure in adults and children. Lower respiratory tract infections are a vital cause of septicemia/sepsis (aka pneumonia-derived sepsis). The goal of the project is to explore the innate immune mechanisms associated with pneumonia-derived sepsis in order establish new therapies to reduce multiple organ dysfunction and failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Hydrocephalus is a potentially debilitating neurological condition that primarily affects babies under a year of age and has traditionally been treated by inserting a shunt between the brain and the abdomen. A newer endoscopic procedure offers hope of shunt-free treatment that may reduce complications over a child's life, but it is not clear if the endoscopic procedure results in similar intellectual outcome as shunt. We propose, therefore, a randomized trial to compare intellectual outcome and brain structural integrity between these 2 treatments, to help families make the best treatment decision for their baby.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Seventy million Americans suffer from chronic sleep disturbances and are at a high risk of developing intestinal dysfunction, which can promote acute cardiovascular and cardiometabolic diseases. However, little is known about the fundamental biological molecular, and cellular mechanisms affecting the intestinal tract when sleep is low. This proposal will elucidate the impact of sleep loss on the intestinal tract's cellular composition and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative The proper development of vertebrates requires the deployment of morphogen signaling gradients and the ability of cells exposed to the morphogen to interpret different levels of signal. This proposal will identify mechanisms by which cells interpret the Bone Morphogenetic Protein (BMP) morphogen gradient, which when disrupted can lead to disorders such as cardiac defects, undifferentiated mesoderm, lack of germ cells, eye abnormalities, gastrointestinal diseases, Sjögren’s syndrome, and various cancers. By understanding how cells interpret levels of BMP signaling, my research will shed light on the mechanisms of BMP-derived diseases and congenital syndromes and provide important insight into how cells interpret other types of morphogen gradients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE The tobacco industry has historically manipulated nicotine in its products to increase their appeal and potential for addiction for the widest possible audience, including young people and non-users. They are now doing this with newer products, like e-cigarettes and oral nicotine pouches. Our center will study how these manipulations affect young people and adults, with the goal of helping the FDA develop regulations that will make these products less appealing to young people, including non-users, but not older adult smokers and smokeless tobacco users who may benefit from their use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research addresses a key public health problem, the need for feasible psychosocial interventions for people with chronic pain, that follow evidence-based guidelines and improve all aspects of physical function assessed by self- report, performance based and objective/ambulatory step count. Combining mind-body skills with walking aided by a Fitbit is feasible and has the potential to sustainably improve all aspects of physical and emotional function (whole person). This proposal follows IMMPACT and ICF criteria and directly addresses NCCIH's mission to apply rigorous scientific methods to the identification of complementary and integrative health interventions to improve management of chronic pain and the whole person.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: In this proposal, we aim to define how cells in the blood vessels in the lung from persons who suffer from systemic sclerosis communicate with each other and promote the development of disease in those blood vessels. In doing so, we will embark on a first-in-human study to define a new imaging technique for better detection of blood vessel disease in lungs. If successful, our work could shape the principles of how blood vessel disease in the lungs develops, offering much needed and more effective ways to detect and treat this deadly condition in systemic sclerosis.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As a public health response to the COVID-19 pandemic, telehealth was widely implemented, including in pediatric primary care where it is highly likely to continue being a frequent mode of care after the pandemic. However, telehealth changes the communication and structure of healthcare interactions which may impact shared decision making and health outcomes for children with chronic conditions. Having an in-depth understanding of the impact of telehealth on shared decision making and health outcomes will position us to develop targeted interventions aimed at ensuring the use of telehealth does not increase health disparities, particularly for the large number of inner-city and minority children with chronic conditions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Comparing Family Decision Making Engagement in Telehealth versus In-person Primary Care for Children with Chronic Conditions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) is a rare genetic disorder that causes progressive extrapyramidal dysfunction and dementia and characterized by iron deposition in the brain. The disease is caused by autosomal recessive mutations in the PANK2 gene, which encodes the enzyme pantothenate kinase, responsible for the metabolism of vitamin B5 (pantothenate). Herein, we propose biochemical, cell biological and mouse studies to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a novel class of molecules for the treatment of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  One of the core questions in biology is how the genetic alteration in a cell translates into organ-level phenotype, especially for the phenotypes affecting human health. We propose to develop a multiscale, integrative imaging platform that probes organ-scale phenotype, subcellular phenotype, and single-cell genotype in the same tissue by innovating appropriate chemical and imaging tools. The new platform will help researchers identify the molecular basis of structural and functional abnormalities in diseased tissues and study how a focal point of abnormality affects nearby cells and propagates.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT SHORT NARRATIVE The purpose of the ILAR Roundtable is to foster communication and problem solving among the many different constituencies with strong interests in the use and welfare of laboratory animals in research and testing, including, government agencies, pharmaceutical and consumer product corporations, vendors, animal advocacy groups, professional societies, and academic institutions , including scientists and veterinarians. The objectives of all workshops organized by the ILAR Roundtable are to: 1 ) provide a forum in which to stimulate open dialogue, exchange information and foster communication ; 2) promote collaboration among a wide range of entities interested in the development of cutting edge laboratory animal research topics; and 3) facilitate discussion on more effective, efficient and humane use of animals and use of animal alternatives in biomedical research.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Workshops of the National Academies Roundtable on Science and Welfare in Laboratory Animal Use (ILAR Roundtable)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) regenerate all blood and immune cells throughout life, but their function declines with age. This proposed fellowship will investigate the role of Heat shock factor 1 and Transglutaminase 2 in promoting protein homeostasis and HSC fitness during aging. Uncovering mechanisms that promote HSC function and regenerative capacity is critical for identifying therapeutic targets that can increase HSC fitness and immune function during aging, a critical need for an increasingly older population.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants with injuries concerning for abuse (e.g., extremity fracture) can have additional important injuries (e.g., brain injuries, certain additional fractures) that are clinically occult and only revealed with imaging. While neuroimaging can identify clinically occult head injuries from abusive head trauma, clinicians must weigh the neuroimaging-associated risks of sedation or radiation with the risks of missing a clinically or forensically important injury, while having little clinical guidance to inform their decisions. The proposed research is designed to benefit an AHRQ priority pediatric population through development of a clinical decision rule (CDR) that identifies which well-appearing infants undergoing abuse evaluations are at high risk of intracranial injury from abusive head trauma and warrant neuroimaging.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Optimizing targeted, equitable use of neuroimaging in cases of suspected infant physical abuse

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: GM/CA@APS is a national user facility that provides cutting-edge technologies for visualizing the 3D structures of protein and DNA molecules in atomic detail. Knowledge of 3D structures is essential to understanding how proteins and DNA perform their normal functions in living systems, how mutations in some proteins cause cancer progression, how drugs bind to their target proteins, how receptor proteins respond to external stimuli and transmit information from outside to inside the cell, how pathogens evade detection by our immune system, and how our proteins detect infection by pathogens. At the facility, an extremely intense, focused X-ray beam is scattered from proteins packed in a crystal. The X-ray scattering is measured and used to solve 3D structures by the method of X-ray crystallography. Located at the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory, GM/CA provides the sophisticated instrumentation and highly automated software necessary for recording and analyzing the scattering data used in 3D structure determination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While the scaffolding protein Caveolin-1 has been implicated in disease progression in cancer, its precise role remains controversial. This proposal aims to leverage innovations in imaging, computational analysis, and zebrafish disease models to test the mechanosensory role of Caveolin-1 as a putative plasticity factor in Ewing Sarcoma, an aggressive pediatric bone and soft-tissue cancer. The anticipated results will reveal a mechanism of non-genetic cellular adaptation to diverse microenvironmental cues, providing unique insight into the drivers of metastasis and drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a disease characterized by pulmonary vascular remodeling, impaired cardiac function, respiratory muscle weakness, and exercise intolerance; however, mechanisms underlying vascular dysfunction in respiratory and cardiac muscle with PH have never been determined. Therefore, using a unique combination of techniques (fluorescent microspheres, isolated blood vessel preparation, contractility measures), the current proposal will determine the distribution of diaphragm blood flow and diaphragm and coronary vasomotor function in PH rats with an emphasis on the therapeutic efficacy of pharmacological (Nrf2 activator) and exercise treatments to improve vascular and contractile function. The proposed experiments will enhance the knowledge of PH pathogenesis which may provide the foundation for development of therapeutic targets designed to improve blood flow regulation, survival, and quality of life in PH patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Epidemiologic studies identify that obesity and the related metabolic syndrome nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) are major risk factors of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The goal of this proposal is to investigate how the nuclear receptor CAR regulates tumor lipid synthesis to promote HCC, and determine whether simultaneously blocking CAR and lipid uptake is therapeutically effective in obesity related HCC. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The initiation of DNA replication is tightly regulated to maintain genome integrity, yet the molecular mechanisms that underlie this fundamental process are poorly understood, especially in multicellular organisms. Key proteins involved in replication initiation are poorly conserved between yeast and humans, and mutations in these proteins cause genetic diseases. This project will employ a powerful single-molecule approach that we developed to dissect the mechanism of replication initiation, delineate the exact roles of replication initiation proteins, and understand why mutations in these proteins cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial Fibrillation (AF) is the most common type of cardiac arrhythmia, affecting over 40 million people globally. Small conductance calcium-activated potassium channels (SK channels) retain a unique role in the integration of the intracellular Ca2+ and membrane potentials within the heart. Our approaches integrating patch-clamp, TIRF microscopy, super-resolution immunofluorescence imaging, optogenetics and genetic manipulations may elucidate the mechanism of SK2 channels regulation by PIP2, and present a potential, novel therapeutic target for atrial arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite huge progress in understanding the biological function of every human gene, significant hurdles remain, among them to establish a systematic catalogue of cellular phenotypes associated with each gene. The pilot phase of the Molecular and Cellular Phenotypes of Null Alleles in Cells (MorPhiC) program will study the feasibility, scalability, required scope, and utility of such a catalogue. Our proposed Data Resource and Administrative Coordinating Center (DRACC) will develop and deploy infrastructure and tools to provide the highest quality MorPhiC data resource, analyze, annotate, and disseminate MorPhiC data, integrating external data & information, and serve as an administrative and coordination center.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This study seeks to link a group of hospitals to measure and share the rates of diagnostic errors, to understand underlying causes of diagnostic errors, and develop ways that hospitals, clinicians, and patients can work together to avoid diagnostic errors and harms due to those errors. We will test how data sharing and collaboration improve diagnostic processes and develop approaches which can be sustained into the future. Our approach represents a novel application of rigorous outcome adjudication to the problem of inpatient diagnostic errors using a learning health system model.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Achieving Diagnostic Excellence through Prevention and Teamwork (ADEPT)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is a potentially blinding secondary glaucoma characterized by anterior segment neovascularization, leading to elevated intraocular pressure and poor visual prognosis. The objective of this proposal is to investigate the role of Angiopoietin-like 4/Neuropilins, alone or in combination with VEGFs, as regulators of iris/angle neovascularization. The ultimate goal of our investigations is to design better therapeutic modalities for the prevention and treatment of NVG.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL The Universities, Hospitals and Community Organizations in Rhode Island are well positioned to bridge the gaps between the worlds of clinical and basic science. Using the targeted resources of an IDeA-CTR Award, the Brown Institute for Translational Sciences, and a statewide consortium of collaborators, hospitals, universities, non-profit organizations and government agencies, will draw on the resources already developed in the NIH Institutional Development Award (IDeA) programs (core labs and faculty development programs) to enhance the Advance Clinical and Translational Research Program’s (Advance-CTR) ability to support clinical and translational research. We will serve as a bench-to-bedside research network and career development umbrella for the investigator community in affiliated institutions. In so doing, we will enhance patient-centered research and accelerate discoveries and health innovations to benefit our communities and to serve our State.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanisms underlying the loss and recovery of consciousness from general anesthesia remain poorly understood. This project aims to use human cerebral organoids, which are brain-like structures derived from human pluripotent stem cells, to isolate the molecular mechanisms that cause induction and emergence from anesthesia. Completion of this project may not only aid in the development of methods aimed at actively inducing recovery of consciousness from anesthesia, but may also lay the foundation for using human cerebral organoids in the search for interventions for pathological states of unconsciousness, such as coma and vegetative states, for which there currently no treatments or animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE - OVERALL This P01 aims to improve therapy for Pancreatic cancer, one of the most lethal of cancers, and nonmelanoma skin cancer, the most ubiquitous cancer in the United States. We use visible light activation to not only destroy the cancer itself, but also to increase the efficacy of other treatments such as chemotherapy and immunotherapy while minimizing the toxicity associated with the latter. Our overall strategy includes two clinical trials (in Projects 1 and 2), and preclinical studies (Project 3) which together will ultimately allow patient customized combination treatments that will benefit even those patients whose disease has stopped responding to any of the conventional treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Graft injury is unavoidable during heart transplant procedures, where surgical procedures and graft ischemia times will generate potent immune responses that may contribute to the development of immunosuppressant- resistant fibrosis and vasculopathy leading to chronic rejection. This proposal will study how macrophage recognition of allogeneic MHCI components within the graft confounds their reparative functions. I will also define novel macrophage allorecognition pathways and target them to evaluate if this blocks chronic rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this proposed project is to develop a multivalent "mosaic" vaccine, termed SNAP-AD, targeting multiple epitopes of Aβ and tau simultaneously with a novel spontaneous nanoliposome antigen particle (SNAP) vaccine system and to investigate its therapeutic effects for treating Alzheimer’s disease (AD) in a transgenic mouse model. A positive outcome of this project would potentially lead to a novel vaccine for the treatment of AD and AD-related dementia, which would have an immense impact on the health of our society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Stroke-related disability - including cognitive impairment and dementia - is a public health epidemic and a key national research priority in the United States. Because of its disproportionately high impact on health disparity populations, understanding the mechanisms of post-stroke cognitive decline is a matter of equitable health care delivery. DISCOVERY, the proposed collaborative nationwide network of clinical sites with access to diverse acute stroke US populations has the expertise, experience and capacity to execute a large prospective study that will unravel the mechanisms of post-stroke cognitive disability, early recovery after stroke, and potential targets for personalized prevention, intervention, and rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain function is built atop connections made between neurons. The proposed Center for Mesoscale Connectomics will use multiple imaging and neuroanatomical methods across nonhuman primates and humans to build an accurate, fine-grained wiring diagram of the brain. We will start with connections between the frontal and parietal lobes, with the eventual goal of mapping connections across the whole brain.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Bacterial respiratory tract infections are the most common reason for hospitalization in children with tracheostomy (an artificial airway placed in the neck that allows children to breathe), yet there is very limited evidence available to help prevent, diagnose or treat this condition. This AHRQ R01 project will evaluate 1500 hospitalizations in children hospitalized at one of five freestanding children's hospitals to determine what factors influence clinicians to diagnose and treat suspected bacterial tracheostomy-associated infections, such as pneumonia, with antibiotics. Through our multicenter prospective study, we expect to identify strategies to reduce antibiotic exposure and hospitalizations in this vulnerable patient population that account for increased health care utilization.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Diagnosis and management of pediatric tracheostomy-associated infections

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pathogenic collagen-producing fibroblasts accumulate and persist at sites of fibrosis in progressive silica- associated pulmonary fibrosis. We hypothesize that targeted removal of collagen1a1-expressing fibroblasts through genetic ablation or sensitization to apoptosis after Bcl-2 knockdown will reduce fibrosis in a silica-induced progressive fibrosis mouse model. The results of our studies should provide insight into the dependence of fibrosis progression on Col1a1-expressing fibroblasts and development of novel therapeutic strategies to stop fibrosis progression that will improve the outcomes for patients with silica-induced fibrotic lung disease; as there are currently no FDA approved therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Postural instability and gait disturbances are important factors contributing to decreased mobility, falls and reduced quality of life in people with Parkinson’s disease, yet the mechanisms contributing to these motor signs are poorly understood and current treatments are often insufficiently effective. This project will use transcranial magnetic stimulation, deep brain stimulation (DBS) and patient-specific computational models of DBS, in conjunction with quantitative measures of motor function to explore the hypothesis that neuronal pathways projecting to the extensor muscles of the ankle are preferentially affected in PD in comparison to ankle flexors, and these abnormalities contribute to deficits in gait. These experiments will increase our understanding of the impact of disease and DBS on leg muscle function in PD which could lead to refinement and/or development of therapies to improve postural stability and gait in people with PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – Project 1 This project will advance new therapeutic approaches that use photodynamic therapy (PDT), 5-fluorouracil, and Vitamin D as immune-priming agents, with subsequent addition of immune checkpoint inhibition (ICI) for the treatment of advanced squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and basal cell carcinoma (BCC), which together represent the most common of all human cancers. Preclinical experiments in mouse models, and clinical studies in patients with SCC and BCC, will be done with the aid of advanced optical fluorescence techniques provided by Core B and Core C to detect changes in initial photosensitizer levels and immune cell recruitment post-PDT. These experiments will allow us to determine the precise timing of increased checkpoint molecule expression and recruitment of specific populations of immune cells into tumors after PDT treatment, thereby establishing a rationale and a therapeutic window for designing a new combination treatment regimen that will benefit patients by improving treatment outcomes for advanced SCC and BCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The persistence of chronic pulmonary sequelae following acute respiratory viral diseases such as COVID-19 is developing into a significant public health burden, however the mechanisms underlying this condition remain unknown. Aged individuals in particular, are at increased risk of adverse long-term outcomes after severe viral pneumonia. The goal of these studies is to understand how persistent immune dysfunction post infection, a consistent feature in aged individuals, contributes to impaired alveolar regeneration and dysplastic lung repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) are new cancer immunotherapy agents that are effective in treating some advanced and metastatic cancers and improve the likelihood of patients living with the disease. Since we still know little about their survivorship needs, we aim to characterize the long-term survival and physical and psychosocial symptom trajectories of patients treated with ICIs for advanced and metastatic cancer. Our findings are expected to provide much-needed data that can inform new evidence-based intervention strategies to optimize cancer survivorship care for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – Project 2 Pancreatic cancer is a deadly disease that is very resistant to chemotherapy, partly because the tumor is encased in a fibrous shell that helps the cancer disguise itself from the body's immune system. The purpose of this project is to create an immunologically-based treatment that first damages the primary pancreatic tumor using a light activated drug that disrupt the fibrous shell (allowing chemotherapeutic treatments to reach the cancer), and also causes the tumor to release damage signals that permit the patients' own immune system to identify and attack the cancer. This research could help immune-activating drugs (currently ineffective on their own) to become more effective for treating pancreatic cancer, both the primary lesions as well as distant metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardiac arrhythmia and a major cause of stroke. AF causes significant morbidity and mortality, and its prevalence is rising dramatically. We aim to leverage innovative computational tools and high-quality, extensive data (1.6 m patients, augmented with social determinants of health information) to improve the accuracy and equitably of stroke risk prediction. The work proposed here will use machine learning and artificial intelligence to identify novel clinical risk factors and social determinants of heath that impact AF risk and outcomes. This will provide better, more personalized, and equitable stroke risk stratification and prevention for patients with AF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Pancreatic cancer is a devastating disease with poor response to most therapies, including immunotherapy, which is the new hope for cancer management. Therefore, we propose a new treatment approach to overcome the major obstacle of non-responsiveness of pancreatic cancers to immunotherapy, by transforming non- responding, immunologically “cold” tumors, to “hot” responsive ones using red light activation of a drug already FDA approved with no serious reported toxicities. Combined with a novel real-time, high-resolution imaging system this strategy is expected to provide the ideal timing of immunotherapy drugs thus enhancing efficacy, reducing toxicities and expanding the immunotherapy eligible pancreatic cancer patient population (presently only 1-3%).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Autophagy is an important cell biological mechanism that cells use to restore energy supplies at time of starvation and to rid themselves of damaging content such as aggregated proteins, dysfunctional mitochondria or invading bacteria. Interruption of autophagy causes neuronal degeneration of neurons and photoreceptor cell dysfunction. The specific aims described in this proposal will explore the mechanisms boosting starvation-independent autophagy to address cellular challenges without the damage that can result from excessive autophagy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of disability in the United States. It is even more common in Veterans than the general population, is the primary source of disability in combat-wounded veterans, and is the most common reason for a service member to be removed from active duty. Developing treatments that delay or reverse the joint damage of osteoarthritis has been difficult partly because the disease is not evident on x-rays until it is far advanced and likely not reversible. Microphones can be used to measure noise created by a damaged joint and are able to identify a healthy knee from one with disease. The goal of our project is to build a portable knee brace with an attached microphone that will measure noise from the knee in common clinical settings. This allow prompt identification of Veterans with early osteoarthritis and allow for therapies that prolong joint lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Administrative CORE A- Narrative Core A is mandated for all P01s and is an essential element of the application which ensures maximal integration and utilization of diverse skills and resources to develop new treatments for cancers that are a burden to society in different ways yet allowing synergistic skills to come regardless of the geographic location of individuals. The limited budget available (<$100K) make it incumbent for the core to leverage essential services that are not directly funded by the P01 and offered by the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) or Harvard Medical School (HMS) but are crucial to the success of the Program. Although the Core was noted for being highly integrated, it continues to focus on enhancing this along with a succession plan for future planning, so that at the end, we have a more economical approach to healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Core B interacts with each of the Program Projects to provide biological models, multiplexed in vivo optical biopsy, molecular pathology, and biostatistics support that are essential for the Projects to be successful in optimizing photodynamic priming of cancer immunotherapy to suppress the primary tumor (local control) as well as to shrink distal metastatic tumors while reducing costs and lowering the toxic side-effects of immune checkpoint inhibitors. The Core integrates newly developed biological models of the tumor immune microenvironment of skin and pancreatic cancer with novel tools and approaches for in vivo imaging, ex vivo microscopy, and ex vivo biochemical assays to enable therapeutic discovery and precise timing for administration of immune checkpoint inhibitors. Because the in vivo imaging technologies are conducive to integration with clinical endoscopy, the long-term impact of Core B is not only to stimulate and to support new research but also there is real potential to produce clinical translation of these precision medicine approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative We aim to dramatically improve the spatial resolution of an innovative medical imaging technique called Magnetic Particle Imaging (MPI), which has already shown extraordinary promise for noninvasive, rapid, and zero-radiation scans of targeted tracers with ideal contrast and SNR. The PI’s lab at UC Berkeley has pioneered MPI scanner design, MPI fast image reconstruction algorithms, and biomedical appli- cations like tracking CAR-T therapies, early detection of GI bleeds, cancers, strokes and pulmonary embolisms. In a Bioengineering Partnership with the MPI Industry leader, Magnetic Insight, three re- search groups at UC Berkeley plan to improve MPI’s spatial resolution 10-fold in each dimension, which will finally enable the first human clinical MPI scanners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to adapt ongoing behaviors in dynamic environments is impaired across many neuropsychiatric disorders. The lateral habenula performs computations that compare past outcomes to current outcomes in order to drive reward-guided decision making. The proposed project will inform a richer, cell type-specific model of how lateral habenula neuronal subpopulations monitor past outcomes to guide flexible behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cincinnati Children's (CCHMC) proposes to join eMERGE IV by enrolling of local Cincinnati African-American newborn babies and their mothers with available fathers and brothers and sisters to develop predictions of their risk for Asthma, Atopic Dermatitis, Obesity, Hypercholesterolemia, Hypertension, Prematurity, and Breast Cancer (along with 15 disorders chosen by the eMERGE IV Network and disorders chosen by CCHMC Faculty) using genetic variation, environmental factors, and family history. We will test whether knowledge of having a higher genetic risk for these disorders will motivate closer adherence to health recommendations made to reduce disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative ACTA2 Multisystemic Smooth Muscle Dysfunction Syndrome is an ultra-rare disease with less than 50 known cases worldwide; it is caused by a specific genetic mutation in the ACTA2 gene that affects smooth muscle cells. Smooth muscle cells are found in many different organs in the body including the arteries, the gut, the eye, the bladder, and the intestines; some mutations can cause brain infarcts (strokes) and rupture of large artery and death in childhood. In this study we use a combination of cell and animal modeling studies to determine if we can improve the disorder through gene therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) is a cancer with significant morbidity and mortality, and limited treatment options. In this study, we will examine how dietary restriction of serine impacts tumor growth, using OSCC cells and an OSCC mouse model. This research will give us better insight into the development of OSCC and may one day lead to more effective therapeutic options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our brains rely both on the segmentation of experience into distinct memories and on the integration of those episodic memories across space and time to inform our perception of the world and help us make decisions. Event boundaries are conceptual or physical boundaries such as reward locations or environment changes that can segment experience into distinct episodes. This project proposes a novel experimental design and set of analyses focused on illuminating how the hippocampus forms neural representations of segmented episodes through place cells, the firing of place-cell sequences during theta oscillations (“theta sequences”), and multi-neuronal replays during sharp-wave ripples, and how these representations and patterns are altered upon introduction of new event boundaries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current standard of care for ventral hernia repair does not include objective measures of function or post- operative physical therapy, which may improve patient quality of life. This mentored training plan will use data from a CMS Qualified Clinical Data Registry and an NIH/NIDDK funded registry-based clinical trial (R01DK131207) to understand the complex relationships between patient- and surgical-characteristics as they relate to post-operative function. Findings from this fellowship will provide (1) robust predictive models to understand characteristics of patients who have a good or poor self-reported quality of life 1 year after ventral hernia repair and (2) foundational evidence in understanding treatment response to physical therapy using objective measures of function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Heart failure is a syndrome of major public health significance that contributes to the death of about 1 in 8 Americans. Despite a range of existing therapies, the mortality rate for patients with heart failure is high, with nearly 50% of patients dying within 5 years of a diagnosis. In this application, we aim to develop a new therapy for heart failure based upon selectively targeting the anchoring of RSK3 to the scaffold protein mAKAPβ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Anti-seizure medications are commonly prescribed to older adults after traumatic brain injury, but these drugs may not be necessary, or the harms could outweigh the benefits particularly among those with dementia. There is limited rigorous evidence guiding when and how physicians should prescribe this type of treatment. This project will use the real-world experience of millions of Medicare beneficiaries to generate this evidence and inform both policy and future clinical decisions.

PHR: We seek to continue Wake Forest NeuroNEXT as a high performing NeuroNEXT Network (NN) Clinical Site that has rapidly opened, enrolled, and contributed to NN trials. Since our initial award in 2018, Wake Forest Baptist Health entered into a strategic partnership with Atrium health to expand our already diverse catchment to include 40 hospitals, 1,200 care locations, and >7 million patients. We will continue to (1) rapidly rollout trials, (2) expand access to diverse populations in the southeast United States, (3) contribute to improved trial efficiency through the network, and (4) train the next generation of clinical trialists in adult & pediatric neurology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Single cell genomics data have become indispensable tools in studying physiological and pathological processes, and a grant challenge is to extract quantitative mechanistic information from the snapshot data. The research will provide a quantitative framework for extracting mechanistic information from single cell data that can guide on controlling cellular processes for biomedical purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The broad, long-term goal of this project is to develop a pritelivir intravaginal ring (IVR) for the treatment and pre-exposure prophylaxis of genital herpes, a common problem that affects millions of Americans. On average, recurrences occur 4 times a year, and infection is life-long. Pritelivir is a promising α-helicase inhibitor that has proved superior to existing therapies in Phase 2 clinical testing, but whose clinical development as a systemic therapy has been slowed due to observed unexplained systemic toxicity in primates. Local therapy is therefore of special interest. Using our proprietary Versa technology platform, we have developed an intravaginal ring (IVR) formulation of pritelivir. The goal of this Phase IIB SBIR proposal is to follow the FDA-instructed nonclinical activities and achieve an Investigational New Drug (IND) allowance in pursuit of clinical testing of our pritelivir IVR product in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The conversion of a fertilized egg into a fully developed human comprised of many different cell is orchestrated by genes acting through complex networks. Despite genetic variations between different individuals, these networks generally lead to a faithfully formed human. We propose to reveal how such gene networks operate faithfully in individuals with varying genetic makeups and how non-genetic heritable (epigenetic) effects influence successful outcomes from these developmental gene networks. The findings from this research may lead to a better understanding of the events that lead to accurate embryo development and how genetic and epigenetic alterations can disrupt them, resulting in birth defects. They will also help to illuminate the relationship between an individual's genetics, their propensity for medical difficulties, and their responsiveness to drugs, thereby contributing to advances in precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States. About 875,000 Americans die from heart disease each year, of which 50-60% deaths are caused by coronary artery disease which can further develop into heart failure and scarring. We discovered a specific non-coding RNA (lnc RNA TARID) in the exosomes that play an essential role in cardiac repair. In this grant proposal we will use lipid nanoparticles to deliver this non-coding RNA to the injured heart and study safety, efficacy, and mechanism in both small and large animal models.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Approximately 40% of Veterans have obesity and are at increased risk for cardiometabolic disease. Intensive lifestyle-based weight management programs can lead to clinically significant (≥5%) weight loss. The VA’s MOVE! program is effective for promoting weight loss and behavior change for those who attend. Unfortunately, MOVE! has low enrollment and high attrition due to several obstacles including low motivation. Mental Contrasting with Implementation Intentions (MCII) is an innovative strategy developed over 20 years of research that uses imagery to increase motivation for behavior change. MCII can be implemented in primary care settings using an easy to teach technique called “WOOP” (Wish, Outcome, Obstacle, Plan) that Veterans then use regularly on their own with the help of paper-based tools or the WOOP app. We will evaluate the efficacy and implementation of MCII when combined with telephone-delivered MOVE! vs. telephone-delivered MOVE! alone to enhance weight management outcomes for Veterans in primary care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The swallowing muscles are prone to decreased strength and function as part of the natural aging process which can lead to difficulty swallowing, malnutrition, and frailty. Exercise and nutrition are powerful stimulators of muscular change. The proposed research will investigate the effectiveness of a proactive regimen of swallowing exercises (with or without daily protein supplement drinks) to improve the composition, force, and physiology of the swallowing muscles and explore the relationship to overall health and physical function in community-dwelling older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The selective routing of retinal ganglion cell (RGC) axons to the correct side of the brain by the cells of the optic chiasm is required for normal vision. Here we investigate how β2 laminins, an essential component of the extracellular matrix sheet surrounding the brain, controls the organization of the cells in the optic chiasm and thereby the selective routing of RGC axons. The findings from this project will lead to new insights into the regulation of selective axon routing and the development of rational strategies for RGC axon regeneration and brain target selection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal addresses the critical need for robust computational methods and tools for mass spectrometry (MS)-based proteomics data. We are focusing on three key areas of biological research: MS-based characterization of “interactomes”, post-translational modifications (PTMs), and single-cell proteomics. We will develop new functionalities and algorithms in our interactome analysis resources, advance comprehensive PTM profiling strategies, and improve the sensitivity and accuracy of protein quantification in single-cell data. We will continue providing our widely used computational tools and data resources to the research community.

PHR: Project Narrative Our study will use a multi-disciplinary approach to provide critical, new information about the impacts of airborne fine particle and metal exposures on dementia-associated neuropathology (DAN) and incident dementia (including Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), microvascular brain injury (μVBI), and Lewy body disease (LBD)), and the pathways through which they do so. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to improve the ability of non-specialty urgent and emergent care providers to provide patients with eye examinations on site. Leveraging innovative imaging technologies developed by our laboratories and modified specifically to be used without on site personnel, we expect to make modern ocular imaging techniques more readily available where the patients are. This provides the potential to improve eye diagnostics at the point of care in a physically distanced manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Localized pancreatic cancers (PC) have a high risk of recurrence and are treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy which improves cure rates though identifying early resistance during NAC remains a clinical challenge. This project utilizes advances in single cell transcriptomics, highly multiplexed imaging and ctDNA technologies, paired with large clinically annotated PC biospecimen repositories to develop methods for assessing response and identifying resistance to neoadjuvant therapies used in localized PC. I anticipate that this work will nominate novel biomarkers for clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative condition that exhibits a marked age- dependence. Levels of NAD+ decline in animals and humans as a function of age, and restoring NAD+ levels has been shown to slow or prevent deficits seen in pre-clinical models of AD. Here, we describe a comprehensive program to develop a brain penetrant, small molecule that potently stimulates the rate-limiting enzyme regulating NAD+ levels in the brain, as a treatment for late onset AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with chronic kidney disease (CKD) pose unique challenges to the health care system, which must address not only the primary kidney disorder, but the many extrarenal manifestations which include social function and emotional wellbeing, risk for cardiovascular disease and metabolic bone disease and a high mortality rate in young adulthood. The CKiD study is a landmark cohort study of children with CKD, having rallied more than 50 pediatric nephrology centers across the US and Canada to recruit and study 1100 children with mild to moderate CKD. From 2023 to 2028, the Clinical Coordinating Centers will continue to coordinate study visits with the following long term goals: enhance the current cohort to collect additional data as the new and existing cohorts become young adults; define how risk factors for GFR decline, and early cardiovascular abnormalities detected during childhood ultimately impact long-term health outcomes after transition to adulthood; examine the impact of risks developed during childhood CKD on outcomes in adulthood by linking CKiD data with external sources; and assess the social functioning and emotional well-being of children with CKD to understand their impact on subsequent clinical care and life course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: UM1 NARRATIVE The Colorado Clinical and Translational Sciences Institute (CCTSI) is a Partnership among University of Colorado Denver’s two campuses, University of Colorado Boulder, Colorado State University, five hospitals and multiple community organizations committed to translating discoveries into better, equitable public health and patient care for all. Through innovative programs and collaborations to advance clinical and translational science, the CCTSI will facilitate the performance of high impact research and the training of the next generation of clinical-translational researchers. Team science, reducing health disparities and being poised to respond to a public health emergency will be emphasized. Ongoing evaluation and quality improvement will assure maximum efficiency and impact of our programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sequence-based assays provide a powerful toolset for gaining insight into the function and disfunction of cancer cells. Unfortunately, the resulting data sets are a classic example of “big data” and experimental biologists are traditionally not trained to handle or analyze them. The goal of this R50 proposal is to provide Dr. Bartom’s expertise in both computation and biology to the cancer research programs of the Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center, and more specifically to the Quantitative Data Sciences Core (QDSC).
