IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hormones control important biological processes through proteins called nuclear receptors, which are targetted by ~16% of drugs used in the clinic. This proposal takes aim at making never seen observations of a model nuclear receptor named RORγT interacting with and manipulates chromatin. By incorporating novel biological contexts and using interdisciplinary structural biology techniques to study RORγT structure, function, and regulation, this work has the potential to open novel areas of investigation in NR biology, has broad implications to human health and physiology, and may also facilitate the development of chemical modulators with more efficacy and fewer side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Colon cancer is the fourth deadliest cancer with ~150,000 new cases and 53,000 deaths in the US in 2021. Colon cancers develop by selection of oncogenic mutations in stem cells of morphologically normal epithelium. This proposal seeks to identify the role of immune system in suppressing selection of mutated stem cells in the colon with the goal of developing treatment strategies to prevent colon cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE  Ten percent of Americans meet criteria for an alcohol use disorder, with rising levels of problematic drinking during the COVID-19 pandemic. Novel strategies, including leveraging telehealth, are needed to bring effective interventions to the millions of people in the US who experience problems with alcohol. We propose to investigate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of an incentive intervention called contingency management that will be delivered via telehealth using a novel alcohol biomarker called phosphatidylethanol (PEth), and we will also identify factors that predict long-term abstinence during a 12-month follow-up period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Huntington’s disease (HD) is an inherited, debilitating, and fatal neurodegenerative disease for which there is no effective treatment. HD is caused by a mutation in the huntingtin gene, which is essential for normal body and brain function, however, in patients with HD, the huntingtin protein is susceptible to misfolding that results in nerve cell dysfunction and cell death. Origami Therapeutics, Inc. has developed and will test and then select an orally available drug that lowers the levels of the toxic misfolded huntingtin protein, eliminating the cause of HD as a potential treatment to prevent HD progression, morbidity, and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Research in neuroscience is crucial for attacking the causes of neurological and mental health disorders. If the field of neuroscience is to continue its rapid advance, neuroscientists must use, understand, and develop new technologies, acquire and analyze ever larger data sets, and grapple more directly with the complexity of neurobiological systems. The primary goal of this training program is to train a new generation of interdisciplinary neuroscientists with strong quantitative skills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to elucidate the role of endothelial Activin signaling in age-related heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). This research plan is relevant to public health because it is expected to lead to advance our understanding of cardiovascular diseases in older adults, and develop potential novel therapeutics for age-related HFpEF, a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in older adults. Thus, it accomplishes the National Institute on Aging’s missions and initiatives by not only providing novel molecular and cellular mechanism in pathological aged mice, but also potential therapeutic advancements that can improve the longevity and functional capacity in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Hearing loss in infants is a “developmental emergency”, and early hearing detection, intervention, and hearing loss prevention are central to national strategies for ear and hearing care. Building on collaborations with the Technical Working Group for Ear and Hearing Care in Kenya’s Ministry of Health, we will optimize and test implementation outcomes for smartphone-based universal hearing screening for newborns and infants. Among infants with HIV exposure, a population of interest for hearing surveillance, we will deploy serial hearing screening coupled with simple smartphone-based detection of middle ear fluid and determine rates of otitis media with effusion, a modifiable risk factor for early hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While naloxone is an effective opioid overdose antidote, in many cases its short half-life is ineffective against synthetic opioids with longer half-lives, such as fentanyl, leading to a phenomenon called renarcotization (whereby an overdose patient revived with naloxone re-enters an overdose state from residual opioid in the body after the naloxone wears off). The objective of this project is to create a better pharmacokinetic profile for naloxone delivery that continuously maintains naloxone at therapeutic levels long enough to prevent renarcotization. This novel product will directly lead to saving lives of opioid overdose victims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adaptation of coronaviruses to human transmission and virulence present continuous threat to global health. SARS-CoV-2 and all other coronaviruses adapt primarily through variations in the conformationally dynamic and very large multidomain S glycoproteins that mediate virus-cell entry. As S protein complexity leaves the biological impacts of many such adaptative variations enigmatic, we propose to use diverse virus entry assays to elucidate mechanisms by which changes in the membrane fusion – inducing domains reset viral dynamics and cell entry properties in ways that may increase transmission or virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Linking the evolution of cognitive abilities to genetic differences between humans and nonhuman primates is challenging since it requires an understanding of how life experiences induce changes in brain activity and neuronal gene expression. We will use experimental methods in primary and stem cell-derived neuronal cultures to investigate how neuronal activity-responsive regulatory elements differ between humans and other primates, and we will create machine learning models to predict the location of these elements in the genome. Since many neurodevelopmental disorders are thought to involve disruptions in neuronal plasticity, understanding the molecular and cellular mechanisms of plasticity in human neurons will be crucial to understanding both the evolutionary specializations of the human brain and to developing treatments for neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Even before COVID-19, pneumonia with respiratory failure was a very common cause of hospitalization in the United States. Unfortunately, many patients who survive pneumonia have persistent health problems for months or years afterwards. The goal of this Effective Primary Care Practices that Enhance Recovery Trajectories after Pneumonia (EXPERT) study is to use appreciative inquiry to help primary care clinicians take better care of pneumonia patients–by taking a strengths-based approach for transformational change to design and test a new systems-level intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The studies proposed in this application address the molecular and cellular mechanisms responsible for the formation and maintenance of the light-sensitive compartment of vertebrate photoreceptor cells, the outer segment. Because of adverse effects of daily light exposure, the outer segment material has to be replaced approximately every ten days; this requires an exquisite efficiency and precision in performance of the molecular machinery responsible for supporting the integrity of this cellular compartment. Dysfunction of outer segment morphogenesis causes some of the most severe types of inherited retinal degeneration, which highlights the significance of our proposed studies for developing strategies of disease prevention and future therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will advance understanding of the biological mechanisms contributing to cellular senescence, a known driver of aging and disease. Specifically, we will investigate the mechanisms by which mitochondrial double-stranded RNA contributes to the induction of pro-inflammatory genes in senescence and test the efficacy of genetic and pharmacological interventions to promote healthy aging. This knowledge could potentially lead to novel clinical treatments to counteract aging and age-related disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL The purpose of this new, inter-institutional U54 application between San Diego State University (SDSU) and the University of California San Diego (UCSD) is to advance cancer health equity in underserved communities throughout the southern California border communities of San Diego and Imperial Counties. Under a new name – the Cancer Research and Education to Advance HealTh Equity (CREATE) Partnership – the overarching goals are to further increase SDSU’s cancer research capacities and expand SDSU’s and UCSD’s emphasis on cancer health disparities research. Additional goals include developing cancer research opportunities and pathways for undergraduate, graduate, and medical students as well as early-stage investigators (ESIs), which will lead to a future workforce that is more diverse and reflective of the catchment- area population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative When trauma is bad enough to paralyze a limb, there are many factors that play into the clinical assessment and prognosis for recovery; and nowadays, clinicians have many tests to assess one or another tissue type – but we do not have any test for the status of the nerve tissue usable before weeks of waiting. Nerves control everything in a limb, and without nerve input, a paralyzed limb is useless; severed nerves require urgent surgery whereas non-severed nerves are best left to recover on their own – and no test can tell the difference at the time of injury. We have found a commonly-used drug (4-aminopyridine), has the previously unknown effect of reactivating only non-severed nerves, and we propose a clinical trial to see if this drug can be used as a single-dose test for severed nerves in our trauma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative We propose novel hardware and data acquisition strategies for next-generation causal mapping of the human cerebral cortex using transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and high-resolution MRI. Leveraging our recent developments in MR-compatible TMS coils, we will develop a hybrid brain array of 48 coils for both TMS and noninvasive imaging that will be used to probe and map structural and functional changes in the living human brain at an unprecedented level of detail.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcoholic hepatitis (AH) is a severe, potentially life-threatening form of alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) with limited therapeutic options. The proposed research focuses on studying the connection between alcohol-associated cholestasis and AH in a novel murine model for ALD. The proposed research is expected to lead to an important positive impact on the development of therapeutic strategies to improve outcomes in patients with AH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Total joint arthroplasty is the most common orthopedic procedure for patients with refractory osteoarthritis, yet a significant number of patients fail to recover and develop chronic postsurgical pain (CPSP) following surgery. While risk factors for CPSP have been documented in this population, the mechanisms that promote resilience remain poorly characterized. Therefore, the goal of this project is to identify multisystem phenotypic profiles of resilience that predict postsurgical recovery trajectories in pain impact and physical function among adults undergoing knee and hip arthroplasty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE HIV prevention among young women in East and southern Africa is paramount to curbing the global epidemic and the advent of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) with daily medication has been only mildly helpful given its reliance on daily medication use. New PrEP products that are used every month (a vaginal ring) or 2 months (an injectable) could reduce compliance challenges and lead to greater HIV prevention coverage. In a set of implementation science driven studies in Kenya with collaborating public reproductive health clinics, we will address unanswered questions about how to optimize incorporation of new PrEP products and the degree to which the availability of additional products impacts HIV protection coverage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a need for imaging markers to hep prognosticate progression to Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). We propose the use of a novel method, named Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopic Fingerprinting (MRSF), to assess changes in the cellular microenvironment which contribute to AD. In combination with positron emission tomography and blood plasma measurements, we hypothesize that MRSF will provide new markers for predicting neurodegeneration and cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will pioneer an innovative approach to treat highly aggressive and therapy refractory B-cell lymphomas (MCD-DLBCLs) using MALT1 targeted therapy, which interrupts key lymphomagenic pathways and at the same time has the potential to disengage anti-lymphoma T-cell responses. Using newly developed MCD-DLBCL models and fully immunocompetent syngeneic host mice in comparison with host mice lacking specific arms of the immune system, we will elucidate the contribution of T-cell responses to the anti- lymphoma activity of MALT1 inhibition. Building on this, we will establish optimal regimens of MALT1 inhibition to enhance the efficacy of immunotherapy against MCD-DLBCLs in preclinical settings and study similar effects of MALT1 inhibition in lymphoma patients enrolled in the first in human trial with a MALT1 inhibitor, thus providing the proof-of-principle to investigate its combination with immunotherapy in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This project is relevant to public health as kidney disease is a major cost and national health concern. By monitoring chronic kidney disease (CKD) with laboratory diagnostic measurements in pediatrics to adults, it provides an opportunity for insight into underlying disease mechanisms and their relation to cardiovascular risk, social/behavioral development, and CKD progression. To accomplish the above we will be providing laboratory services ranging from routine laboratory diagnostics, gold standard measured glomerular filtration rate testing, novel biomarker analysis, and overall support of the specimens collected for the CKiD study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: There is increasing concern that social media use may be impacting mental health in adolescents. The goal of this proposal is to determine if using social media passively is related to mental health as well as characterize physiological pathways (parasympathetic nervous system and alterations in expression of genes regulated by the immune system) that influence risk for poor mental and physical health. Additionally, we will examine how self-reported stressors and geospatial exposures to stressful environments (i.e. streets with high levels of violent crime) impact frequency of passive social media use and the degree to which passive social media use as stress coping strategy alters emotional and physiological responses to stressors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Little is known about the impact of activity, sleep patterns, and genetic background on cardiovascular risk. We propose to use Fitbit and genomic data from the All of Us Research Program to examine the separate and aggregate associations between physical activity and sleep behaviors and genetic background on the incidence of cardiovascular risk factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is a debilitating disorder characterized by spontaneous and recurring seizures and persistent memory and emotional impairments that are both treatment resistant and dissociable from seizures themselves. There is strong evidence that these comorbidities are driven by circuit deficits along the dorsoventral axis of the entorhinal-hippocampal circuit, thus necessitating characterization of epilepsy- induced circuit changes at both functional and molecular levels. In this proposal, I will use an established mouse model of TLE to determine how epilepsy drives functional and molecular changes in entorhinal-hippocampal circuits implicated in spatial memory and emotional deficits, providing new insight for development of targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT / PROJECT NARRATIVE Health research in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) is often conducted in collaboration with investigators and institutions in high-income countries with the rationale that this helps circumvent many of the structural and economic limitations faced by LMIC-based researchers and promotes local research priorities at a global scale. However, there is growing attention to the fact that international research partnerships may often inadvertently perpetuate academic and scientific asymmetries between research partners which ultimately risks suboptimal scientific and partnership outcomes. Here we use experienced HIV-focused research partnerships between Uganda and the United States to comprehensively describe best practices and barriers to equitable research collaboration and pilot a pragmatic equity planning tool to guide international research partnerships toward equity-focused outputs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Despite substantial investment in treatment, prevention, and recovery, the United States continues to experience historically high rates of fatal overdoses, many of which involve opioids. Naloxone, an opioid antagonist, is a highly effective overdose reversal mechanism that can be easily used by laypersons – but it remains remarkably underutilized. This study will test how best to connect a large, existing CPR citizen responder network with opioid education and naloxone distribution programs, with the long-term goal of supporting a national-scale assessment of whether this approach can reduce the prevalence of fatal opioid- involved overdoses.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to improve care coordination for children with vascular anomalies, especially those in rural areas. Pediatricians often lack the knowledge and resources needed to care for patients with vascular anomalies and struggle to coordinate care with specialists. High-quality care coordination is essential for patients managing rare diseases and can help reduce the risk of emergency room visits, hospitalizations, and readmissions, particularly for patients in rural communities who live far from specialized medical centers.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Primary Care Needs for Patients with Vascular Anomalies: Improving Continuity of Care and Care Coordination in Rare Diseases

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the development and validation of a data-driven lay first responder program aims to fill a critical deficit in prehospital care and decrease deaths and disability among injured patients in Cameroon. If found to be feasible and effective, this approach would shift clinical practice patterns in this context. The research is relevant to the NIH’s mission because it seeks to lengthen the lives of trauma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-melanoma skin cancers are a growing public health challenge that cost the United States (U.S.) healthcare system more than $1 billion in treatment costs annually. Actinic Keratoses (AK) are ultraviolet light induced premalignant skin lesions that are precursors to cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (CSCC). CSCC is the second most common type of cancer, is associated with significant morbidity, and results in more deaths than from melanoma in the U.S. each year. This Direct Phase II SBIR proposal builds upon two successfully completed clinical trials and aims to complete a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, 4-arm, multicenter study to demonstrate the efficacy and safety of topical dosage formulations of Calcipotriol (CPO) plus 5-Fluorouracil (5- FU) for the treatment of AK.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A key problem in Zebrafish (Danio rerio) husbandry science and industry is that a high-quality standardized diet, including optimized physical properties and feed management strategies, has not been developed for this important vertebrate animal model. Our solution for the industry, driven by a synergistic collaboration between Meridian Biotech and the laboratory of Dr. Stephen Watts at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, is to develop optimized ingredient profiles (based on bacterial-based single cell protein source) for an open formulation standard reference diet for larval, juvenile and adult Zebrafish, that will achieve a desired level of control and whereby use of Zebrafish as a modern and effective biomedical animal model is substantially improved and standardized. Given the utility of the Zebrafish as an animal model for human health, and coupled with the concomitant investment of research dollars, it is imperative that we develop open, high quality standard reference diets to add to the confidence, reproducibility, and exchange of results derived from this important animal model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Acute lung injury, or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is the final common pathway of a variety of direct and indirect insults to the lungs. Lower respiratory tract bacterial infections and pneumonia contribute to prolonged respiratory failure and increase morbidity and mortality in patients with acute lung injury, or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The broad, long term objective is to identify key factors that promote host protection against pathogen-triggered lung injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in six Americans report at least four adverse childhood experiences, an exposure that increases the risk of mental health conditions later in life and specifically in the perinatal period. This rigorous hybrid type 2 randomized controlled trial will optimize strategies to implement TRIO, a trauma-informed interpersonal therapy-based program based on the ROSE intervention, using the collaborative care model, for low income pregnant and postpartum people with a history of adverse childhood experiences. We will evaluate acceptability, appropriateness, cost, feasibility, and fidelity of the intervention as well as preliminary efficacy data with the goal of informing the design of a planned definitive cluster randomized effectiveness trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Submassive pulmonary embolism (PE) is a common dangerous disease that often causes cardiopulmonary disability, reduced functional capacity, and decreased quality of life. Catheter-directed therapy (CDT), by acutely reducing clot burden and improving right ventricular function, has the potential to prevent these long- term complications. This study will determine if CDT in addition to anticoagulant therapy, rather than anticoagulant therapy alone, should be used to treat patients with submassive PE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the rapidly growing population of older Asian Americans, their participation in clinical research for Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease-Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) remains historically low – masking health disparities in this minority group. Social determinants of health (SDOH) are the conditions in the environment that affect an individual’s overall health and quality of life. This proposed study will investigate mechanisms involved in the relationship between SDOH and AD/ADRD outcomes, as well as identify vascular risk factors and novel biomarkers for predicting AD/ADRD using modern systems biology and machine learning based approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The population of the US is aging rapidly, with considerable growth in Latinx older adults. The increase in the minority population will tremendously impact the public health systems. Understanding the determinants of health in the Latinx population and contrasting them to other racial/ethnic groups will provide better preventive strategies for the Latinx minorities and help lessen the growing Alzheimer's and dementia epidemic in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  The goal of this project is to provide in-depth research experiences, career training and mentorship to underrepresented minority graduates in Montana, including Native Americans, and rural first generation and/or low-income students, so that they can successfully transition into doctoral degree programs in the biomedical sciences. To accomplish this goal, we have designed an evidence-based postbaccalaureate program, PREP- MT, that will equip recent minority graduates (“PREP scholars'') with the experience, knowledge, research skills and confidence to become highly successful PhD students and graduates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Motivated by the insight that overcoming centuries of structural racism will require significant concentrated  investment in the structures that have left Black people and Black neighborhoods in peril, we propose a cluster  randomized controlled trial of a suite of place-based and financial-wellbeing interventions delivered at the  community, organizational, and individual/household levels. Designed to target many of the key mechanisms  by which structural racism results in racial health disparities among Black adults in Philadelphia, we  hypothesize that because the interventions will be implemented simultaneously in targeted micro-geographic  areas, positive health impacts will be multiplied and longer-lasting than has accrued by more traditional  individually focused interventions. Upon completion, the proposed research will provide policymakers,  communities, and health systems with innovative, timely, and scalable evidence on new strategies that can  meaningfully close long-standing racial health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Hypothalamic tanycytes are radial glial cells that closely resemble neural progenitors in morphology and gene expression profile, as well as retain a limited ability to generate neurons postnatally but are undetectable in adult animals. Identifying intrinsic (Ascl1) and extrinsic (Shh signaling) factors that stimulate neurogenic competence in tanycyte and differentiation of tanycyte-derived neurons that modulate body weight, could potentially be a useful means of treating obesity and metabolic disorders such as type II diabetes. In the K00 phase, I will pursue postdoctoral training to understand injury-induced neurogenic competence in Danio reiro (zebrafish) tanycytes, and gene regulatory networks controlling the regeneration of the zebrafish hypothalamus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed studies will reveal the intrinsic properties of spinal neurons, neuronal interactions, and organization of spinal circuits involved in the generation of locomotor rhythm. A better understanding of the spinal neural mechanisms controlling locomotion will provide essential insights for the development of future clinical strategies to restore and promote motor functions by identifying specific targets for recovery of locomotion in spinal cord injury and motor disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE As people age, some of their body cells acquire genetic changes. A newly recognized type of acquired genetic change, called cytosolic DNA, has emerged as an important player in either triggering or mediating other age-related biological alterations that can lead to health conditions. By studying identical and fraternal twins, over a time frame of 10 to 15 years, we will determine the frequency of cytosolic DNA, discover if it occurs due to a genetic predisposition or environmental factors, characterize the types of cytosolic DNA and their stability over time, and identify relationships between cytosolic DNA and other age-related biological changes; all of which is knowledge that is needed to develop targeted therapies to reduce/alleviate age-related health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a pathology associated with inflammation, tau phosphorylation, and amyloid accumulation. Many modulators of these neurodegenerative processes come from the interaction of the brain- gut-microbiome axis and the production of bacterial metabolites. Our central hypothesis is that gut microbiota dysbiosis after traumatic brain injury (TBI) contributes directly to the inflammatory response in AD brains and that precision microbiota therapy will restore dysbiosis and preserve protective gut signals in AD pathogenesis. Manipulating the gut microbiota could serve as a therapy for AD patients after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Abdominal pain in patients over 65 years old is very common, causing 1.4 million emergency department visits per year. Older adults who develop abdominal pain severe enough to seek care at an emergency department have poor health outcomes, including death, as often as patients who develop a heart attack. This proposal seeks to understand how care of this patient population is managed—especially for patients with impaired cognition, Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, and/or frailty—so that it can ultimately be understood and improved.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Harmful menstrual practices, such as chhaupadi (menstrual seclusion) in Nepal, are an urgent threat to women’s health, wellbeing, and development. This study will investigate underlying mechanisms of promising aspects of chhaupadi interventions to date and build upon these findings to co-design and pilot test a context- specific intervention in partnership with community members. In the short-term, outcomes from this proposal will advance the field by resulting in 1) a pilot tested intervention that can be further tested in a future randomized controlled trial, 2) a refined approach for engaging communities in sustainable and contextually appropriate intervention co-design that is expected to be applicable to other low- and middle-income country contexts, and 3) in the longer-term support public health efforts aiming to reduce the negative health effects of harmful menstrual practices on women in Nepal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We propose to develop a unique three-dimensional (3D) human mini-glioblastoma (GBM) model through the utilization of a light-based bioprinting technology and taking advantage of primary neuronal, vascular, and GBM cells, to more precisely replicate the brain tumor microenvironment in human patients. The construction of a high-content in vitro 3D human mini-GBM model mimicking not only the cellular compositions but also the extracellular matrix properties and importantly, tissue architecture of its in vivo counterpart, will allow us to precisely assess proliferation, migration, and transformation of GBM cells, at higher availability and throughput for potential drug screening in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The area postrema, a brain circumventricular sensory organ regulated by both humoral signals and inputs from the gastrointestinal tract, plays a critical role in nausea and aversive behaviors. During my postdoctoral fellowship, I identified and characterized a population of area postrema neurons which mediates aversive behaviors, and here I will specify and map both humoral and vagal inputs to these area postrema neurons and understand their physiological effects. Acquiring expertise required to achieve these aims, namely hormone signaling and functional circuit mapping, will enable me to establish an independent research program which focuses on the cellular and neural mechanisms of nausea combining mice and vomiting animals, and may lead to the development of novel anti-emetic therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This large qualitative study of Gulf War Veterans will yield significant insight into the features of effective care models, treatments, and satisfaction with care. Interviews of Gulf War Veterans suffering chronic multisymptom illness by our team of experienced qualitative researchers will yield 1) significant insight into treatment regimens—from care both in- and outside the VA—that have the greatest patient benefit, 2) a more complete and nuanced understanding of symptoms that can be used for more directed treatment, and 3) publicly available resources that can be used by veterans, caregivers, clinicians, and researchers. It will also create a rich, ongoing resource that can inform VA’s effort to develop better care models for Gulf War veterans, identify better illness-specific health measures and promising therapeutic approaches, and activate veterans to be more engaged with the health system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hemianopia (contralateral blindness) is a severely debilitating disorder that is a common consequence of unilateral stroke or traumatic injury to the neocortex. The present study will examine the effectiveness of a novel technique for its rehabilitation using a primate model and will explore the nature of the recovered vision as well as the neural substrates that support it. The findings will provide essential insights into the mechanisms of multisensory-induced visual plasticity in the primate brain and inform future translational efforts to develop effective treatment regimens based on its underlying premise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As we have yet to understand the multilingual caregiving experience of those living in an English-dominant society, health service providers are stymied in their response to Latino AD/ADRD patients and their ability to support family caregivers. By considering the cross-cultural and linguistic variability within caregivers’ social networks, this project aligns with NIA’s priorities to address the health of the nation’s aging population in the context of its changing demographics. Insights gleaned from this project could be relevant to other multilingual family caregivers.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Fundamental to diabetes treatment is the control blood sugar to delay the onset of complications such as eye and kidney problems. Effective treatment may be limited by concern over hypoglycemia (low blood sugar), a common and potentially hazardous side effect. To monitor for this side effect and improve the safety of care for Veterans with diabetes, this study will identify patients with hypoglycemia using patient surveys and searches of text in medical records for notation by clinicians. Other information will be collected in surveys and from the electronic health record and used in predicting which patients will have hypoglycemia. The best set of predictors will be used in assigning risks to diabetes patients. The new methods for finding hypoglycemia and identifying those diabetes patients at high risk will be applied in a national automated system for use in monitoring patient safety and improving care to reduce risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Suicide is a leading cause of death among adolescents, and recently, problematic social media use has been linked to the emergence of suicidal thoughts and behaviors. By coupling biological measures–including neural and physiological markers–with deep interrogation of social media real-time interactions, there is enormous promise to elucidate suicide risk among adolescents. Collectively, this innovative approach will identify those who are susceptible to negative social media exposures and inform novel clinical targets, which will facilitate the development of preventative-intervention approaches that reduce the needless loss of life among young people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this project is to develop a clinical diffusion image analysis software which will automatically calculate diffusion imaging-based biomarkers for early Alzheimer’s disease diagnosis, better patient management and potentially monitor the effects of the therapeutic interventions. We will either use diffusion tensor images or if available multi-shell diffusion images in conjunction with volumetric MRI images for segmentation and then report microstructural parameters from these segmented brain regions. These microstructural parameters or diffusion biomarkers will then be used for separating AD patients from controls and monitoring treatment response during pharmaceutical interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: This effort is expected to impact public health by advancing a new high-speed, high-resolution, low-cost imaging technology capable of real-time three-dimensional structural and angiographic imaging of periodontal tissue over large volumes using swept source optical coherence tomography (SS-OCT). The proposed technology will enable imaging at previously inaccessible wavelengths and at speeds several times faster than previous SS- OCT dental imaging, ultimately enabling real-time whole mouth imaging for assessment of periodontal attachment, alveolar bone quality and level, gingival inflammation, sub gingival calculus plaque and tissue biotype. Such a system can also provide an objective means to determine and evaluate the prognosis of periodontal, regenerative, and restorative therapies, improve computer aided design and machining (CAD/CAM) capability for dental restorative procedures and planning, and become a reliable tool for long term monitoring and maintenance in clinical practice for oral health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence of a greater burden of Alzheimer's causing abnormal protein, pathological tau, and more rapid cognitive decline in women versus men on the Alzheimer's trajectory makes it critical to examine female- specific Alzheimer's risk factors and pathways. Because inflammation in the brain (neuroinflammation) and testosterone show ties to tau and demonstrate sex differences, we propose to examine their relationships to tau burden and memory performance over 2-years in older women and how the modifiable risk factors of physical activity and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) might influence these relationships. Finding answers to these questions will contribute to the identification of both therapeutic targets and lifestyle interventions that are tailored specifically for the sex that bears the greatest burden of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) releases extracellular vesicles (EVs) into the bloodstream at relatively early disease stages, making them ideal liquid biopsy markers for early HCC detection. This Direct-to-Phase-II SBIR proposal aims to further develop, optimize, and automate the HCC EV Surface Protein (SP) Test, ultimately establishing an in vitro diagnostic (IVD) test based on HCC EVs. Successful development of the HCC EV SP Test will enable a sensitive, EV-based IVD test for detecting early-stage HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Summary Rationale: To understand the many disorders of the brain it is necessary to grapple with its complexity. Increasingly large and complicated data sets are being collected, but the tools for analyzing and modeling the data are not yet available. More researchers trained in computational neuroscience are desperately needed. This project supports interdisciplinary graduate training programs in computational neuroscience (TPCN) at both Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) and the University of Pittsburgh (Pitt), and a summer school in computational neuroscience for undergraduates, which are available to students coming from colleges and universities throughout the United States. Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) is a world leader and innovator in quantitative fields such as machine learning, computer science, and artificial intelligence, and recently, neuroscience has emerged as a field for strategic growth at the university. The University of Pittsburgh is renowned for the strength of its clinical and biomedical research programs. The TPCN is set within a highly collegial, cross-disciplinary environment of our Center for the Neural Basis of Cognition (CNBC), which is operated jointly by CMU and Pitt. The CNBC was established in 1994 to foster interdisciplinary research on the neural mechanisms of brain function, and now comprises 162 faculty having appointments in 32 departments. Goals: The goals of the TPCN are to: 1) Support computational training of PhD students across the neurosciences, 2) Broaden accessibility for students historically underrepresented in STEM by augmenting an existing MS-to-PhD training program that prepares them for advanced graduate training in computational neuroscience, 3) Expand computational training of undergraduate students through a formal academic minor in computational neuroscience, 4) Support an undergraduate summer program that combines a two-week “boot-camp” overview of computational neuroscience with an 8-week research experience, 5) Create online materials that not only serve our own students but are publicly available on the web, and 6) Enhance our recruitment through relationships we have developed with minority-serving institutions.

PROJECT_TITLE: Interdisciplinary Training in Computational Neuroscience

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The field of neuroscience is experiencing a renaissance in terms of the scale and complexity of the datasets that are now routinely collected. It is crucial that the next generation of neuroscientists are able to synthesize, organize, and model these datasets, with the goal of building new theories of the brain. The central goal of our training program will be to train the next generation of neuroscientists with the strong quantitative skills needed to advance the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need for novel therapeutic approaches to treat chronic pain, however a major hurdle is the lack of detailed understanding of nociceptive circuitry. Our premise is that spinal cord nociceptive circuit outputs to the brain are attractive targets because pain-related signals emanating from a range of nociceptors and other sensory neuron types, descending modulatory inputs, and local interneurons, channel through only a limited number of ascending outputs pathways. Our plan is to use new mouse genetic tools and physiological and behavioral analyses to reveal the properties and functions of dorsal horn nociceptive circuit output pathways to generate a new predictive model of spinal cord nociceptive circuitry as a foundation for developing alternatives to opioids as analgesics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Psychological distress and depression are common among young people living with HIV (Y-PLWH) and negatively impact medication adherence and disease control. In low- and middle-income countries, this problem is compounded by the lack of trained mental health professionals on the provider side and the requirement of frequent clinic-based visits imposing greater cost, inconvenience, and stigma for patients. In this proposal, we will 1) finalize the prototype of Change My Story, a narrative digital game with a choose-your- own-adventure format in which young players navigate difficult experiences based on drivers of psychological distress and depression and 2) integrate this game into a comprehensive, task-shifted PST intervention to optimize engagement in mental health care to improve treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive weight gain leading to obesity is common during the early phases of pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) treatment, and results in higher risk of relapse, lower event-free survival rates, and more adverse events during treatment. To address multiple calls from the NCI and other federal agencies for research targeting disparities in treatment outcomes among patients who experience obesity, this K08 research will adapt, refine, and pilot test family-based health promotion intervention that aims to curb excessive weight gain among youth with newly diagnosed ALL. The proposed research and career development plan will yield important patient- centered data regarding components of intervention adaptation, feasibility, acceptability, and participant engagement, enhancing the potential for the investigator to advance behavioral cancer control science and improve clinical outcomes for youth with ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative:  Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an incurable autoimmune disease characterized by autoantibodies that continue to spread to new self-antigens over time resulting in increased pathogenesis and disease. We propose that this phenomena, referred to as epitope spreading, is promoted by a specialized subset of autoreactive B cells that originate from both spontaneous GC and non-GC lymphoid space. In the current proposal, we will characterize the developmental kinetics and dynamics of this subset and how their fates are determined by the two different environments.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the unmet needs for tailored guidelines to manage genital infections, and for accessible sexual and reproductive health care, among Syrian refugee women, who constitute the world's largest and most vulnerable forcibly displaced female population. By quantifying and characterizing drivers of recurrent genital infections, we seek to develop contextualized prevention and management tools to be incorporated into an adapted and evidence-based sexual health intervention for rural-dwelling refugee women in Lebanon. The novel application of implementation science methodologies to improve refugee women's health in a humanitarian setting is directly responsive to the Fogarty International Center's goal to “catalyze timely, high-quality, ethical, and actionable research in crisis settings”, and may inform global responses to the growing refugee crisis with potential to improve the lives of millions of forcibly displaced women in resource-limited, humanitarian settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Oncology-focused Postdoctoral Training In Care Delivery and Symptom Science (OPTICS) T32 program will train postdoctoral fellows (MDs and PhDs) to conduct innovative translational research to decrease cancer mortality by improving cancer care delivery. The program's cornerstone will be a 2-year mentored research experience in which trainees will I) execute an impactful research project aligned with one or more of four cancer-focused thematic areas: (1) Data Science, (2) Risk Mitigation, (3) Symptom Science, and (4) Care Delivery; II) train in core research methods through coursework, seminars, workshops, and reading groups; and III) acquire the professional skills prerequisite for success as independent investigators. OPTICS trainees will benefit from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center's large patient population, diverse faculty mentors, data assets, New York City location, and close partnership with Weill Cornell Medicine and Rockefeller University, as well as its vibrant culture dedicated to population health, training, and scientific discovery through collaborative multidisciplinary team science.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to precisely target individuals with cancer and at-risk populations with evidence-based tools to address individual, sociocultural, or environmental factors is likely to lead to the greatest improvements in cancer outcomes and reductions in cancer risk. Thus, this application for a new T32 postdoctoral training program at Fox Chase Cancer Center is designed to prepare PhD and MD postdoctoral fellows to lead innovative and scientifically rigorous research in precision cancer control with diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed U01 consortium will expand long-standing work centered at the NIH Clinical Center focused on individuals with germline GATA2- or RUNX1-mutations who are at high-risk for developing bone marrow failure (BMF) and hematopoietic malignancies (HMs). Intramural and four extramural investigators will test the hypothesis that inflammation derived from intrinsic and extrinsic sources drives BMF in GATA2-mutant patients, plus clonal hematopoiesis that frequently evolves into HMs in both syndromes. The results of the planned work will identify new biomarkers and pathways associated with BMF and HMs and lead to novel strategies to lower systemic inflammation and slow or prevent clonal expansion that could be tested in a clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the bioengineered human corneal endothelial grafts have shown vision recovery in animal models, the current grafts do not provide native-like reconstruction of the cornea due to suboptimal degradation of the biomaterial in the eye, which has hindered further development of this technology for corneal patients. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it develops a new biomaterial that can be dissolved from the outside after transplantation, thereby enabling improving corneal reconstruction. Upon completion, this research will improve the current corneal endothelial grafts for corneal patients and is in line with NIH’s mission of improving the quality of life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The proposed project is of public health importance because children with intellectual and developmental disabilities are at increased risk for having their pain missed or under-treated. Parents play an important role in judging when their children are in pain and when that pain needs to be treated, but little is understood about what factors influence these judgments among parent-child dyads affected by intellectual and developmental disabilities. The proposed study will identify the reciprocal parent and child factors that influence how children with intellectual and developmental disabilities express pain and how parents interpret and respond to these pain behaviors, with a long term goal of improving pain assessment and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: National Institute on Aging (NIA) REDI Skill for ENtrepreneurs for Elder Solutions (SENES) fellowship program  Project Narrative SENES is a year-long educational experience that will provide a five-founder cohort (annually; 25 over five years) with six months of hands-on learning punctuated with an “elder solutions” capstone project in month six. The second six months of the fellowship will be an active and supported technology translation in one of two tracks, all supported by medical faculty and aging-focused advisors as well as the experienced commercialization team at UCSC. SENES will expose founders to the aging market for their solutions in a practical and material way; position founders for success in their commercialization efforts, resulting in more successful technology-based startups from NIH-funded and supported researchers; and leverage government investment by increasing the likelihood of success of private capital.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the rapidly growing population of older Chinese Americans, their participation in clinical trials for Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease-Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) remains historically low due to a lack of culturally and linguistically appropriate study materials and assessment tools. The Memory Support System (MSS) from the Healthy Action to Benefit Independence & Thinking® (HABIT) Program is a promising non-pharmacological intervention for individuals with mild cognitive impairment, but the system was primarily developed and used on non-Hispanic White, English-speaking adults. Translation and adaptation of the MSS materials and assessment tools from English into Chinese, the third most spoken language in the US, will help create clinical trial opportunities for older Chinese Americans and collect the pilot data needed to conduct a larger non-pharmacological intervention targeting early symptoms of AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The effects of recreational cannabis legalization (RCL) on use of cigarettes, cigars, and electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS)—the US’s three most popular tobacco/nicotine products—are unclear and understudied, despite potentially substantive public health implications due to tobacco’s longstanding role as the US’s leading cause of preventable morbidity and mortality. Collecting detailed information on state and local cannabis policies and retail environments and matching these to nationally representative survey data, this project will clarify how these regulations impact underage and adult use of cigarettes, cigars, ENDS, and blunts as well as cannabis use, assess how state policy details and local cannabis laws modify these effects, and simulate the impacts of alternative policy scenarios for tobacco product use by age-group. Findings will clarify RCL’s effects on tobacco/nicotine use and identify cannabis policy opportunities at the federal, state, and local level to ensure continued progress towards eliminating tobacco’s toll on society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Mayo Advancing Research Equity in ADRD Study in Jacksonville (MAREAS-Jax; Spanish for tides) will support the development of infrastructure to recruit and engage Hispanic/Latino Americans and African Americans in a longitudinal research program designed to characterize the contributions of genetic, medical comorbidities, and lifespan influences of Structural/Social Determinants of Health (the “exposome”) to disparate burden of Alzheimer disease and related dementias. Real-time communication of brain health risk factors will empower participants to mitigate risks and improve overall brain health. Neuroimaging and blood-based biomarkers of amyloid, tau, neurodegeneration, and vascular burden together with multi-omics measures will inform the relationship between the exposome and Alzheimer disease and related dementia burden within and across individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) use body's own immune response to fight cancer. Because immune response is generally stronger in patients of African ancestry (AA) than European ancestry (EA), AA patients may have more negative side effects from ICIs but may also respond better to them. In this study, we will follow a large group of AA and EA patients on ICIs over time in order to understand these racial differences and to see what other patient factors may predict these differences. The long-term goal is to ensure that all patients can benefit from new treatments for their cancer through appropriate management of side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is to support a unique program of predoctoral training in Cancer Biology at Emory University. A suite of evidence-based learning approaches, experienced research mentors, and a unique ability to interact across clinical and laboratory disciplines will enable the development of our Ph.D. level workforce in academic, industry, and government-based research careers, as well as other biomedical research-related careers to enhance understanding the biology of cancer and ultimately reach a cancer-free world. This proposal will ensure appropriate training in rigor and reproducibility, methods to assessing student competencies, and a focus on inclusive excellence to train a diverse cadre of Ph.D. scientists capable of cross-disciplinary communication.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no effective, long-acting reversible male contraceptives commercially available. Contraline has developed a long-lasting, non-permanent, injectable hydrogel (ADAM) to occlude sperm transport in the vas deferens, which has demonstrated safety and efficacy in a First-in-Human clinical study. This SBIR proposal focuses on the development of a next-generation implantable male contraceptive (ADAM Air) that is simpler to implant and reverse than previous vas-occlusive contraceptives, and demonstration of its safety and efficacy via GLP studies to allow Contraline to pursue future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (Parent Grant)  Gender diverse children often experience disparities in mental health and well-being. Further questions concern the stability of their gender as that has implications for medical transitions. The proposed work would examine the role of gender beliefs and self-categorization in predicting mental health and well-being, as well as provide better estimates of rates of stability and change across time in the identities of both cisgender and gender diverse youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of this Northwestern University Clinical and Translational Science (NUCATS) UM1 proposal is to transform clinical and translational science to improve health for all. NUCATS will continue to serve as a hub for clinical and translational research across Northwestern University and its clinical affiliates, Northwestern Medicine, Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago, and the Shirley Ryan AbilityLab. NUCATS will build upon its exceptional strengths in cross-disciplinary team science and boundary-crossing partnerships to address three Specific Aims: to advance inclusive excellence in our workforce, community partnerships, and research participants (INCLUDE); to harness innovation to enhance entrepreneurship as well as the rigor and reproducibility of research (INNOVATE); and to infuse implementation science into work across the translational continuum in our health system and with community partners (IMPLEMENT).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Project Narrative The overarching goal of the Washington University Advancing Cancer Control Equity Research through Transformative Solutions Center (WashU-ACCERT) is to advance cancer control equity in the St. Louis region through community engaged multilevel research interventions that address the impact of social determinants of health on adverse cancer control outcomes. Our innovative strategies to promote community partnerships and implement responsive research will position WashU-ACCERT to meaningfully engage with the local communities and implement interventions that will build capacity among scholars and community partners, and benefit our communities, health systems, providers, and people at greater risk of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: In this proposal, Baylor College of Medicine (BCM) and the University of Houston (UH) are coming together to form the Consortium for Translational and Precision Health. Our goal is to build on the strengths of BCM in basic and genomic science with the strengths of UH in the science of spreading information, entrepreneurship, pharmaceutical science, and community engagement. We will form a highly impactful organization that promotes the development of new ways to work on local and national health needs and reduces the time it takes for research discoveries to reach the doctor’s office, so it can help the right person at the right time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Musculoskeletal health conditions lead to disuse, bone and muscle loss, and increased risk of bone fractures. Racial minorities have worse health outcomes during the recovery from musculoskeletal health conditions, suggesting specialized care is needed for genetically diverse patients. We will use the Diversity Outbred mouse population, an innovative animal model that incorporates the same genetic diversity found in humans, to perform a comprehensive analysis of how genetics and disuse influence the musculoskeletal system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Portal hypertension is a common final pathway of chronic liver disease and is responsible for significant morbidity and mortality among patients with liver disease. The goal of this research is to elucidate the role of neutrophil-platelet interactions in driving microvascular thrombosis which we previously identified as critical in the pathogenesis of portal hypertension. This proposal is expected to identify clinically-relevant mechanisms to inhibit the neutrophil-platelet interactions which drive portal hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell therapy is a new technology that involves collecting a patient’s own immune cells, engineering them to fight a specific disease, then re-injecting the cells to the patient. In a recent clinical trial, we tested a new RNA-based approach for cell therapy that helped patients with the autoimmune disease myasthenia gravis. In this proposal will test if this exciting technology can also be used to safely and effectively treat patients with a different autoimmune disease, lupus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Virginia Advancing Cancer Control Equity Research Through Transformative Solutions (VA-ACCERT) Center fortifies a community-academic partnership between the Virginia Commonwealth University, the Eastern Virginia Medical School, and Virginia’s federally supported, income-based housing communities with the infrastructure to design and conduct multi-level, health promotion and cancer prevention interventions that address the complex social drivers of health that impede cancer health equity in these communities. The VA- ACCERT Center also strives to engage early-career investigators from groups underrepresented in behavioral and biomedical sciences to advance future cancer prevention research among income-based housing populations. Ultimately, the Center will disseminate and promote the adoption of its findings and best practices so they can be adapted to similar income-based housing communities across the United States.

PHR: Project Narrative Fifty percent of patients with lupus fail to respond to current treatment options, while Mesenchymal Stromal Cells (MSCs) are a safe novel approach to treating lupus refractory to standard of care. The ongoing and newly proposed mechanistic studies will provide key understanding into immunologic effects of the MSCs.

PHR: NARRATIVE American Joint Replacement Research-Collaborative (AJRR-C) provides methodological expertise and access to nationwide data resources to facilitate innovative, methodologically rigorous and interdisciplinary clinical research in total joint arthroplasty (TJA). The clinical research needs of the TJA research community that are addressed by the AJRR-C include training and mentoring of the next generation of TJA researchers, customized consultations, facilitated access to high quality, rich data sources and national registry data, improvement of statistical methodologies for risk adjustment, new informatics tools and infrastructure for prospective studies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: In the last few years, “missed” diagnostic test results, i.e., those with absent or delayed follow-up, have been determined to be a significant patient safety problem in the VA. While thousands of veterans have abnormal test results every day, there are currently no methods to identify opportunities to reduce care delays. Rigorous measurement and improvement of diagnostic safety can thus benefit veterans and should be prioritized given the increasing amount of electronically available data. We will develop a multi-faceted measurement and improvement approach and build on recommendations from the recent IOM report “Improving Diagnosis in Health Care” to improve veterans' outcomes related to follow-up of abnormal test results. We will develop and evaluate a new VA facility-based systems approach for surveillance and improvement of test results follow-up. Our project is relevant to several VA national policy initiatives related to measurement and safety improvement and builds on our extensive work in improving patient safety related to the diagnostic process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults (AYAs) have the highest prevalence rates of prescription drug misuse (PDM) and increasing rates of overdose from PDM, but little research has examined longitudinal changes or age, time period, and cohort differences in PDM, PDM from multiple medication classes, and polysubstance use that involves PDM in AYAs. This research program will examine longitudinal change and age-period-cohort differences in PDM in AYAs, aged 12 to 30 years, to identify at-risk AYAs in need of targeted screening, prevention and treatment. As such, this research is relevant to the mission of the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) because it will allow researchers and clinicians to prevent PDM at the most vulnerable periods and intervene in those AYAs most in need of treatment for PDM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) represent the most widespread manifestation of preventable intellectual disability. Our preliminary data suggest that choline supplementation initiated early in pregnancy can ameliorate adverse growth retardation and some of the debilitating neurocognitive effects seen in FASD. In the current study, we will add neonatal brain anatomical, diffusion and metabolic imaging to our recently- funded, fully-powered clinical trial of choline supplementation in heavy drinking pregnant women in the Western Cape province of South Africa. This study will contribute to our understanding of the mechanistic underpinnings of the neuroprotective benefits of prenatal maternal choline supplementation to the developing fetus exposed prenatally to alcohol and has the potential to inform prenatal interventions and postnatal FASD remediation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We are building a complete, commercial software solution to enable team-based genomic analysis in all settings, including, but not limited to, challenging diagnostic cases in undiagnosed diseases clinics and rapid sequencing programs in newborn intensive care units. Our software will include secure computational pipelines to process genomic data that can be deployed on the cloud, or on institutional hardware, and visual data portals that make access to, and analysis of, this data available to all. We will evaluate and refine these tools in team-based settings in the NHGRI funded Undiagnosed Diseases Network clinical site, and newborn intensive care unit at the University of Utah.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer is the second-most common malignancy in men and other people with prostates worldwide, yet we do not fully understand the genetic events that drive tumor initiation or drug resistance. While the hallmark alterations of prostate cancer have been reported, the functional consequences of most mutations remain unknown. We aim to identify the mechanisms by which IRS4 gain of function drives tumor initiation and CDK4 gain of function drives drug resistance in prostate cancers with PTEN loss, which will contribute fundamental insight into the altered cell circuitry in prostate cancer and identify potential therapeutic targets.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neurodevelopmental impact of prolonged sedation (in weeks) as part of the complex perioperative care is infancy is unknown. This proposal is relevant to the part of the NICHD and NIDA’s mission as it will investigate structural and clinical care aspects of early brain development in esophageal atresia - the most common gastro- intestinal birth defect, using structural MRI and neurobehavioral evaluations. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with substance use disorders (SUD) in the criminal legal system often cannot access SUD treatment– and those who do are less likely to receive evidence-based services–which can reinforce pathways that worsen community health. We will study the dynamics between the criminal legal system and community SUD treatment system to generate unprecedented cross-sector evidence of the spillover effects of county incarceration on community SUD treatment need, availability, use, and outcomes, and racial/ethnic and gender disparities therein. With input from experts and people with lived experience, we will disseminate findings to inform antiracist health policies that can transform the criminal legal and SUD treatment systems to reduce SUD-related morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is focused on understanding the public health impact of daily experiences with discrimination, harassment, and stigmatization experienced by sexual and gender minority couples living in rural communities in the Midwest. We aim to isolate key factors that increase the likelihood of alcohol use and destructive conflict in response to distress experienced from daily minority stress (i.e., drinking to cope motives and internalized forms of minority stress). We will also identify sources of resiliency arising from interpersonal relationships and community-based resources that interrupt this maladaptive cascade and mitigate risk for the dual public health threats of alcohol use and intimate partner violence in this underrepresented population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The most accurate current methods for understanding text with computers have severe restrictions on the lengths of the text that they can process, which is a severe limitation for current systems’ understanding of electronic health records. In this project, we first propose new algorithms that can handle longer text sequences, along with innovative ways to learn the models. Our second major goal is to incorporate multiple data types in the same architecture, combining structured data from traditional databases, unstructured text, and images. We evaluate our proposed methods on several important clinical tasks, including predicting injury severity in patients in the emergency department, diagnoses in intensive care unit patients, and several prognostic variables in intensive care unit patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synonymous codon substitutions are typically regarded as “silent” and “neutral.” Yet, synonymous mutations can significantly alter the folding mechanism of the encoded protein, leading to adverse effects on cell fitness. With this project, I will develop a novel experimental approach to broadly and deeply define the types of proteins most sensitive to codon usage and the codon usage patterns that best support the folding of proteins to their native, active structures.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Since current clinical imaging (MRI/PET) can only detect tumors larger than 10 million tumor cells, it is exceedingly difficult to distinguish whether cancer therapies shrink tumor size by killing tumors or causing tumor cell scattering. These two scenarios have vastly different implications for the metastatic spread of cancer that eventually causes patient death. There are now more than 2.2 million women Veterans in the United States, and the health concerns of this growing female Veteran population are a VA priority. The National Cancer Institute estimates that 1 out of 8 women will develop breast cancer in their lifetime, yielding a current population of 275,000 female Veterans who will confront breast cancer and require effective treatment. This project will develop strategies to improve breast cancer treatment for the growing female Veteran population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Universal Human Papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination would significantly decrease cervical, vaginal, vulvar, anal, and oral cancers, and reduce racial disparities in these cancers. In this project we will further adapt our Embodied Conversational Agent for HPV system to produce an English and Spanish smartphone ECA-HPV system to provide vaccine recommendations and motivational interviewing to parents/guardians and vaccine-eligible adolescents and facilitate communication with clinic staff. If proven effective, this scalable approach can be broadly implemented and adapted to other childhood, adolescent, maternal, and adult immunizations.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will provide essential information regarding which intervention targets and strategies are most likely to improve receipt of preventive services and ultimately reduce morbidity among children with SCA. We will use quantitative methods to identify critical targets within the healthcare delivery system, as well as key subgroups of the population, that can be intervened upon to improve the receipt of preventive services, and qualitative methods to identify barriers and facilitators to receipt of these services. We will integrate the findings from the quantitative analysis with the results from the qualitative analysis to fill the gap in understanding specific targets within the healthcare system, key population subgroups, and feasible strategies for interventions to maximize the receipt of preventive services among children with sickle cell anemia.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Opportunities to optimize the receipt of preventive services among children with sickle cell anemia: A Mixed Methods Approach

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of “Diagnostic Innovations in Glaucoma Study (DIGS): Glaucoma and High Myopia” is to improve our understanding and detection of progressive glaucoma in patients who are particularly challenging to correctly diagnose with the disease, individuals with high myopia. The prevalence of myopia is increasing rapidly and Individuals with high myopia are at a higher risk of developing glaucoma. With its extensive longitudinal structural, functional and vascular testing and deep learning analysis strategies, this study will enhance our understanding of the complex relationship between structural, functional and vascular changes in glaucoma and improve our ability to manage the disease and prevent glaucoma-related functional impairment and blindness in individuals with high myopia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. We will use mouse and rat models of Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) to determine whether neonatal lung angiogenesis, pulmonary hypertension (PH), pathologic lung remodeling and lung regeneration in hyperoxia-injured animals can be improved via nanoparticle-based gene delivery of FOXF1 transcription factor into the pulmonary circulation, or via cell therapy with FOXF1+ general capillary cells (FOXF1+ gCAPs) which serve as progenitors of pulmonary microvascular endothelial cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Differentiation therapy is curative in one subtype of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) and underexplored in the rest. We conducted gain-of-differentiation screens in AML models and identified that combined inhibition of LSD1 and MEN1 synergizes to induce terminal, potentially curative, differentiation in many AMLs. Validating the therapeutic efficacy of these pre-clinical differentiation therapy targets and determining the mechanisms of inhibitor-induced differentiation will change the principles of AML treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) have poor prognosis (median overall survival = 3 years) due to the lack of effective or curative treatment options. Recent evidence has implicated metabolic reprogramming, especially related to glutamine and glutamate metabolism, as a major driver of mCRPC progression and drug resistance, but there are currently no treatments that capitalize on this metabolic vulnerability. The proposed research will validate druggable targets related to glutamine and glutamate metabolism in mCRPC both in vitro and in vivo for improved treatment efficacy and patient outcomes.
