IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many genetic variants have been associated with prostate cancer risk, but the functional mechanisms through which they mediate risk are unclear. Recent efforts have collected and analyzed large-scale functional genomic data (e.g., gene expression, isoform splicing) across a broad category of tissues, however this has primarily been performed in men of European ancestry which limits application to non-European men. Here, we propose to measure methylation, mRNA, proteins, and metabolites in prostate tissue for men of African and European ancestry and integrate them with ultra large-scale prostate cancer GWAS to characterize the genetic regulatory landscape of prostate cancer risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative According to the CDC, Periodontal disease effects 47.2% of people aged 30 and over; by the age of 65, the number of people impacted by the disease jumps to 70.1%. Shifts in the amount and species of bacteria that make up dental plaque are known to be the major cause of tooth decay. Our preliminary results suggest that the building blocks of dental plaque are small multispecies dental plaque aggregates left over from routine oral hygiene, a finding with potential clinical importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL – PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced technologies in radiation therapy and the higher cost of proton therapy have engendered the need to accurately compare photon and proton radiation treatment modalities based on their clinical effectiveness to facilitate the improved selection of the optimum modality for cancer radiotherapy. As a follow up to our previous MD Anderson and Massachusetts General Hospital collaborative program projects, which explored the clinical applicability of proton therapy, in the proposed joint program project we will investigate the unique physical, biological and immunomodulatory properties of proton therapy vs. photon therapy and apply the knowledge thus gained to develop precision medicine techniques to identify the patients most likely to benefit from protons and optimize proton and photon therapy to maximize their effectiveness. This approach is a marked paradigm shift from the conventional assumption that improved dosimetry alone or population-based (as opposed to precision medicine) techniques will lead to better outcomes with protons in unselected patients and reframes the discussion for how patients should be assigned to a particular modality and their treatments optimized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National User Resource for Biological Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (User Resource) will provide ultra-sensitive Carbon-14 isotopic analysis by accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) for NIH-funded researchers. The User Resource will enable a deeper understanding of the etiology of human health concerns by enabling quantification of pharmacokinetics and other molecular endpoints directly in humans; offering the ability to conduct quantitative studies using biologics such as proteins or lipids; and enabling more relevant studies of metabolic pathways in health and disease through the use of much lower, more biologically-relevant, concentrations of metabolic substrates in cells and intact organisms. The User Resource will increase the accessibility and visibility of ultra-sensitive 14C measurements by training new investigators and expanding the National user base while concurrently improving the efficiency of AMS measurements through installation of new interfaces, technical modifications to ion sources and upgrades to data analysis software for improved ease of use and data reporting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients diagnosed with Barrett’s esophagus have a more than 30-fold higher risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) than the average person, and thus are advised to undergo follow-up examinations for early detection of EAC when it can be removed. With current clinical measurements, however, it is impossible to discern which patients are most likely to develop EAC versus the >90% who will never get this rare but deadly cancer. In efforts to solve this public health question, we aim to interrogate the entirety of Barrett’s tissue, measure how it evolves over time in patients, and look for clues in these “tissue maps” to better decide who needs preventative action and who can live their life with less worry and intensive surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For persons living with dementia (PLWD), and particularly for those with serious illness, an Emergency Department (ED) visit is a critical event and an opportunity to address the unmet needs that preceded this visit. Our multiple PI (mPI) team, who have together conducted cluster-randomized, multi-site trials in >50 EDs as well as multiple hospice and home health agencies, is uniquely poised to address previous shortcomings in the development of scalable models of care for PLWD. The overarching goal of EDs LEading the Transformation of Alzheimer’s and Dementia Care (ED-LEAD) is to turn an ED visit from a crisis into an opportunity to improve the health and well-being of PLWD and their care partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 2 - Narrative Radiation-Induced Lymphopenia: Understanding, Predictive Modeling and Developing Photon and  Proton-Based Mitigation Strategies Radiation therapy (RT), a key pillar of cancer management, causes a common, yet often ignored, side effect – immune system suppression (i. e., radiation-induced lymphopenia [RIL]). Severe RIL has been linked to poor cancer treatment outcomes, presumably due to the reduced tumor surveillance by the immune system, thereby increasing disease recurrence and distant metastasis after RT. We propose approaches to identify clinical and dosimetric factors that predict the risk and severity of RIL and understand the impact of RIL on the immune diversity and profile as it affects clinical outcomes; to develop models that can accurately predict the risk of RIL individualized to a patient’s baseline clinical factors; and to use such models in the optimization of radiation dose distributions to mitigate RIL and its impact on outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Challenging physical or social experiences in early life can have long-lasting effects on individual health. The proposed work will leverage two well-established, unique human cohorts as well as new lab-based, experimental assays to investigate the gene regulatory mechanisms that underlie this relationship as well as the genetic factors that predict individual susceptibility versus resilience. In doing so, this work will improve our understanding how early life experiences become “embedded” into lifelong physiology, our appreciation of the role genotype x environment interactions play in this process, and our insight into intervention strategies that are likely to be effective and that appropriately target individuals at high risk of poor outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autoimmune diseases are caused by immune system cells that have escaped normal controls and inappropriately seek out our normal cells for destruction. These bad killer cells recognize specific normal protein sequences on a cell’s surface as a signal to kill it. We will develop an assay to discover what sequences these bad killer cells recognize, and use the assay to discover normal sequences relevant to Type 1 Diabetes. Once we know what normal sequences these killer cells recognize we can use the sequences to design a vaccine that regulates their killing.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Home-Based Primary Care (HBPC) is a distinctive home care program for Veterans with complex chronic disease at high risk of long-term institutionalization and HBPC enrollment is associated with lower hospitalization risk and reduced costs. Expansion of HBPC by 75 sites is planned by fiscal year 2026. However, there is substantial variation in individual HBPC sites in program structure, patients served, and clinical outcomes. It is unknown if this variation represents variable fidelity to the HBPC clinical model or appropriate flexibility and adaptation to local context. In this mixed-methods study, we will perform a detailed exploration of variation in HBPC program, identify configurations of HBPC site features associated with high performance in patient home time, a novel patient-centered outcome, and elucidate mechanisms of success using configurational analysis, an emerging mixed-methods approach.

PHR: NARRATIVE There is a critical underrepresentation of cancers from American Indian patients in national cancer genome databases. Additionally, American Indians have the poorest cancer survival rates of all ethnicities in the United States. PHR: Project Narrative: Tens of millions of Americans suffer from chronic pain, and the epidemic of overdose deaths related to opioids makes it clear that safer treatments are needed. To help develop new, safer treatments, scientists must learn much more about the genes and cells that contribute to pain in humans. This application proposes a new center that will map the genes and cells associated with various types of pain, focusing on the peripheral nerves and spinal cord, to provide important new information to help with the development of new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE The current ROBIN proposal addresses a knowledge gap on how standard radiotherapy affects the patient’s immune system. By inviting patients newly diagnosed with rectal cancer to donate for research small tumor, stool and blood samples, collected during standard colonoscopy procedure (before and after standard treatment), we will create a bio-repository (a bank of tissues) to study the characteristics of the tumors that respond to radiation and those that don’t: this insight may help avoiding additional treatments in future patients and select others for more effective treatments. We have converged a team of outstanding scientists, physicists, clinicians and patient advocates to carry out this task.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In African Americans, prostate cancer is characterized by higher aggressiveness, more extensive metastases, early- onset, and increased mortality rates than those in Caucasian Americans. We hypothesize that the racial disparity in prostate cancer diagnosis can be reduced by using racially associated magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) analysis. The proposed MRI-based analysis model will be evaluated for men of different racial/ethnic characteristics at the University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) and the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a highly lethal disease and is characterized by extensive hypoxic fibroinflammatory stroma which contributes to the ineffectiveness of immunotherapies. Interactions between tumor cells and surrounding stromal cells substantially influence immune suppression and tumor progression, and the goal of this proposal is to elucidate how hypoxia regulates the recruitment and function of macrophages in pancreatic cancer. My studies will expand our understanding of how hypoxia drives an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, and provide insight into the development of effective immunotherapeutic strategies against pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Stem cells hold great potential for advancing public health, given their critical role in the growth and maintenance of tissues. In addition, many therapies in regenerative medicine are focused on the use of stem cells to replace damaged or missing tissues. Hydractinia represents a new and powerful animal research organism for identifying the molecular and cellular mechanisms that regulate and guide stem cells during homeostasis and regeneration, and the understanding of these mechanisms gained from this project will significantly inform the field of regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Many neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders are associated with characteristic motor abnormalities; e.g., patients with Tourette syndrome, dystonia, autism spectrum, and obsessive compulsive disorders typically show repetitive motor behaviors. In rodent disease models, compulsive repetitive behaviors often manifest as excessive grooming and the striatum plays critical roles in patterning and execution of this stereotyped motor output. A better understanding of how striatal circuits mediate grooming behavior may shed light on neurobiological control of repetitive behaviors in normal and pathological conditions.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that is common in the veteran population. The current and newer therapies are fairly effective at decreasing the morbidity of RA but still have unintended consequences. One commonality of all of the disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARD) therapies is that they are immunosuppressive in a variety of ways. Analysis of response to the new recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) in RA patients proposed in this study has direct clinical relevance and translational potential. It may influence the choices of therapies to be utilized as there are many options for treating RA. It could provide data that supports a clinical trial using drug windowing where the immunemodulatory drug is withheld transiently after vaccination to improve the response. It has been shown recently in RA patients that windowing methotrexate after influenza vaccination was beneficial to the anti-influenza response elicited.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative East Trenton is an environmental justice community that bears a disproportionate burden of lead exposure in addition to low income, high population of less than high school education, and large minority population. This project’s goal is to identify lead exposure pathways within this community using citizen science, providing risk reduction strategies, and testing their efficacy. This project is a potential model for mitigating exposure risk in other lead burdened communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral palsy (CP) is one of the most prevalent and costly developmental disabilities in the United States. Current research and therapeutic interventions related to mobility for transition aged persons with CP is lacking. This project will use clinical mobility outcomes and neurophysiological assessments to probe if a novel robotic exoskeleton gait training protocol will drive beneficial neuroplasticity in transition aged persons with CP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE 1: COMPUTATIONAL - NARRATIVE The significance of Core 1 lies in the accumulation and maintenance of detailed clinical and physical data necessary to enable studies correlating outcomes with the physical and or biological doses radiation delivered. In doing so, we will gain new knowledge into the true biological effectiveness of protons vs. photons in relation to the underlying physical factors. Our gained knowledge and integrated data collection will be introduced into clinical treatment planning systems in order to improve decision-making and outcomes for all patients treated with protons vs. photons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most of the vertebrate genome finds its ultimate origin in transposable elements (TEs), and the thorough annotation of TEs is a critical aspect of genome annotation pipelines. We have developed an innovative open access database (Dfam) that yields substantial gains in TE annotation quality and provides numerous novel features in support of community TE curation. Here, we describe the necessary next steps for the expansion and improvement of the Dfam resource, capable of meeting the demands of large-scale genome reference projects and a broader research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE 2: TRANSLATIONAL BIOSPECIMEN AND IMAGING BIOMARKER - NARRATIVE The Translational Biospecimen and Imaging Biomarker Core Component (Core 2) is building a unique centralized resource to support biospecimen and imaging data collection from radiation-treated patients, will support sample processing and sharing using standardized protocols. Such activities will be carried out for patients enrolled on the NIH-funded clinical trials as well as from other clinical studies of radiotherapy relevant to the hypotheses tested in this grant. Core 2 will establish a database repository with the goals of: (i) creating a standardized patient consent and enrollment process to create efficiencies of scale; (ii) streamlining logistics and processes, reducing redundancy and maximizing the use of human and laboratory resources; (iii) diminishing data loss due to inconsistencies between protocols; and (iv) creating a central resource for translational research and molecular studies at the MD Anderson and MGH Cancer Centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Possible treatments for alcohol use disorder (AUD) include psychosocial therapies, Alcoholics Anonymous or similar 12-step programs, and pharmacotherapy, but only 20% of persons with lifetime AUD seek treatment of any kind. We propose to develop, validate, and apply a computer simulation model to estimate and compare the lifetime benefits of various AUD treatments and to augment an existing decision aid with such information to support shared decision-making. Results from this project will help to close the treatment gap by increasing their use, hence improving the medical care and quality of life for millions of Americans suffering from AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Key steps in vision include: (1) the absorption of light by the visual pigments of retinal rod and cone cells, which initiates a phototransduction cascade, and (2) the regeneration of these pigments by both enzymatic and light- dependent mechanisms. Although much has been learned about the chemistry and biology of these two pathways, fundamental questions remain unanswered. A more comprehensive understanding of these processes is essential to further delineate the etiology of human blinding diseases and consequently, to develop innovative therapeutic interventions that advance the practice of medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human-centered design (HCD) is a paradigm for problem-solving that is gaining attention in the development of explainable artificial intelligence for clinical decision support, but implementation is hindered because it requires a multidisciplinary team of sociotechnical and clinical experts. Building on my unique background of over 10 years in clinical pediatric neuro-oncology and my previously published work and preliminary data in developing clinical artificial intelligence (AI), my proposal applies HCD methods to make usable clinical AI to improve clinical experts' ability to non-invasively diagnose pediatric suprasellar tumors. Upon completing this work, I will have the necessary multidisciplinary skill set to become an independent scientist focused on applying HCD to develop AI in pediatric neuro-oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aberrant transcriptional hub formation, defined by high local concentrations of proteins, has been associated with disease, including cancers and human expansion repeat disease, yet the exact functional consequence of hub formation remains unknown. Oncogenic mutations in the chromatin reader protein, ENL, are linked to transcriptional hub formation and are required for hyper-transcriptional activation of target genes. These mutations are a powerful system in which to understand hub-mediated transcription and the effect of hub formation the molecular kinetics of incorporated proteins, genome organization and alter transcriptional dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from primordial germ cells (PGCs) and are the most common tumors in newborns and fetuses, causing significant perinatal morbidity and mortality and having a 35% rate of recurrence. This study aims to characterize, at the molecular level, the transition of PGCs to teratomas, understand the potential that apoptosis-resistance has on this transition, and to model this in vivo. These studies will identify the important developmental trajectories that occur with reversion from PGCs to pluripotency to tumor, improve insight to aid development of biomarkers for teratoma recurrences, and provide potential targetable pathways to treat the most aggressive tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Diseases of the colon are widespread, with colorectal cancer the 2nd leading cause of cancer death in the US and inflammatory bowel disease highly prevalent and rising in incidence across the globe. These pathologies have distinct presentations and outcomes across the length of the colon, but the genetic etiologies of these differences are poorly understood and limit precision treatment. By understanding how somatic mosaicism differs throughout the colon and disease development, we will be better equipped to treat these pathologies, better prepared to identify at-risk individuals, and better able to study tissue-specific disease progression in other organ systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project could impact public health because it investigates B7-H3, a therapeutic target for neuroblastoma, for which immunotherapies have been developed and are in current or future clinical trials. This proposal aims to understand the mechanism by which B7-H3 is regulated, in addition to its functions as an oncoprotein. This research will help to meet the unmet need for the development of novel immunotherapeutic approaches in neuroblastoma while simultaneously furthering the translational research skills in an early career scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Imbalanced protein homeostasis (proteostasis) disrupts protein clearance and increases abnormal deposition of protein aggregates which facilitates cancer cell survival and progression. Ubiquitin mediated proteolysis pathway and proteasome activity are suppressed in next generation anti-androgen resistant prostate cancer cells which results in stabilized androgen receptor variant protein in these resistant cells through Hsp70/Stub1 machinery. This proposal will provide new insights into the role of chaperone- ubiquitin-proteasome alteration in advanced prostate cancer and devise the strategies to overcome the therapeutic resistance.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a fatal muscle disease with a predicted incidence of 1 in 5000 males. In this Phase 2B SBIR proposal, StrykaGen in collaboration with the Nghiem lab at the Texas A&M University, propose to perform critical preclinical and GRMD dog efficacy studies using our lead α7 integrin enhancing small molecule called Stryka969. Results from this study will move Stryka969 towards IND and clinical trials as a therapeutic option for patients with DMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: HEALING LODGE OF THE SEVEN NATIONS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL With proper training, people can stabilize mental health crisis situations, such as youth in recovery risking relapse, until professional help is available. However, tribal communities might require culturally-appropriate approaches to be most successful, which led to the development of a new mental health support training system for tribal communities, xaʔtus for Mental Health. To ensure that xaʔtus for Mental Health is an effective evidence- based public health intervention system, the proposed set of studies and capacity building activities will rigorously evaluate the program, further advance its development, and ensure its widespread use among tribal communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a vital unmet medical need for new and effective therapeutics for neurological disorders, yet the drug development process remains a challenge due in large in part to a lack of translatable assays, models, and technologies to identify novel drug candidates. Q-State Biosciences has built an industry leading platform that combines cell-based disease models, engineered proteins, custom automated microscopes, and advanced analytics to allow visualization and characterization of electrical signaling in excitable, disease-relevant cell types such as neurons. Here, we propose to build an ultra-high throughput screening instrument that leverages our proprietary optogenetic tools for light-based stimulation and recording of electrophysiology and sensitive camera-based detection for robust measurements of cellular activity whereby successful execution of the proposal will enable a broad suite of novel assays on a wide range of excitable cell types for drug discovery in disorders of the nervous system, including areas of significant need such as chronic pain and severe epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: SARS-CoV-2 is a novel ß-coronavirus that causes the disease called COVID-19, which is responsible for over 5 million deaths since late 2019. We propose using molecular virology assays and live-cell and super-resolution microscopy to visualize important processes that occur during SARS-CoV-2 replication after entry into human airway cells, including evaluation of variants of concern. Improved understanding of SARS-CoV-2 infection may lead to more effective COVID-19 therapies for infected individuals and could prepare us for preventing new coronaviruses that arise in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain norepinephrine (NE) has been implicated in amphetamine-type stimulant (ATS) use/addiction, yet not much is known about the role of NE in ATS-induced reward and behaviors due to a limited understanding of brain NE circuits. This proposal will determine how the poorly understood and sexually dimorphic bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST)-NE system contributes to methamphetamine (METH)-induced drug seeking and reinstatement using an innovative approach that incorporates chemogenetics and in vivo fast scan cyclic voltammetry. These studies will provide insights into the underlying mechanisms of ATS use and lead to novel therapeutic targets and sex specific treatment for ATS use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: AUD is a debilitating neuropsychiatric disorder and the third-leading preventable cause of death in the US, yet remains without efficient treatments. The GABAergic neurosteroid, allopregnanolone (Allo) is decreased in AUD postmortem brain and in rat models of alcohol dependence. PPAR-α is an epigenetically modifiable neuronal target that regulates Allo biosynthesis and anxiety, reduces alcohol drinking, and may thus provide a pharmacological target for symptoms of alcohol withdrawal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fetal-derived resident tissue macrophages (RTMs) are pervasive cells that reside in all major tissues and acquire unique tissue-specific homeostatic roles during development; however, we have not had a direct and simple system to test the extent tissue development is educated by seeding of fetal-derived RTMs. Our preliminary data and published data indicate that RTMs in the cochlea are critical component of normal tissue development and also expand abnormally in response to congenital infection. The objective of this grant is to elucidate the role of fetal-derived RTMs in normal and abnormal cochlear development, to further define mechanisms of pathogenesis within the inner ear, and to identify RTMs as a potential novel therapeutic target for hearing loss treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the Center for Childhood Obesity Prevention is to establish a broad-based, multi-disciplinary disease prevention center, rooted in a team science approach and spanning the full translational spectrum, to bring together research in complex disease origins, epidemiology, and social systems to address the childhood obesity crisis. Efforts will continue to build state-of-the-art institutional biomedical research infrastructure to support this goal, as well as continuing to build and train a critical mass of scientists focused on creating the base of evidence for strategies to improve child health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Diabetes is a common chronic disease in the U.S. veteran population, and non-healing skin wounds are a major cause of loss of limb and debility for veterans with diabetes. Current medical treatments have limited effectiveness at healing wounds because it is not entirely clear how diabetes impairs the healing process. The primary goal of these studies is to identify inflammation signals that direct the early growth of new blood vessels to help with healing. By understanding these mechanisms, we believe these studies will lead to new therapies that promote more effective skin healing and limb salvage for veterans and all patients with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of this project is to create the scientific foundation that will empower pain researchers around the world to approach the problem of treating pain in a new way, deeply rooted in a fundamental understanding of the first neurons and first synapses in the human pain pathway. Our Center will identify molecular phenotypes, using single cell and spatial transcriptomic technologies, of human sensory neurons from the dorsal root ganglion (DRG) and spinal dorsal horn neurons and cells in organ donor recovered tissues and in patients suffering from chronic pain. We envision creating actionable knowledge and data resources that can transform our understanding of human pain conditions.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Perinatal Mood and Anxiety Disorder Learning Laboratory at Children’s National will redesign postpartum maternal mental health care, develop new technology for patient-provider communication, allow benchmarking and systems monitoring, and evaluate system threats and costs. This is a critical next step that brings us closer to new comprehensive, point-of-care maternal mental health care models on a large scale. The project is relevant to AHRQ’s call for using systems engineering approaches by multidisciplinary healthcare teams to test innovative solutions that improve quality and can be replicated and disseminated to improve outcomes for mothers and infants.

PROJECT_TITLE: Perinatal Mood and Anxiety Learning Laboratory in a Freestanding Children's Hospital

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer (PCa) is the most common non-skin cancer among American men. The proposed work will benefit public health by advancing a new HIFU technology, histotripsy, for transrectal non-thermal ablation of prostate cancer to provide a non-invasive, effective focal therapy of PCa with reduced side effects compared to standard treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Myc protein is an essential regulator of growth in all normal cells, but in many cancers Myc is escapes normal controls and supports high rates of growth needed for tumor progression. In this proposal we will determine what events contribute to activation of Myc in tumors and devise approaches to inhibit Myc function. This research is relevant to public health because it will ultimately lead a better understanding of the causes for cancer and provide new approaches to cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Long-term opioid treatment of chronic pain (CP) patients is associated with worsening sleep deficiencies, expressed as inadequate sleep duration and daytime sleepiness. Importantly, opioid-induced sleep disruptions decrease pain tolerance, increase vulnerability for addiction and might trigger suicidal ideations. We will study a novel, neuronal pathway that contributes to these important adverse opioid effects and investigate if this pathway might be therapeutically targeted to reduce the severity and inherent comorbidities of sleep disorders in patients receiving long-term opioid therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Glaucoma, a leading cause of blindness worldwide and frequent cause of visual impairment in the US, is an important public health issue, affecting individuals of African descent at an earlier age and more commonly resulting in blindness. By exploring the genetic and physiologic basis of these disparities, our research will provide support for our hypothesis proposing differences in oxygen/mitochondrial metabolism and oxidative stress (from “toxic” free radicals) within the tissues (trabecular meshwork) of the drain of the eye that control eye pressure, the most significant modifiable risk factor for glaucoma. Improving our understanding of how individuals of African descent are more susceptible to damage will also expand potential novel pathways of therapy and prevention for all individuals afflicted by or at risk for this blinding disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The fetal immune system is considered underdeveloped, immature, and involved in maintaining immune tolerance. However, macrophages produced in the liver and trafficking to multiple fetal tissues have a pro- inflammatory phenotype. In the lung, this inflammatory signature peaks around birth and then becomes suppressed in mature alveolar macrophages in the postnatal period. This proposal will characterize the development of inflammatory macrophage phenotypes in fetal tissues and test specific molecular mechanisms regulating expression of these inflammatory signatures.

PHR: Osteoarthritis (OA) is the leading cause of disability in adults, affecting 1 out of 5 adults, and is associated with traumatic joint injury in 10% of cases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project proposes to identify a key molecular regulator of mitochondrial lipid oxidation in the retinal pigment epithelium. Since mitochondrial dysfunction is a crucial pathogenic factor in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the proposed studies will enhance our understanding of this blinding disorder. The information generated from this project has the potential to lead to oral drug treatment for AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The average age of the population is increasing and with it the prevalence of age-associated cognitive decline. Physical activity (PA) is associated with lower risk for cognitive decline, but many people struggle to maintain PA over the long term, and most existing research on theory-based exercise interventions has been generated among high SES, low diversity samples. This study aims to take a community engaged research approach to develop and test a theory-based intervention to promote exercise maintenance using goal setting and exercise intensity among a vulnerable population (i.e., the Black community) as well as determine the extent to which psychological mediators explain the effects of these interventions on exercise maintenance and changes in biomarkers associated with cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-healing chronic wounds (e.g., diabetic foot ulcers) affect millions of people in the US, but existing therapeutic options have limited efficacy. We propose to elucidate the functional role of crosstalk between Langerhans cells and epithelial cells in skin wound repair by using an innovative in vivo imaging system and novel genetic strategies. The results from this proposed research will have broad implications for understanding mechanisms underlying skin regeneration and inform the development of therapeutic targets for chronic wounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative It is not fully understood how risk factors contribute to Latinos’ high risks of developing nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and its sequelae of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), cirrhosis, and liver cancer. This study will examine metabolic products of diet in a large study sample of Latinos (Hispanic Community Health Study – Study of Latinos, N=16,415 adults from four US centers) with state-of-the-art imaging of subclinical liver fibrosis and steatosis. Based upon our results, diet and metabolome features that predict NAFLD may be translated into low-cost risk screening tests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Pacific Center for Genome Research (PCGR) at the University of Hawaii at Manoa (UHM) is designed to advance Genomic Research workforce at a Minority Serving Institution (MSI) with a mission to serve historically underrepresented population in biomedical research, Native Hawaiians and other Pacific Islanders. We will support a multi-investigator, interdisciplinary team to develop two interrelated and highly innovative genomic research projects, along with three cores, namely, Administrative Core, Genomic Workforce Development Core, and Community Engagement Core. Through the proposed initiative, genomic research capacity will be substantially increased in Hawaii.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Acetaminophen (APAP or paracetamol) is a commonly used medication by pregnant people; however, concerns have been raised over possible adverse effects of APAP on fetal development. We propose to conduct in-depth analyses using highly unique data sources from the Danish National Birth Cohort (DNBC) and investigate whether prenatal and postnatal exposures to APAP affect neurodevelopment from infancy through age 18. Our project will generate robust and scientifically rigorous data that can be used to inform regulatory recommendations and policymaking decisions for APAP and related medication use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent national need to grow a strong genomic workforce which includes populations underrepresented in biomedical research. We propose a streamlined educational feeder pipeline called PoWER-G (Promotion of Workforce Employment and Readiness in Genomics) providing an innovative “on-the- degree” training and professional development platform which draws upon the substantial student diversity within the University of Hawaii system. Knowledge generated by this pilot project will lead to development of a formal 1-year Graduate Certificate Program to promote diversity in the genomic workforce and to continue to meet the exponential growth in genomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Gender minority young adults (GMYA) experience unique stress related to their gender identity and/or expression, which may be amplified be amplified by current events like the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and political actions to restrict the rights of GMYA, that can contribute to worse depression and anxiety compared to their cisgender counterparts. Evidence suggests increasing self-compassion among GM people could decrease depression and anxiety by reducing shame and rumination, but the full mindful self-compassion (MSC) intervention has yet to be tested among GMYA. If feasible and acceptable, MSC could be evaluated in a larger clinical trial for its ability to reduce the impact of gender minority stress on GMYA mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The Community Engagement Core (CEC) will provide the oversight needed to ensure the U54 Pacific Center for Genome Research (PCGR)’s consideration of equity and ethics in the examination of genetic and other risk factors across the underserved and ethnic minority groups, including Native Hawaiians (NHs), Africans, Latinos, Asians, and Europeans served by this research. The CEC will broadly engage these populations and their providers to increase their awareness of genetic and omic risks for disease and obtain their input on our research. The CEC activities will support the dissemination of findings from the two PCGR projects includingProject 1, to better characterize roles of genetically predicted DNA methylation, gene expression, protein expression, and metabolite levels in the blood tissue and known non-genetic risk factors in influencing risks of multiple diseases across NHs, Africans, Latinos, Asians, and Europeans, and Project 2, to characterize genomic risk factors of lung cancer in NHs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because correctly identifying and characterizing cancer subtypes is key to improving the accuracy of prognoses and making treatments more effective. This project will create a complete analysis pipeline and web application able to integrate multi-omics studies, discover molecular subtypes, visualize subtypes’ pathway signatures, which could potentially be targets for therapeutic interventions. This tool will greatly enhance the cancer research community’s capacity for patient stratification and characterization by allowing the vast amount of data stored on public and private repositories to be used more efficiently than is currently possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are urgent needs to identify causally related methylation, gene, protein, and metabolite biomarkers in blood for risk of multiple human diseases across multi-ethnic populations. The proposed study will identify causally related omic biomarkers for multiple diseases using an innovative design and evaluate interactions between newly identified and established markers and known non-genetic risk factors on influencing disease risk. Knowledge generated by this project will significantly contribute to the etiologic understanding of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women living with HIV (WLH) have a greater risk of developing invasive cervical cancer due to greater incidence and longer persistence of high-risk human papillomavirus infection. The primary objectives of this NCI K01 proposal are to: (1) conduct formative research and pilot test the provider-level and patient-level components of the My Self-Sampling for HPV Awareness, Results, and Empowerment (MySHARE+) intervention to increase cervical cancer screening (HPV self- collection; Pap triage adherence) among under/never-screened WLH and (2) provide Dr. Le with didactic training, directed mentorship, and experiential learning opportunities to develop cancer prevention and control research methods skills and content expertise in quasi-experimental studies and cluster-RCTs using multilevel approaches, digital health/technology- based interventions to promote patient-centered care, and implementation science methodologies and frameworks. This career development award will undoubtedly enable the candidate to comprehensively and systematically expand her multidisciplinary research training and effectively facilitate her successful progression towards independence as a behavioral health researcher with an extramurally-funded program in evidence-based bio-behavioral interventions to reduce cancer health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the second most common cancer in the United States and the leading cause of cancer-related deaths, with Native Hawaiians (NHs) having not just the greatest risk of lung cancer but also the poorest survival outcome when compared with other populations. We propose to conduct a genomic and epigenomic profiling study to help understand the health disparities of NH population in lung cancer risk. This project has the potential to be translated into improved lung cancer screening, precision prevention, and therapeutic intervention in NH and other populations, besides enabling us to train students, researchers, and community workers with fundamental genomic technologies such as whole genome DNA sequencing, a useful technology for conducting biomedical research in any human diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is the most common respiratory sequelae of prematurity and is often fatal. While very few treatment options exist that safely reduce BPD, montelukast is FDA-approved and already shows promise in small neonatal trials. Because of limited pharmacokinetic (PK)/pharmacodynamics (PD) research, the optimal montelukast dose for premature infants to avoid BPD is unknown; leveraging an experienced team, the PRISM PK/PD trial will determine the optimal dose of montelukast to reduce BPD.

PHR: Project Narrative Significant resources are being invested to implement quality improvement initiatives in birthing hospitals across the country. There is great need to evaluate these efforts and demonstrate their effectiveness in reducing the burden of preventable severe maternal morbidity (SMM) and maternal deaths. This study will develop and validate a refined comorbidity index for obstetric patients that allows SMM rate comparisons across hospitals and adequate monitoring of obstetric quality improvement initiatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) remains one of greatest unmet medical needs in our country with estimates of over 5 million Americans suffering from the disease in 2016 with no new symptomatic therapies having been approved over the past 12 years, and currently no approved disease-modifying agents. The timeframe, complexity, and expense of the recruitment process and site activation for AD trials are extremely challenging, and indeed trial enrollment and site network development represent a bottleneck for drug development for the AD field; there is a growing consensus that we must fundamentally overhaul the current clinical trial recruitment and assessment structure. This proposal aims aim to create an optimized infrastructure to optimally design, efficiently launch, rapidly recruit with improved diversity, and successfully complete NIH supported clinical trials in AD and related dementias.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The suicide rates among U.S. military service members and Veterans (MV) remain alarmingly high. The current study’s goals are to apply innovative machine learning (ML) to large MV suicide datasets to (1) establish ML algorithms detecting suicide ideation (SI) and suicide attempt (SA) at different military statuses to proactively inform clinicians and (2) develop an SI/SA longitudinal risk data-visualization profile for clinicians. We harness big data and innovative ML applications to provide a 360-degree view of MV, promoting safer, higher quality, more accessible, equitable, and affordable healthcare means by providing clinicians an evidence-informed tool to proactively, effectively, and efficiently detect SI/SA risk levels among MV clients.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A longitudinal machine learning approach providing clinicians timely detection to prevent military suicide

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Frequent HIV testing among persons at higher risk of HIV infection is crucial for facilitating early treatment initiation for those who have become HIV-positive and for supporting engagement in appropriate HIV prevention interventions for those who test HIV-negative. However, in many countries with high HIV prevalence there is insufficient retesting among persons at higher risk. This project will use innovative methods to adapt, test and compare multiple low-cost behavioral interventions to increase HIV retesting among adults in rural Kenya and Uganda, with the goal of identifying interventions that can be rapidly implemented at scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Autistic people may experience more persistent pain but may have more difficulty communicating their pain. In this project, we aim to identify better pain measurement for autistic adults and to understand factors that may result in more pain for autistic people. We will also examine how the brain may respond differently to pain in autistic adults with the aim of identifying new targets of pain treatment for autistic individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will use computational modeling, behavioral measurements, ultra-high-field (7 tesla) functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and human intracranial electroencephalography (iEEG) to quantify the role of human posterior superior temporal sulcus and gyrus (STS/G) in audiovisual speech perception. We theorize that neural computations performed in the STS/G are the basis for the uniquely human ability to combine auditory information from the voice and visual information from the face of the person we are communicating with. A better understanding of STS/G has the potential to benefit the millions of Americans who suffer from impaired communication due to stroke or hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hispanics/Latinos suffer from higher risk of diabetes than non-Hispanic whites, but little is known about the mechanism behind this disparity. Leveraging the rich clinical data collected by the Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos (HCHS/SOL), this project seeks to examine how sociocultural, psychosocial, and lifestyle risk and resilience factors affect aging and risk of diabetes. Such results will greatly enhance our understanding of the mechanisms through which socioenvironmental factors contribute to aging and diabetes, and hold promise for precision prevention and intervention tailored to Hispanics/Latinos.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) is a major cause of childhood mortality globally, and novel point-of-care tools are needed to support earlier diagnosis and rapid TB treatment initiation in lower-level health facilities. This study will develop and initially validate artificial-intelligence (AI) models that utilize lung sounds to automatically detect lower airway abnormalities and TB in children, alone and in combination with clinical data included in TB treatment decision algorithms. If successful, this would support the integration of AI-based digital health tools into clinical care to increase the early detection and treatment of TB and other respiratory diseases in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with asthma from historically marginalized populations experience high rates of emergency department (ED) visits, and numerous barriers to guideline-based preventive asthma care in both clinical and home settings put these children at risk for needing additional ED or hospital care in the future. This project is expected to have a profound impact on public health because it proposes an innovative and technologically-driven intervention to address essential gaps in asthma care for children in the ED at greatest risk for poor outcomes. Should this program prove successful in improving preventive care and patient-important outcomes following ED discharge, it has the potential to serve as a sustainable model for children with asthma in other care settings, as well as for children with other chronic diseases that require well-informed home management to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a very serious, incurable disease of the brain, which is a common cause of death throughout the world. By targeting a novel therapeutic target, Luciole Pharmaceuticals is developing first-in-class agents as disease-modifying therapeutics for AD. Our efforts have the potential to lead to the discovery of a novel, safe, and very effective oral medicine for AD, which will improve patients’ quality-of-life and increase their life expectancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The progressive accumulation of DNA mutations in somatic tissues drives cancer and other diseases; despite significant advances in our understanding of mutational processes, the answer to many fundamental questions in the field of genome integrity is still a mystery. In this project, the first goal is to develop a novel functional ‘reporter’ to estimate DNA mutation rates in mammalian cells with a sensitivity >50 fold compared to current methods. The second major goal of this project will be to study mutation rate in several types of human cells and comprehensively identify all genes that regulate mutation rates across cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative In Ecuador, the HIV epidemic is concentrated primarily among transgender women—those who identify as women or on the transfeminine spectrum and who were assigned a male sex at birth. There is an urgent need for status-neutral HIV interventions tailored to this high-risk group. Through this K01, the candidate will assess the mechanisms through which intersectional discrimination exerts its impact on linkage to HIV prevention and care for transgender women in Ecuador while extending and deepening their research skills to receive advanced training in intersectional qualitative, quantitative, intervention development, and grant writing. Findings will inform policymakers and development of culturally tailored HIV interventions that will mitigate intersectional discrimination and reduce HIV burden in this NIH-designated disparity population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project is relevant to public health because it will examine the extended amygdalar and respiratory circuits involved in sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP), the most common cause of death in refractory epilepsy patients. The proposed research builds on our preliminary data indicating that the extended amygdala is a critical mediator in mortality in a mouse model of SUDEP. The results of this work will provide a foundation to identify potential new mechanistic targets and strategies to modify SUDEP risk, which aligns with the mission of NINDS to reduce the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common type of dementia in the elderly, which accounts for 60-80% of cases. Currently, an estimated 5.7 million Americans of all ages have AD. VGF(non-acronymic) is synthesized by neurons in the brain where it promotes growth and survival of neurons, and is involved in neurogenesis, synaptogenesis and energy homeostasis. Therefore, strong scientific premises indicate that increasing VGF levels in the brain could be a promising therapeutic strategy to treat AD. The long-term goal of the proposed research is to design a non-viral gene delivery carrier for efficient delivery of pVGF to brain through intravenous and intranasal routes for prevention and treatment of aging-related cognitive decile including AD. The studies will be conducted in vitro and in vivo in Wild Type, amyloid 5xFAD and PS19 mice models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The objectives of this study are to determine the impact of exposure to adverse activity spaces characterized by high area-levels of violence, policing activity, and racial exclusivity on everyday perceptions of safety, physiological stress, mental health and substance use. We will also consider whether the impact of adverse exposures on safety, stress, and health is greater for youth who believe others perceive their race to be Black in public interactions. Finally, we will explore whether changes in the extent and impact of adolescent adverse activity space exposures have occurred since the period prior to the COVID-19 pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New epidemiologic tools that identify in real time communities with high amounts of circulating HIV may enhance efforts to reduce HIV transmission and substantially contribute to ending the HIV epidemic. During the COVID-19 pandemic we built a robust wastewater sampling program for the Houston region that includes weekly assessment of 39 wastewater collection sites covering about 4 million residents and our preliminary data demonstrate that HIV can also be detected in wastewater. The project will apply our pioneering wastewater sampling program as a powerful new tool to identify geographic areas with a high active burden of HIV, reflecting substantial numbers of people with undiagnosed or untreated HIV infection, and respond to those areas with effort to reduce unsuppressed HIV in those geographic areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Hispanic/Latino (H/L) individuals are at increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) but are less likely to participate in research. Leveraging our existing community engaged research network – the Engaging Communities of Hispanics/Latinos for Aging Research (ECHAR) Network, the proposed work aims to (1) refine and (2) disseminate a culturally responsive multimedia “toolkit” for use in engaging and recruiting Hispanic/Latino adults into AD/ADRD research, monitoring its reach and uptake via various methods, including a phone-based risk calculator. Along these lines, we aim to develop a risk registry that we will leverage for (3) collection of behavioral data and (4) blood specimens that will allow us the workflow and pilot data necessary to begin characterizing the relationships of these variables in a diverse sample of H/Ls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Spatially informative genomics platforms, such as spatial transcriptomics and single cell imaging mass cytometry, are the new frontiers of single cell omics. However, the bioinformatics challenges are outstanding and the applications in clinical treatment are lacking. In this R01 renewal project, we aim to develop multiple cutting edge computational methods for understanding tumor-tumor microenvironment interaction in order to predict drug reposition and patient survival using these new data types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use disorders affect several million people in the United States every year, create significant economic burden, and cause tremendous suffering at the person, family, and societal levels. This proposal aims to investigate the dynamic interplay between pediatric substance use (a risk factor for substance use disorders) and rate of neuromelanin accumulation (a proxy for dopamine function) for the first time. Thus, this application seeks to identify a brain mechanism (dopamine function) that could be targeted in youth by future treatments in order to prevent onset of substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Researching Effective Strategies to Prevent Opioid Death (RESPOND) model is a simulation model of OUD and OUD treatment delivery in a state. We use RESPOND to investigate the health benefits, costs, and cost-effectiveness of policy choices and interventions to expand OUD treatment. With this grant, we will use the model to investigate economic and equity impacts of policies regulating prescribing for medications for OUD and innovative care delivery models for people with OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder remains a significant public health crisis with poor clinical decision support- predicting use is still challenging and ineffectively accounts for the constellation of factors that play a role in escalation and/or dependence. We will apply a machine learning approach leveraging the diverse and equitable AllOfUs dataset which will integrate genomics, social, and clinical factors to predict development of opioid use disorder. Novel biomarkers will be elucidated to aid in future clinical support for these at-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because Rett syndrome (RTT) is an X-linked neurodevelopmental disorder caused by heterozygous loss-of-function mutation of the MECP2 gene in girls without effective treatment. We propose to apply our DNA methylation editing tools to reactivate the silent wild type allele of MECP2 gene from the inactive X chromosome. Our success in demonstrating MECP2 reactivation and functional rescue in RTT animal model will pave the way for future clinical trials of MECP2 methylation editing in girls with RTT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Bleeding and clotting complications after severe injury are very common and complicate the management of trauma patients. We will identify strategies to minimize these complications by focusing on restoring the health of the endothelium, the lining of blood vessels, which is an important way the body regulates blood clotting.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The percentage of bilingual learners in the US is expected to rise to 25% by 2030; Spanish is the second most common language in the US. The aims of this proposal are to identify cognitive mechanisms that optimize the success of language development in young Spanish-English bilinguals with developmental language disorders that affect 7.5% of the population, regardless of bilingualism status so as to help early identification and targeted remediation for bilinguals and linguistically-diverse learners with developmental language disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunophotonics proposes this IND-enabling research project for the development of a polymeric synthetic biomaterial, IP-001, to potentiate a systemic immunotherapy via microwave thermal tumor ablation for treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma. IP-001 aims to reduce recurrence post ablation and prolong overall survival in patients by eliciting immune control over systemic micro-metastases. It revolutionizes the field of interventional radiology by transforming it into a means of early immunotherapy that can be applied broadly to other solid cancers without disruption to the standard of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project brings together leading international researchers uniquely positioned to uncover the neurobiological risks of adolescent alcohol use and distinguish these from the consequences of alcohol use in adolescence and across the lifespan. Our aims will be achieved through robust analyses of the landmark Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development Study, as well as harmonization of this study with other international datasets covering the full adult lifespan. Outcomes from this project will have the potential to provide novel neurobiological targets for medication development, as well as alcohol preventions and interventions informed by neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative As both immunotherapy and cannabis use are becoming more widespread therapeutic options in oncology, the demand for prospective data on the effects of cannabis among those being treated with immunotherapy for cancer will continue to grow. Our proposed project fills a gap by providing crucial long-term data on the role of cannabis use on benefits and harms among those receiving immunotherapy. Overall, this study will have a sustained impact on the science of cancer symptom management and ultimately improve patient care and safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the US almost 800’000 people have a stroke every year leaving more than half of these people with permanent arm and hand motor deficits (hemiparesis). Unfortunately, the only option available today is intense physical therapy, which improves motor performances but is not effective for many with moderate and severe post-stroke arm hemiparesis. In this project we will test the efficacy of a novel neurostimulation system targeting the cervical spinal cord in combination with physical therapy to increase strength, ameliorate motor function and improve motor recovery in people with chronic post-stroke hemiparesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to human health because it will combine structural biology and biophysics with conventional cellular neuroscience techniques to test a key hypothesis about how neurotransmitter receptor organization regulates synaptic strength, plasticity, and human disease states. In the future, the detailed structural and functional understanding of glutamate receptor clustering that results from this work will inform the design of therapeutics for targeting the organization of glutamate receptors. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission of protecting and improving human health by understanding the processes that control synaptic neurotransmitter receptor regulation in unprecedented detail.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Inflammation and oxidative stress are major factors in the pathogenesis of acute lung injury and progression to ARDS, for which no pharmacological treatments have been approved. CTX-002 is a special formulation form of CNP-miR146a for intra-tracheal administration, which prevents inflammation and lung injury, and is nontoxic upon systemic delivery in rodents. These efforts described in this proposal are intended to complete IND- enabling studies to file an IND for clearance to begin first-in-human clinical trials, based on recommendations from the FDA from our Pre-IND meeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: From 2023 to 2028, the KIdney Disease in children data Management and Analysis Center (KIDMAC) will continue to perform as the Data Coordinating Center of the Chronic Kidney Disease in Children (CKiD) cohort study. We will provide leadership in study design, coordination and conduct, data management, analytical methodology and quality assurance; thereby enhancing the scientific scope of CKiD. KIDMAC investigators have expertise in research design, coordination, data management, quality assurance/control and epidemiological and biostatistical methods for complex longitudinal and survival data from cohort studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on increasing the uptake of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine in young cancer survivors, a vulnerable population at high risk for developing new cancers (such as cervical and anal cancer) caused by persistent HPV infection. An effective vaccine exists that can prevent these cancers, but HPV vaccine uptake is low among young cancer survivors (fewer than 1 in 4 have received the vaccine). This proposed research will provide important information that can be used to implement new strategies to increase the uptake of the HPV vaccine among young cancer survivors, and thus is relevant to the NIH’s mission to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative There are over 600 neurodegenerative diseases affecting nearly a billion people around the world, and many of these diseases like ALS (commonly known as Lou Gherig’s Disease) are fatal and have no cure or effective treatment. There has not been significant work to find elements that are shared or unique across diseases using new large-scale datasets now available, and standard computational approaches cannot distinguish correlation from causation, slowing down drug development. Our proposed research will develop tools to combine vast amounts of data in a computational system which captures causality, to find drug targets we can test in the lab using patient cells, and to extend a pipeline that can then be expanded to multiple other diseases, contributing to drug development across neurodegenerative diseases, thus accelerating progress towards potential cures. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Recent evidence suggests that blood can act as a surrogate for brain tissue to predict alcohol dependence status and drug treatments in mice, but it is unknown whether this is true for humans. These studies will identify molecular biomarkers that can be obtained in a minimally invasive way through blood sampling and offer an accessible precision medicine approach that will facilitate patient stratification, treatment selection, and patient monitoring, and hence have the potential to greatly improve AUD management and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Lay Summary Uroflowmetry or the measurement of the speed of urine flow rates remains the most common tool by which urologists can assess the health of the lower urinary tract. Current methods of me asurement are time consuming, rely upon paper records, and are limited to the office. We offer a new system that can be used on any regular toilet in the office or home that will transmit the flow data wirelessly into the electronic medical record.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Currently, there are no approved treatments for MPS IIIA (also known as Sanfilippo A syndrome), a genetic disorder that causes progressive degeneration of the brain and other organs leading to death during the teenage years. This study is designed to advance the development of a gene therapy that enables patients to produce functional enzyme that is delivered to the brain and other organs to treat the symptoms of the disease. If successful, this treatment is expected to provide the first and only treatment for this debilitating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will be the first large scale RCT in the US assessing effectiveness and cost effectiveness of XR-B versus SL-B with individuals in a carceral setting who are re-entering community. The study will be significant because most individuals with OUD do not receive buprenorphine treatment while in jail, thereby substantially raising their likelihood of relapse to drug use, overdose death, and re-incarceration when they are released. Finally, understanding how to expand acceptance of extended-release and sublingual buprenorphine in jails, has far-reaching implications for expanding treatment access in this population.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Interventions to Prevent and Treat Addictions Study Section[IPTA]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Multiple etiologies variously contribute to the clinical syndrome of mild cognitive impairment and dementia presumed due to Alzheimer’s disease, but the many factors that give rise to symptoms are difficult to quantify at the level of the individual. A comprehensive panel of imaging and plasma biomarkers will improve the likelihood that etiologies beyond Alzheimer’s disease can be detected. Such individual-level characterization will greatly impact diagnostic accuracy, and prediction of symptom course and response to experimental therapies.
